children.definition: The soil profile is the vertical section of the soil, from the surface throughÂ all its horizons, where a horizon is a layer of soil, approximately parallel toÂ the soil surface, differing in properties and characteristics from adjacentÂ layers below and above it.Â
children.label: SOIL HORIZONS/PROFILE

children.definition: The resistance of the soil to penetration by water and by roots.Â
children.label: SOIL IMPEDANCE
SOIL PRODUCTIVITY
children.definition: The capacity of a soil for producing a specified plant or sequence of plantsÂ under a specified system of management; emphasizing the ability to produceÂ crops.Â

children.label: SOIL STRUCTURE
children.definition: The combination or arrangement of primary soil	particles into secondary unitsÂ or peds. These secondary units may be, but usually are not, arranged in theÂ profile in such a manner as to give a distinctive characteristic pattern.  TheÂ secondary units are characterized and classified on the basis of size, shape,Â and degree of distinctness into classes, types, and grades, respectively.Â

children.label: SOIL ROOTING DEPTH
children.definition: The distance in inches that plant roots extend into the soil. Knowing the  average root depth for the plants in each watering zone is important to  determine an efficient watering schedule. Shallow roots require more frequent  watering than deep roots, which can draw water from a larger soil profile.   Average root depths vary with plant type. Trees will have root depths of 24  inches or more. Xeriscape plants will have root depths around 10 inches. Shrubs and perennials will have roots of 8 inches or more. Grass can have deep roots  (greater than 6 inches, depending on region). Annuals and bedding plants have  the shallowest roots at 4-5 inches.

children.label: FEED CONTAMINATION AND TOXICOLOGY
children.definition: Any measure related to the contamination and toxicology of feed byÂ microorganisms, pathogens, viruses, weeds, etc...Â
Any measure related to the composition of harvested forage, such as hay,Â fodder, silage, grain, or other processed feed for livestock.  May include newÂ mixes, new types, etc..., and any additives.Â
children.label: FEED COMPOSITION

children.definition: Any measure related to the processing of feed, including new methods.Â
children.label: FEED PROCESSING
FEED STORAGE
children.definition: Any measure related to the storage of feed, and new methods for improvedÂ qualtiy over the long term, feed hopper types, etc...Â

children.label: FEED PRODUCTS
children.definition: Any measure related to harvested forage, such as hay, fodder, silage, grain, orÂ other processed feed for livestock.Â

children.label: PLANT COMMODITIES
children.definition: Measurements related to any transportable plant resource product withÂ commercial value; all plant resource products which are articles of commerce. Â Does NOT include Forest Products (see Forest Science > Forest Products).Â

children.label: FIELD CROP PRODUCTS
children.definition: Measurements related to any field crop (plants grown primarily for their seed,Â e.g. corn, wheat, oats, soybeans) products which are articles of commerce.Â
Measurements related to any fruit product which is an  article of commerce .Â
children.label: FRUIT PRODUCTS

children.definition: Measurements related to any Horticultural (flowers and ornimental shrubs andÂ trees, gardens) product which is an  article of commerce .Â
children.label: HORTICULTURAL PRODUCTS

children.definition: Measurements related to any  product which is an  article of commerce .Â
children.label: VEGETABLE PRODUCTS

children.definition: Any measurment related to poultry commodities, including, but not limited to,Â meat, eggs, and feathers, from animals such as chickens, turkeys, ducks, geese,Â etc...Â
children.label: POULTRY PRODUCTS
LIVESTOCK PRODUCTS
children.definition: Any measurement related to livestock commodities (does not include DAIRY orÂ Poultry) including, but not limited to: meat, wool, leather, glue, chemicalsÂ (e.g. insulin), and any other edible or none edible products from beef cattle,Â swine, sheep, horses, and goats.Â
Any measurement related to Dairy commodities/produce, including, but notÂ limited to: milk, cheese, Ice cream, butter, etc...  See Animal Commodities.Â
children.label: DAIRY PRODUCTS

children.definition: Measurments related to any transportable animal resource product withÂ commercial value; all animal resource products which are articles of commerce. Â Does NOT include Apicultural/Sericultural products (see Apiculture orÂ Sericulture).Â
children.label: ANIMAL COMMODITIES
FOREST FIRE SCIENCE
children.definition: The branch of Forestry that studies the effects, benefits,  prevention, movement, and ecology of Fire in forests.  May include any  Forest Fire related items.

children.label: AFFORESTATION/REFORESTATION
children.definition: Afforestation: "the establishment of trees on an area that has lacked forest  cover for a very long time or has never been forested. "  Reforestation: " the natural or artificial restocking (i.e., planting, seeding) of an area with forest trees. Also called forest regeneration. "

children.label: FOREST HARVESTING AND ENGINEERING
children.definition: Process and methods related to removal of trees from the forest for purposes ofÂ forest improvements, manufacturing forest products, and lumber, orÂ conservation.Â
Any measure related to or about the protection and/or conservation of forestsÂ from insects, diseases, pathogens, windstorms, excess logging, and decreasedÂ biotic diversity.Â
children.label: FOREST PROTECTION

children.definition: The application of business methods and technical principles to the operationÂ of a forest property for purposes of a predetermined objective (e.g. maximizeÂ revenue, conservation of biotic diversity, etc...).Â
children.label: FOREST MANAGEMENT
FOREST MENSURATION
children.definition: In forestry, the measurement of both standing and harvested timber; ForestÂ measurements.Â

children.label: DEFOLIANTS
children.definition: "An agent that damages trees by destroying leaves or needles. "

children.label: FOREST CONSERVATION
children.definition: Management of the human use of the biosphere so that it may yield the greatest  sustainable benefit to present generations while maintaining its potential to  meet the needs and aspirations of future generations. It includes the  preservation, maintenance, sustainable utilisation, restoration and enhancement of the environment.
Any measure related to or about the production of lumber, composite andÂ reconstituted wood, pulp and paper, chemicals from trees, and otherÂ miscellaneous forest products.Â
children.label: FOREST PRODUCTS/COMMODITIES
FOREST YIELDS
children.definition: Amount of product output recovered from a quantity of raw material input inÂ forest product industries. - Estimate in forest mensuration of the amount ofÂ wood that may be harvested from a particular type of forest stand by species,Â site, stocking, and management regime at various ages.Â
Restocking an area with forest trees.Â
children.label: REFORESTATION
FOREST SCIENCE
children.definition: The branch of Agriculture that deals with forestry, trees, forests, Tree andÂ forest management.Â

The artificial augmentation of the amount of water available to crops/plants,Â either by spraying water directly on to the plants or making it available toÂ their root systems through a series of surface channels or ditches.Â
children.label: IRRIGATION

children.definition: Any measure related to gene mapping, plant /crop species breeding for hybrid orÂ higher value species, breeding for increased production, disease resistance,Â pest resistance, or related genetic measures.Â
children.label: PLANT BREEDING AND GENETICS
RECLAMATION/REVEGETATION/RESTORATION
children.definition: Reclamation, as used here refers, to putting a natural resource to a new orÂ altered use.  Restoration is the return of an ecosystem to a closeÂ approximation of its condition prior to disturbance. Revegetation is theÂ planting of vegetation in an area where vegetation has been removed. Â

The quantity of plant materials resulting from cultivation or growth. IncludesÂ all comercial crops, as well as plant biomass yields (i.e. amount of grassÂ produced per unit land in natural agroecosystems (e.g. rangeland)).  Does notÂ include PRODUCT yield (e.g. bushels of wheat vs. lbs. flour).Â
children.label: CROP/PLANT YIELDS

children.definition: Any method of crop/plant management and/or strategy of production, including,Â but not limited to: no-till, residue management, organic, rotations,Â rest-rotation grazing, etc....Â
children.label: CROPPING SYSTEMS
PLANT DISEASES/DISORDERS/PESTS
children.definition: Measurements related to any deviation from a normal state of health in plantsÂ which temporarily or permanently impairs vital functions.  It may be caused byÂ insect pests, viruses, pathogenic bacteria, parasites, poor nutrition,Â congenital or inherent deficiencies, unfavorable environment, or anyÂ combonation of these, and related pests.Â

children.label: WEEDS, NOXIOUS PLANTS OR INVASIVE PLANTS
children.definition: Measurements related to 1) A plant growing out of place 2) more popularly, anÂ herbaceous plant which takes possession of fallow fields or finds its way intoÂ lawns or planted fields, crowding the vegetation there and robbing it ofÂ moisture and nutrients.  3) A plant whose usefulness is not recognized or whichÂ is undesirable because of odor, spines, prickles, or poisonous characteristics.Â 4) Any plant that harbors insects, fungi, or viruses that may spread to nearbyÂ crop plants.Â

children.label: AGRICULTURAL PLANT SCIENCE
children.definition: The branch of Agriculture that focuses on plants(includes agronomy,Â horticulture, etc... but NOT Forestry, which is a seperate term).Â
Related to the study of products of human consumption specifically for purposesÂ of human nourishment and  nutrition.Â
children.label: FOOD SCIENCE

children.definition: Any measure related to the storage of food stuffs, including refrigeration,Â canning, smoking, irradiation, drying, etc... Methods of storage of foodÂ products: effects of storage conditions on food quality; temperature,Â controlled atmosphere, etc. Shelf life.Â
children.label: FOOD STORAGE
FOOD PACKAGING
children.definition: Any measure related to the packaging of food stuffs. Technical aspects ofÂ canning, bottling, hermetic sealing, vacuum packing, wrapping, coating,Â packeting, etc. Â

Any measure related to any substance that is added to food, either directly orÂ indirectly, to improve nutrition, taste, or shelf life.  Examples includeÂ colorants, flavorings, seasonings, emulsifiers, stabilizers, thickeners,Â sweeteners, preservatives, antioxidants, etc.Â
children.label: FOOD ADDITIVES

children.definition: Any measure related to the contamination and toxicology of food stuffs causedÂ by improper handeling, improper storage, improper preparation, etc... FoodÂ safety; Deleterious food microorganisms; Food toxicology and spoilage: defects,Â diseases, adulteration, contamination; Residues from feed additives such asÂ hormones and antibiotics; Public health aspects of foodstuffs: meat inspection,Â food hygiene, food disease control, etc. Â
children.label: FOOD CONTAMINATION AND TOXICOLOGY
FOOD PROCESSING
children.definition: Any measure related to the processing of food stuffs. Basic technologiesÂ applied in the postharvest production of food for man. Planning and developmentÂ of industries for the processing of food products. General descriptions of foodÂ processing industries. Equipment and processing techniques of food and drinkÂ manufacture. Methods of preservation of foodstuffs and processed foods: drying,Â dehydration, irradiation, etc.      Â

Any measure related to the quality of food stuffs.  Constituents andÂ composition of foods and beverages; Food composition tables; Â Nutrients: proteins, amino acids, nitrogen, carbohydrates, lipids, minerals,Â vitamins; nutritive value, caloric value, sensory evaluation; Protein quality:Â protein efficiency ratio, net protein utilization, nitrogen balance index,Â chemical score, microbiological assays, etc. Â
children.label: FOOD QUALITY
PESTICIDES
children.definition: Any measure of or about insecticides, fungicides, or herbicides; may includeÂ non-chemical/manufactured agents, and/or natural defense mechanisms.Â

Any natural or manufactured material added to the soil in order to supply oneÂ or more plant nutrients.  The term is generally applied to inorganic materialsÂ other than lime or gypsum sold in the trade.Â
children.label: FERTILIZERS
AGRICULTURAL CHEMICALS
children.definition: A term used to designate chemical materials used in Agriculture such asÂ herbicides, insecticides, fungicides, and fertilizers. Does NOT include food orÂ feed additives, or animal hormones.Â

children.label: FISHERIES
children.definition: Related to the act, process, or season of taking fish or other sea animals;Â includes marine and non-marine environments, excludes fish farming, hatcheries,Â and other aquaculture.Â

children.label: AQUACULTURE
children.definition: A use of land and water category under Agricultural Production that  includes fish farming, fish hatcheries, and aquaculture in rotation with  cropland.

children.label: AGRICULTURAL AQUATIC SCIENCES
children.definition: Fisheries and Aquaculture
Any tool, including vehicles, used in agriculture which aids a person to makeÂ work and effort more productive and effective.Â
children.label: AGRICULTURAL EQUIPMENT

children.definition: Related to or about any permanent or temporary construction on a farm, ranch, orÂ other agricultural land.  This includes items such as barns, but also waterÂ improvements, fencing, shelters, henhouses, dams, etc...Â
children.label: FARM STRUCTURES

children.definition: The design, construction, and use of agricultural implements and buildings;Â soil and water management; rural use of electricity; and processing ofÂ agricultural products.Â
children.label: AGRICULTURAL ENGINEERING

children.definition: The range of dynamic natural bodies composed of  mineral and organic materialsÂ and living forms in which plants grow.Â
children.label: SOILS

children.definition: The mass of dry soil per unit of bulk volume,  including the air space.Â
children.label: SOIL BULK DENSITY
MACROFAUNA
children.definition: "Macrobiota" is a general term for the larger soil organisms. Macrofauna, in particular, refers to burrowing vertebrate animals, but may include larger insects and earhworms.
The application of the principles of mechanics and hydraulics to engineeringÂ problems dealing with the behavior and nature of soils, sediments, and otherÂ unconsolidated accumulations.Â
children.label: SOIL MECHANICS
CALCIUM
children.definition: Measurment of Clacium in various forms in the soil, such CaCO3

children.label: CARBON
children.definition: Any measurement of Carbon in the soil, in organic or inorganic fractions.

children.label: CATION EXCHANGE CAPACITY
children.definition: The sum of exchangeable bases plus total soil acidity at a specific pH value usually 7.0 or 8.0. When acidity is expressed as salt extractable acidity, the cation exchange capacity (CEC) is called the effective cation exchange capacity(ECEC) because this is considered to be the CEC of the exchanger at the native pH value. It is usually expressed in centimoles of charge per kilogram of exchanger.

children.label: DENITRIFICATION RATE
children.definition: The rate of biochemical reduction of nitrate or nitrite to gaseous nitrogen,Â either as molecular nitrogen or as an oxide of nitrogen.Â

children.label: ELECTRICAL CONDUCTIVITY
children.definition: A measure of ease with which a conduction current can be caused to flow through a soil under the influence of an applied electric field. It is the reciprocr.

children.label: HYDRAULIC CONDUCTIVITY
children.definition: A measure of the readiness with which a liquid, such as water, flows through aÂ solid, such as soil, in response to a given  potential gradient.Â

children.label: MAGNESIUM
children.definition: Measurement of any form of magnesium in the soil; one macronutrient in  the soil.

children.label: MICRONUTRIENTS/TRACE ELEMENTS
children.definition: A plant nutrient usually found in relatively small amounts(<100 mg  kg-1) in plants.  These are usually B, Cl, Cu, Fe, Mn, Mo, Ni, Co, and  Zn.  In environmental applications it is those elements exclusive of the eight  abundant rock-forming elements: oxygen, aluminum, silicon, iron, calcium,  sodium, potassium, and magnesium.
Measure of any form of Nitrogen, a macronutrient, in the soil, such  as biomass nitrogen, ammonium, nitrate, etc...
children.label: NITROGEN

children.definition: Soil constituents consisting of a wide range of  organic (carbonaceous)Â substances, including living organisms, carbonaceous remains of organisms whichÂ once occupied the soil, and organic compounds produced by current and pastÂ metabolism in the soil.Â
children.label: ORGANIC MATTER
PERMAFROST
children.definition: Permanently frozen material underlying the solum.Â

children.label: PHOSPHORUS
children.definition: Measure of any form of Phosphorus (such as Phosphate), a macronutrient, in  the soil.

children.label: POTASSIUM
children.definition: Measure of any form of Potassium (such as K2O), a macronutrient, in the  soil.

children.label: RECLAMATION/REVEGETATION/RESTORATION
children.definition: RESTORATION: The processes by which an area is treated in  an attempt  to restore original conditions.  RECLAIMATION: The process of reconverting  land to other  forms of productive uses.  REVEGETATION: Reestablishment  of vegetation which may take  place naturally or be induced by humans  through seeding or transplanting.

children.label: SOIL SALINITY/SOIL SODICITY
children.definition: The term salinity refers to the presence of the major dissolved inorganicÂ solutes, essentially Na, Mg, Ca, K, Cl, SO4, HCO3, and CO3, in aqueous samples.Â As applied to soils, it refers to the soluble plus readily dissolvable salts inÂ the soil or, more usually, in an aqueous extract of a soil sample.  Salinity isÂ quantified in terms of the total concentration (or, occasionally, the content)Â of such soluble salts.Â
The movement of ions and water into the plant root as a result of metabolicÂ processes by the root or diffusion along a gradient.Â
children.label: SOIL ABSORPTION
SOIL CHEMISTRY
children.definition: The branch of soil science that deals with the chemical constitution,  chemical properties, and chemical reactions of soils.
The taxonomy of a soil, the great order, suborder, and great group of theÂ soil based upon the characteristics and properties.Â
children.label: SOIL CLASSIFICATION

children.definition: The property of a soil that is based upon three components of hue, chromaÂ (intensity or brightness), and value (lightness or darkness).Â
children.label: SOIL COLOR

children.definition: The reduction in bulk volume or thickness of a soil owing to increasing weightÂ of overlying material that is continually being deposited, or to pressures fromÂ earth movements, resulting in a decrease of porosity.Â
children.label: SOIL COMPACTION

children.definition: The combination of properties of soil material that determine its resistance toÂ crushing and its ability to be molded or changed in shape.Â
children.label: SOIL CONSISTENCE
SOIL DEPTH
children.definition: A measure from the surface to the bottom of the soil profile.Â
The quality of a soil that enables it to provide  essential chemical elementsÂ in quantities and proportions for the growth of specified plants.Â
children.label: SOIL FERTILITY

children.definition: The soil atmosphere; the gaseous phase of the soil, being that volume not  occupied by solid or liquid.
children.label: SOIL GAS/AIR

children.definition: The relation between the fluxes of heat into and out of a soil and the  heat stored by the soil.
children.label: SOIL HEAT BUDGET
SOIL HORIZONS/PROFILE
children.definition: The soil profile is the vertical section of the soil, from the surface throughÂ all its horizons, where a horizon is a layer of soil, approximately parallel toÂ the soil surface, differing in properties and characteristics from adjacentÂ layers below and above it.Â

children.label: SOIL IMPEDANCE
children.definition: The resistance of the soil to penetration by water and by roots.Â

children.label: SOIL MOISTURE/WATER CONTENT
children.definition: Soil Water Content: The water lost from soil upon drying to constant  mass at 105 degrees Celcius; expressed either as the mass of water per  unit mass of drysoil or as the volume of water per unit bulk volume of  soil. For GCMD purpose, this also includes all measurements related to  soil water, such as capcity, potential, and pressure, etc...
The negative log of Hydrogen ion concentration
children.label: SOIL PH

children.definition: The degree to which a soil is capable of being	molded or deformed continuouslyÂ and permanently, by relatively moderate pressure, into various shapes.Â
children.label: SOIL PLASTICITY
SOIL POROSITY
children.definition: The volume percentage of the total soil bulk not occupied by solid particles.Â
The capacity of a soil for producing a specified plant or sequence of plantsÂ under a specified system of management; emphasizing the ability to produceÂ crops.Â
children.label: SOIL PRODUCTIVITY

children.definition: The metabolic process whereby electrons are transfered from a reduced compoundÂ (usually organic) to an inorganic acceptor molecule other than oxygen.Â
children.label: SOIL RESPIRATION
SOIL STRUCTURE
children.definition: The combination or arrangement of primary soil	particles into secondary unitsÂ or peds. These secondary units may be, but usually are not, arranged in theÂ profile in such a manner as to give a distinctive characteristic pattern.  TheÂ secondary units are characterized and classified on the basis of size, shape,Â and degree of distinctness into classes, types, and grades, respectively.Â
The degree of hotness or coldness of the soil as  measured on some definiteÂ temperature scale.Â
children.label: SOIL TEMPERATURE

children.definition: The relative proportions of the various soil separates in a soil, as  described by the percent clay, sand, and silt.
children.label: SOIL TEXTURE
SOIL WATER HOLDING CAPACITY
children.definition: The percentage of water remaining in a soil two or three days after its havingÂ been saturated and after free drainage has practically ceased (field moistureÂ capacity).Â
Measure of any form of Sulfur, a macronutrient, in the soil.
children.label: SULFUR
THERMAL CONDUCTIVITY
children.definition: A measure of the ability of a soil to transfer heat (through a unit thickness,Â across a unit area for a unit difference in temperature).Â

The wearing away of the land surface by rain or irrigation water, wind,  ice, or other natural or anthropogenic agents that abrade, detach and remove  geologic parent material or soil from one point on the earth's surface and  deposit it elsewhere, including such processes as gravitational creep and  so-called tillage erosion; The detachment and movement of soil or rock by  water, wind, ice, or gravity.
children.label: SOIL EROSION

children.definition: Those metals which have densities >5.0 Mg m-3. In soils these include the  elements Cd, Co, Cr, Cu, Fe, Hg, Mn, Mo, Ni, Pb, and Zn.
children.label: HEAVY METALS

children.definition: The entry of water into soil. Also, the infiltration flux is the volume of  water entering a specified cross-sectional area of soil per unit time [L t-1].
children.label: SOIL INFILTRATION

children.definition: Microfauna (or simply microbiota) refers to the smallest soil organisms, including bacteria and protozoa.
children.label: MICROFAUNA
MICROFLORA
children.definition: Microflora (or simply microbiota) refers to the smallest soil organisms, including fungi and algae.

children.label: SOIL ROOTING DEPTH
children.definition: he distance in inches that plant roots extend into the soil. Knowing the  average root depth for the plants in each watering zone is important to  determine an efficient watering schedule. Shallow roots require more frequent  watering than deep roots, which can draw water from a larger soil profile.   Average root depths vary with plant type. Trees will have root depths of 24  inches or more. Xeriscape plants will have root depths around 10 inches. Shrubs and perennials will have roots of 8 inches or more. Grass can have deep roots  (greater than 6 inches, depending on region). Annuals and bedding plants have  the shallowest roots at 4-5 inches.
The observed physical cover and natural use of the land including the vegetation and human construction, which covers the earth's surface.
children.label: LAND USE/LAND COVER
LAND RESOURCES
children.definition: Areas containing available sources of wealth, including cultural heritage resources, recreation features, range	developments, or any other feature similarly designated.
The rate of production, especially of food, by the utilization of solar energy by producer organisms.
children.label: LAND PRODUCTIVITY

children.definition: An index that is determined using visible and near-IR channels on AVHRR. Denotes relative chlorophyll content of vegetation during daylight conditions, and is thus used to monitor drought conditions.
children.label: VEGETATION INDEX

children.definition: An index of plant âgreennessâ or photosynthetic activity, and is one of the most commonly used vegetation indices.
children.label: NORMALIZED DIFFERENCE VEGETATION INDEX (NDVI)
LAND USE/LAND COVER CLASSIFICATION
children.definition: Relates to the type of feature present on the surface of the earth. This can include such things as corn fields, lakes, maple trees, and concrete highways.
Categories defining the land in some way, such as by slope, land cover, and type
children.label: LAND USE CLASSES

children.definition: Soil within which the moisture has predominantly changed to ice, the unfrozen portion being in vapor phase.   Ice within the soil bonds (adfreezes) adjacent soil particles and renders frozen ground very hard. Permanently frozen ground is called permafrost. Dry frozen ground is relatively loose and crumbly because of the lack of bonding ice. Frozen ground is sometimes inadvisedly called frost or ground frost.
children.label: FROZEN GROUND

children.definition: Ground that freezes and thaws annually.
children.label: SEASONALLY FROZEN GROUND
PERMAFROST
children.definition: (Also called perennially frozen ground, pergelisol, permanently frozen  ground.) A layer of soil or bedrock at a variable depth beneath the surface of  the earth in which the temperature has been below freezing continuously from a  few to several thousands of years. Permafrost exists where the summer heating fails to descend to the base of the layer of frozen ground. A continuous stratum of permafrost is found where the annual mean temperature is below about 5C (23F).

children.label: ACTIVE LAYER
children.definition: Active layer, also called frost zone or mollisol is that part of the soil  included with the suprapermafrost layer (i.e., existing above permafrost) that  usually freezes in winter and thaws in summer.

Soil formed in either mineral or organic materials having permafrost either  within 1 m below the surface or, if the soil is strongly cryoturbated, with 2 m below the surface, and having a mean annual ground temperature below 0 deg C.
children.label: CRYOSOLS

children.definition: A general term referring to all types of ice contained in freezing and frozen  ground. Ground ice occurs in pores, cavities, voids or other openings in soil  or rock and includes massive ice. It may occur as lenses, wedges, veins,  sheets, seams, irregular masses, or as individual crystals or coatings on  mineral or organic particles. Perennial ground ice can only occur within  permafrost bodies.
children.label: GROUND ICE
PERIGLACIAL PROCESSES
children.definition: Of, or pertaining to, the outer perimeter of a glacier, particularly to the  fringe areas surrounding the great continental glaciers of the geologic ice  ages.  Thus, periglacial weathering is said to have produced certain  characteristic land forms.

children.label: ROCK GLACIERS
children.definition: A mass of rock fragments and finer material, on a slope, that  contains either interstitial ice or an ice core and shows evidence of past or  present movement.

children.label: SOIL TEMPERATURE
children.definition: The temperature measured at a given soil depth, typically at 2, 4, 8, and  sometimes 20 and 40 in.   Many biological processes, including seed germination, plant emergence,  microbial activity, and soil respiration are a function of soil temperature.

children.label: TALIK
children.definition: Talik, also called tabetisol, is a Russian term applied to permanently unfrozen ground in regions of permafrost.

children.label: AEOLIAN PROCESSES
children.definition: The erosion, transport, and deposition of material due to the action of the wind at or near the Earth's surface. Aeolian processes are at their most effective when the vegetation cover is discontinuous or absent.

children.label: VENTIFACTS
children.definition: Rocks  that have been abraded, pitted, etched, grooved, or polished by wind-driven sand or ice crystals. These geomorphic features are most typically found in arid environments where there is little vegetation to interfere with aeolian particle transport, where there are frequently strong winds, and where there is a steady but not overwhelming supply of sand.

children.label: YARDANGS
children.definition: A streamlined hill carved from bedrock or any consolidated or semiconsolidated material by the dual action of wind abrasion, dust and sand, and deflation. Yardangs are elongate features typically three or more times longer than they are wide, and when viewed from above, resemble the hull of a boat. Facing the wind is a steep, blunt face that gradually gets lower and narrower toward the lee end.

children.label: ABRASION
children.definition: Mechanical scraping of a rock surface by friction between rocks and moving particles.

children.label: DEFLATION
children.definition: Processes pertain to the activity of the winds and more specifically, to the winds' ability to shape the surface of the Earth and other planets. Winds may erode, transport, and deposit materials, and are effective agents in regions with sparse vegetation and a large supply of unconsolidated sediments.

children.label: SALTATION
children.definition: A specific type of particle transport by fluids such as wind, or the denser fluid water. It occurs when loose material is removed from a bed and carried by the fluid, before being transported back to the surface.

An aeolian sediment formed by the accumulation of wind-blown silt and lesser and variable amounts of sand and clay that are loosely cemented by calcium carbonate. It is usually homogeneous and highly porous and is traversed by vertical capillaries that permit the sediment to fracture and form vertical bluffs.
children.label: LOESS
MONADNOCK
children.definition: An isolated rock hill, knob, ridge, or small mountain that rises abruptly from a gently sloping or virtually level surrounding plain.

children.label: SEDIMENT TRANSPORT
children.definition: The movement of solid particles (sediment), typically due to a combination of the force of gravity acting on the sediment, and/or the movement of the fluid in which the sediment is entrained. An understanding of sediment transport is typically used in natural systems, where the particles are clastic rocks (sand, gravel, boulders, etc.), mud, or clay; the fluid is air, water, or ice; and the force of gravity acts to move the particles due to the sloping surface on which they are resting.

children.label: SEDIMENTATION
children.definition: The tendency for particles in suspension to settle out of the fluid in which they are entrained, and come to rest against a barrier.

children.label: SEDIMENT CHEMISTRY
children.definition: Refers to the chemical makeup and characteristics of sediments. In chemistry, sedimentation has been used to measure the size of large molecules (macromolecule), where the force of gravity is augmented with centrifugal force in an ultracentrifuge.
The composition of sediment including parent rock lithology, mineral composition, and chemical make-up.
children.label: SEDIMENT COMPOSITION
STRATIGRAPHIC SEQUENCE
children.definition: A chronological succession of sedimentary rocks.
The lowering of a fluvial surface, such as a stream bed or floodplain, through erosional processes.
children.label: DEGRADATION

children.definition: Breaking down of Earth's rocks, soils and minerals through direct contact with the planet's atmosphere. Weathering occurs in situ, or "with no movement", and thus should not be confused with erosion, which involves the movement of rocks and minerals by agents such as water, ice, wind, and gravity.
children.label: WEATHERING

children.definition: The physical interaction of flowing water and the natural channels of rivers and streams. Such processes play an essential and conspicuous role in the denudation of land surfaces and the transport of rock detritus from higher to lower levels.
children.label: FLUVIAL PROCESSES
DOWNCUTTING
children.definition: Erosional downcutting or downward erosion or vertical erosion is a geological process that deepens the channel of a stream or valley by removing material from the stream's bed or the valley's floor.
The lowering of a fluvial surface, such as a stream bed or floodplain, through erosional processes.
children.label: DEGRADATION
SEDIMENTATION
children.definition: The tendency for particles in suspension to settle out of the fluid in which they are entrained, and come to rest against a barrier.

Refers to the chemical makeup and characteristics of sediments. In chemistry, sedimentation has been used to measure the size of large molecules (macromolecule), where the force of gravity is augmented with centrifugal force in an ultracentrifuge.
children.label: SEDIMENT CHEMISTRY
SEDIMENT COMPOSITION
children.definition: Refers to the parent rock lithology, mineral composition, and chemical make-up of sediment.
A chronological succession of sedimentary rocks.
children.label: STRATIGRAPHIC SEQUENCE
SEDIMENT TRANSPORT
children.definition: The movement of solid particles (sediment), typically due to a combination of the force of gravity acting on the sediment, and/or the movement of the fluid in which the sediment is entrained. An understanding of sediment transport is typically used in natural systems, where the particles are clastic rocks (sand, gravel, boulders, etc.), mud, or clay; the fluid is air, water, or ice; and the force of gravity acts to move the particles due to the sloping surface on which they are resting.
Mechanical scraping of a rock surface by friction between rocks and moving particles.
children.label: ABRASION

children.definition: The down slope movement of soil, rock, and other weathered materials because of gravity.
children.label: LANDSLIDES
ENTRAINMENT
children.definition: The process by which surface sediment is incorporated into a fluid flow (such as air, water or even ice ) as part of the operation of erosion.

children.label: SALTATION
children.definition: A specific type of particle transport by fluids such as wind, or the denser fluid water. It occurs when loose material is removed from a bed and carried by the fluid, before being transported back to the surface.

children.label: ATTRITION
children.definition: A form of coastal or river erosion, when the bed load is eroded by itself. As rocks are transported downstream along a riverbed (by a mixture of rolling, sliding and saltating), the regular impacts between them cause them to be broken up into smaller fragments. This process also makes them rounder and smoother. Attrition can also occur in glaciated regions, where it is caused by the movement of ice with embedded boulders over surface sediments.

children.label: SUSPENSION
children.definition: A heterogeneous fluid containing solid particles that are sufficiently large for sedimentation.

children.label: HYDRAULIC ACTION
children.definition: A form of erosion caused by the force of moving water currents rushing into a crack in the rockface.It is strong enough to loosen sediment along the river bed and banks. The water compresses the air in the crack, pushing it right to the back.

children.label: WEATHERING
children.definition: Breaking down of Earth's rocks, soils and minerals through direct contact with the planet's atmosphere. Weathering occurs in situ, or "with no movement", and thus should not be confused with erosion, which involves the movement of rocks and minerals by agents such as water, ice, wind, and gravity.

A glacier is an accumulation of ice, air, water, and rock debris or sediment. It is a large enough quantity of ice to flow with gravity due to its own mass. The ice can be as large as a continent, such as the ice sheet covering Antarctica; or, it can fill a small valley between two mountains, such as a valley glacier. "Glacial landforms/processes" refers to the erosional or depositional processes of glaciers and the landforms (e.g., drumlins, cirques, fjords) that result.
children.label: GLACIAL PROCESSES
ABRASION
children.definition: Mechanical scraping of a rock surface by friction between rocks and moving particles.

The process of removal of material from the surface of an object by vaporization, chipping, or other erosive processes. The term occurs in spaceflight associated with atmospheric reentry, in glaciology, medicine, and passive fire protection.
children.label: ABLATION
DUMPING
children.definition: A deposit of glacial materials.

children.label: ENTRAINMENT
children.definition: The process by which surface sediment is incorporated into a fluid flow (such as air, water or even ice ) as part of the operation of erosion.

children.label: BASAL ICE FREEZING
children.definition: A process made by made by glaciohydraulic supercooling, though some studies show that even where physical conditions allow it to occur, the process may not be responsible for observed sequences of basal ice.

children.label: FREEZE/THAW
children.definition: The process where water seeps into a crack in a rock, as the temperature drops below freezing, the water freezes and expands causing the crack to enlarge. The ice then melts into water again as the temperature rises above freezing. This action is repeated until the rock breaks.

children.label: FIRN FORMATION
children.definition: The formation process of firn, a partially compacted nÃ©vÃ©, which is a type of snow that has been left over from past seasons and has been recrystallized into a substance denser than nÃ©vÃ©. It is ice that is at an intermediate stage between snow and glacial ice.
Less apparent is the ground moraine, also called glacial drift, which often blankets the surface underneath much of the glacier downslope from the equilibrium line.
children.label: GLACIAL DRIFT

children.definition: The growth of a glacier over time
children.label: GLACIAL GROWTH
GLACIAL DISPLACEMENT
children.definition: The displacement of a glacier. The speed of glacial displacement is partly determined by friction. Friction makes the ice at the bottom of the glacier move slower than the upper portion. In alpine glaciers, friction is also generated at the valley's side walls, which slows the edges relative to the center.

Scratches or gouges cut into bedrock by glacial abrasion. Glacial striations are usually multiple, straight, and parallel, representing the movement of the glacier using rock fragments and sand grains, embedded in the base of the glacier, as cutting tools. Large amounts of coarse gravel and boulders carried along underneath the glacier provide the abrasive power to cut trough-like glacial grooves, and finer sediments also in the base of the moving glacier further scour and polish the bedrock surface, forming a glacial pavement.
children.label: GLACIAL STRIATION

children.definition: Erosion resulting from glacial action, whereby the surface material is removed and the rock fragments carried by the glacier abrade, scratch, and polish the bedrock.
children.label: SCOURING
PLUCKING
children.definition: Exploits pre-existing fractures in the bedrock. This plays a key role in opening and creating new fractures but has only provided small segments of loose material. This is then followed by the entrainment of the loosened rock by the ice. During the process of entrainment, loose rock material is frozen onto the base of the glacier and incorporated into the glacial ice.
The tendency for particles in suspension to settle out of the fluid in which they are entrained, and come to rest against a barrier.
children.label: SEDIMENTATION
SEDIMENT TRANSPORT
children.definition: The movement of solid particles (sediment), typically due to a combination of the force of gravity acting on the sediment, and/or the movement of the fluid in which the sediment is entrained. An understanding of sediment transport is typically used in natural systems, where the particles are clastic rocks (sand, gravel, boulders, etc.), mud, or clay; the fluid is air, water, or ice; and the force of gravity acts to move the particles due to the sloping surface on which they are resting.

The motion of a surface (usually, the Earth's surface) as it shifts downward relative to a datum such as sea-level. The opposite of subsidence is uplift, which results in an increase in elevation. Ground subsidence is of concern to geologists, structural engineers and surveyors.
children.label: GLACIER CRUST SUBSIDENCE
CRUST REBOUND
children.definition: Post-glacial rebound (sometimes called continental rebound, glacial isostatic adjustment) is the rise of land masses that were depressed by the huge weight of ice sheets during the last glacial period, through a process known as isostasy. It affects northern Europe (especially Scotland, Fennoscandia and northern Denmark), Siberia, Canada, the Great Lakes of Canada and the United States, parts of Patagonia, and Antarctica.

Breaking down of Earth's rocks, soils and minerals through direct contact with the planet's atmosphere. Weathering occurs in situ, or "with no movement", and thus should not be confused with erosion, which involves the movement of rocks and minerals by agents such as water, ice, wind, and gravity.
children.label: WEATHERING
PERIGLACIAL PROCESSES
children.definition: Describes a geomorphic process related to freezing of water occur. In its original meaning a periglacial area was at the time in question, the area was not buried by glacial ice but was subject to intense freezing cycles and exhibits permafrost weathering and erosion characteristics.

children.label: DEGRADATION
children.definition: Refers to the lowering of a fluvial surface, such as a stream bed or floodplain, through erosional processes.
The process of upwelling of magma, plate movement, subduction of crust, folding, faulting, warping, fracturing, earthquakes, and volcanic activity.
children.label: TECTONIC PROCESSES

children.definition: The formation of mountain ranges by intense upward displacement of the earth's crust, usually associated with folding, thrust faulting, and other compressional processes.
children.label: OROGENIC MOVEMENT
EPEIROGENIC MOVEMENT
children.definition: Refers to upheavals or depressions of land exhibiting long wavelengths  and little folding apart from broad undulations.

Refers to the the gradual uplift following rapid erosional removal of material from a mountain range. The land rises as a result of the removal of the weight. Another example of isostatic uplift is post-glacial rebound following the melting of continental glaciers and ice sheets.
children.label: ISOSTATIC UPLIFT
RIFTING
children.definition: The process in which continental crust is extended and thinned, forming extensional sedimentary basins and/or mafic dyke-swarms. Rifts commence as intracratonic, down-thrown blocks dominated by normal or oblique-extensional (transtensional) faults.
A geological process most often caused by plate tectonics which increases elevation
children.label: TECTONIC UPLIFT
SUBDUCTION
children.definition: The process that takes place at convergent boundaries by which one tectonic plate moves under another tectonic plate, sinking into the Earth's mantle, as the plates converge. A subduction zone is an area on Earth where two tectonic plates move towards one another and subduction occurs.
Landscapes characterized by (or the processes characterizing) the formation andÂ collapse of caves and sinkholes because of carbonation weathering of aÂ limestone bedrock.Â
children.label: KARST PROCESSES
KARST HYDROLOGY
children.definition: Karst Hydrology refers to the extensive dissolution of rock has led to the development of subterranean channels through which groundwater flows in conduits (enclosed or semi-enclosed channels). These conduits can vary in size from slightly enlarged cracks to tunnels many meters in diameter and many kilometers in length.

The carbon dioxide dissolved in water has even more effect than the oxygen. Oxygen remains as an O2 molecule, whether it's in its gas phase or in solution, but when CO2 is dissolved in water, a small proportion of it reacts chemically with H2O to form carbonic acid, H2CO3. (There's no mystery about that: just add up the six atoms.) In water carbonic acid dissociates rapidly to form a H+ ion and HCO2 (bicarbonate), so it affects the carbonate equilibrium, and pH values change as a result.   Dissolved CO2 lowers the average pH of rainwater to 5.7, even where "acid rain" caused by pollution isn't a factor. The gentle acidity of rainwater is a major source for the weathering of minerals, which the carbonic acid leaches from rocks and which eventually find their way to the ocean.
children.label: DISSOLVED CO2
CAC03
children.definition: A chemical compound that is a common substance found in rocks in all parts of the world, and is the main component of shells of marine organisms, snails, coal balls, pearls, and eggshells. Calcium carbonate is the active ingredient in agricultural lime, and is created when Ca ions in hard water react with carbonate ions creating limescale.

children.label: POROSITY
children.definition: A measure of a rock's ability to hold a fluid. Mathematically, porosity is the open space in a rock divided by the total rock volume (solid +  space or holes). Porosity is normally expressed as a percentage of the total rock which is taken up by pore space.

children.label: WEATHERING
children.definition: Breaking down of Earth's rocks, soils and minerals through direct contact with the planet's atmosphere. Weathering occurs in situ, or "with no movement", and thus should not be confused with erosion, which involves the movement of rocks and minerals by agents such as water, ice, wind, and gravity.
The process where coastal sediments return to the visible portion of the beach following storm erosion.
children.label: ACCRETION

children.definition: Mechanical scraping of a rock surface by friction between rocks and moving particles.
children.label: ABRASION
ATTRITION/WEATHERING
children.definition: A form of coastal or river erosion, when the bed load is eroded by itself. As rocks are transported downstream along a riverbed (by a mixture of rolling, sliding and saltating), the regular impacts between them cause them to be broken up into smaller fragments. This process also makes them rounder and smoother. Attrition can also occur in glaciated regions, where it is caused by the movement of ice with embedded boulders over surface sediments.

children.label: DEPOSITION
children.definition: The act of depositing material, especially by a natural  process; the resultant deposit.

children.label: HYDRAULIC ACTION
children.definition: A form of erosion caused by the force of moving water currents rushing into a crack in the rockface. It is strong enough to loosen sediment along the river bed and banks. The water compresses the air in the crack, pushing it right to the back.
An overflow of an expanse of water that submerges land.
children.label: FLOODING

children.definition: The movement of solid particles (sediment), typically due to a combination of the force of gravity acting on the sediment, and/or the movement of the fluid in which the sediment is entrained. An understanding of sediment transport is typically used in natural systems, where the particles are clastic rocks (sand, gravel, boulders, etc.), mud, or clay; the fluid is air, water, or ice; and the force of gravity acts to move the particles due to the sloping surface on which they are resting.
children.label: SEDIMENT TRANSPORT

children.definition: The tendency for particles in suspension to settle out of the fluid in which they are entrained, and come to rest against a barrier.
children.label: SEDIMENTATION

children.definition: Refers to the chemical makeup and characteristics of sediments. In chemistry, sedimentation has been used to measure the size of large molecules (macromolecule), where the force of gravity is augmented with centrifugal force in an ultracentrifuge.
children.label: SEDIMENT CHEMISTRY
SEDIMENT COMPOSITION
children.definition: The composition of a sediment, which can be measured in terms of parent rock lithology, mineral composition, and chemical make-up.
A chronological succession of sedimentary rocks.
children.label: STRATIGRAPHIC SEQUENCE

children.definition: A specific type of particle transport by fluids such as wind, or the denser fluid water. It occurs when loose material is removed from a bed and carried by the fluid, before being transported back to the surface.
children.label: SALTATION
SEA LEVEL CHANGES
children.definition: Sea levels around the world are rising. Current sea-level rise potentially affects human populations (e.g., those living in coastal regions and on islands) and the natural environment (e.g., marine ecosystems).  Two main factors contributed to observed sea level rise. The first is thermal expansion: as ocean water warms, it expands. The second is from the contribution of land-based ice due to increased melting. The major store of water on land is found in glaciers and ice sheets.

children.label: SUBMERGENCE
children.definition: To cover with water; inundate.
The motion of a surface (usually, the Earth's surface) as it shifts downward relative to a datum such as sea-level
children.label: SUBSIDENCE
SUSPENSION
children.definition: A heterogeneous fluid containing solid particles that are sufficiently large for sedimentation.

children.label: WAVE EROSION
children.definition: The power of the wave is generated by the fetch. Waves erode cliffs by abrasion/corrasion and hydraulic pressure.

children.label: WAVE REFRACTION
children.definition: The change in direction of a wave due to a change in its medium. It is essentially a surface phenomenon.

children.label: WAVE DIFFRACTION
children.definition: Refers to various phenomena which occur when a wave encounters an obstacle. It is described as the apparent bending of waves around small obstacles and the spreading out of waves past small openings.

children.label: WAVE BREAKING
children.definition: A wave whose amplitude reaches a critical level at which some process can suddenly start to occur that causes large amounts of wave energy to be transformed into turbulent kinetic energy. At this point, simple physical models that describe wave dynamics often become invalid, particularly those that assume linear behavior.
The effect by which surface waves entering shallower water increase in wave height (which is about twice the amplitude).
children.label: WAVE SHOALING
COASTAL PROCESSES
children.definition: Coastal processes refers to the action of natural forces (e.g., erosion, deposition, tectonic uplift) on the shoreline, and the nearshore seabed. Some examples of landforms resulting from these processes are wave-cut cliffs, beaches, and wave-cut benches.
A small island. It is especially used to refer to islands found on the River Thames and its tributaries in England.
children.label: AIT

children.definition: An area or ridge of land that separates waters flowing to different rivers, basins, or seas.
children.label: WATERSHED/DRAINAGE BASIN
BAR
children.definition: A linear shoaling landform feature within a body of water. Bars tend to be long and narrow (linear) and develop where a current (or waves) promote deposition of particles, resulting in localized shallowing (shoaling) of the water.

children.label: BAYOU
children.definition: A body of water typically found in flat, low-lying areas, and can refer either to an extremely slow-moving stream or river (often with a poorly defined shoreline), or to a marshy lake or wetland.

children.label: CONFLUENCE
children.definition: The meeting of two or more bodies of water.

Also known as a river cliff, is an erosional feature of streams. Cut banks are found in abundance along mature or meandering streams, they are located on the outside of a stream bend, known as a meander.
children.label: CUTBANK
DELTAS
children.definition: Land built up by deposits of sand and silt at the mouth of some rivers.
A closed drainage basin that retains water and allows no outflow to other bodies of water such as rivers or oceans.
children.label: ENDORHEIC BASIN
FLOOD PLAIN
children.definition: Flat or nearly flat land adjacent to a stream or river that experiences occasional or periodic flooding.

children.label: CANYON
children.definition: A narrow valley with steep sides; usually created by erosion.
Piece of sub-continental land that is surrounded by water. Very small islands such as emergent land features on atolls can be called islets, cays or keys.
children.label: ISLAND
GULLY
children.definition: A landform created by running water eroding sharply into soil, typically on a hillside.

children.label: LACUSTRINE PLAIN
children.definition: Lakes that get filled by incoming sediment. Overtime, the water may drain from the lake, leaving the deposited sediments behind. This can be caused by natural drainage, evaporation or other geophysical processes.
Type of wetland, featuring grasses, rushes, reeds, typhas, sedges, and other herbaceous plants (possibly with low-growing woody plants) in a context of shallow water.
children.label: MARSH
MEANDER
children.definition: A bend in a river, also known as an oxbow loop. This usage derives from the name of the Maeander River in Turkey.
U-shaped body of water formed when a wide meander from the main stem of a river is cut off to create a lake.
children.label: OX-BOW LAKE
PINGO
children.definition: Also called a hydrolaccolith, is a mound of earth-covered ice found in the Arctic and subarctic that can reach up to 70 metres (230 ft) in height and up to 600 m (2,000 ft) in diameter.

children.label: POINT BAR
children.definition: A depositional feature of streams. Point bars are found in abundance in mature or meandering streams.

A body of standing water, either natural or man-made, that is usually smaller than a lake. They may arise naturally in floodplains as part of a river system, or they may be somewhat isolated depressions (examples include vernal pools and prairie potholes).
children.label: POND
RIFFLE
children.definition: A shallow stretch of a river or stream, where the current is above the average stream velocity and where the water forms small rippled waves as a result.

children.label: RIVER
children.definition: A natural watercourse, usually freshwater, flowing towards an ocean, a lake, a sea, or another river.

children.label: SPRING
children.definition: A natural flow of water from the sub-surface to the surface. Usually occurs when the water table intersects the Earth's surface.

children.label: STREAM
children.definition: A long narrow channel of water that flows as a function of gravity and elevation across the Earth's surface. Many streams empty into lakes, seas or oceans.

children.label: STREAM TERRACE
children.definition: Also known as fluvial terraces are elongated terraces that flank the sides of floodplains and fluvial valleys all over the world. They consist of a relatively level strip of land, called a âtread,â separated from either an adjacent floodplain, other fluvial terraces, or uplands by distinctly steeper strips of land called ârisers.â These terraces lie parallel to and above the river channel and its floodplain. Because of the manner in which they form, fluvial terraces are underlain by fluvial sediments of highly variable thickness.

children.label: SWAMP
children.definition: An area of land that is always soaked with water; low, wet land that supports grass and trees.

children.label: VALLEY
children.definition: Low land between hills or mountains.

children.label: V SHAPED VALLEY
children.definition: A valley having a cross-sectional profile in the form of the letter V, commonly produced by stream erosion.
A place where running water makes a sheer drop, usually over a cliff.
children.label: WATERFALL
FLUVIAL LANDFORMS
children.definition: "Fluvial landforms" are features on the Earth's surface produced by the action, i.e. erosion and deposition, of a stream or river and include such landforms as bars, levees, braided and meandering channels, and alluvial fans.  "Fluvial processes" are those processes included in the action of running water in a stream or river

children.label: BARRIER ISLANDS
children.definition: A coastal landform and a type of barrier system, are relatively narrow strips of sand that parallel the mainland coast. They usually occur in chains, consisting of anything from a few islands to more than a dozen.

Geological landform along the shoreline of an ocean, sea or lake. It usually consists of loose particles which are often composed of rock, such as sand, gravel, shingle, pebbles, waves or cobblestones.
children.label: BEACHES

children.definition: One of the three main types of coral reefs recognized by most coral reef scientists. It is distinguished from the other two main types (barrier reefs and atolls) in that has either an entirely shallow backreef zone (lagoon) or none at all.
children.label: FRINGING REEF

children.definition: A long, narrow ridge of coral or rock parallel to and relatively near a coastline, separated from the coastline by a lagoon too deep for coral growth.
children.label: BARRIER REEF
PATCH REEF
children.definition: An isolated, comparatively small reef outcrop, usually within a lagoon or embayment, often circular and surrounded by sand or seagrass. Patch reefs are common.

children.label: APRON REEF
children.definition: A short reef resembling a fringing reef, but more sloped; extending out and downward from a point or peninsular shore.
A linear or semi-circular shaped-outline, larger than a patch reef.
children.label: BANK REEF

children.definition: A long, narrow, somewhat winding reef, usually associated with an atoll lagoon.
children.label: RIBBON REEF
ATOLL REEF
children.definition: A ring-shaped coral reef including a coral rim that encircles a lagoon partially or completely. There may be coral islands/cays on the coral rim.

children.label: TABLE REEF
children.definition: An isolated reef, approaching an atoll type, but without a lagoon.

Underwater structures made from calcium carbonate secreted by corals. Corals are colonies of tiny living animals found in marine waters containing few nutrients. Most coral reefs are built from stony corals, and are formed by polyps that live together in groups. The polyps secrete a hard carbonate exoskeleton which provides support and protection for the body of each polyp.
children.label: CORAL REEFS

children.definition: Geographical features found on coastlines and created by long shore drift. Made out of sand and shingle, and later stabilized by vegetation, cuspate forelands are triangular-shaped accretions and extend seawards.
children.label: CUSPATE FORELANDS
DELTAS
children.definition: Land built up by deposits of sand and silt at the mouth of some rivers.

A hill of sand built by aeolian processes. Dunes occur in different forms and sizes, formed by interaction with the wind. Most kinds of dunes are longer on the windward side where the sand is pushed up the dune and have a shorter "slip face" in the lee of the wind.
children.label: DUNES

children.definition: A hill of sand built by aeolian processes. Dunes occur in different forms and sizes, formed by interaction with the wind. Most kinds of dunes are longer on the windward side where the sand is pushed up the dune and have a shorter "slip face" in the lee of the wind.
children.label: CRESCENTIC (BARCHAN/TRANSVERSE)
LONGITUDINAL/LINEAR DUNE
children.definition: Elongate parallel to the prevailing wind, possibly caused by a larger dune having its smaller sides blown away. Seif dunes are sharp-crested and are common in the Sahara. They range up to 300 m (980 ft) in height and 300 km (190 mi) in length.

children.label: STAR DUNE
children.definition: Radially symmetrical, star dunes are pyramidal sand mounds with slipfaces on three or more arms that radiate from the high center of the mound. They tend to accumulate in areas with multidirectional wind regimes. Star dunes grow upward rather than laterally. They dominate the Grand Erg Oriental of the Sahara. In other deserts, they occur around the margins of the sand seas, particularly near topographic barriers. In the southeast Badain Jaran Desert of China, the star dunes are up to 500 metres tall and may be the tallest dunes on Earth.

children.label: DOME DUNE
children.definition: Oval or circular mounds that generally lack a slipface, dome dunes are rare, and these occur at the far upwind margins of sand seas.

children.label: PARABOLIC DUNE
children.definition: U-shaped mounds of sand with convex noses trailed by elongated arms are parabolic dunes. Sometimes these dunes are called U-shaped, blowout, or hairpin dunes, and they are well known in coastal deserts. Unlike crescent shaped dunes, their crests point upwind. The elongated arms of parabolic dunes follow rather than lead because they have been fixed by vegetation, while the bulk of the sand in the dune migrates forward.

children.label: ESTUARIES
children.definition: Estuaries form a transition zone between river environments and ocean environments and are subject to both marine influences, such as tides, waves, and the influx of saline water; and riverine influences, such as flows of fresh water and sediment. The inflow of both seawater and freshwater provide high levels of nutrients in both the water column and sediment, making estuaries among the most productive natural habitats in the world.

children.label: FJORDS
children.definition: Formed when a glacier cuts a U-shaped valley by abrasion of the surrounding bedrock. Many such valleys were formed during the recent ice age. Glacial melting is accompanied by rebound of Earth's crust as the ice load and eroded sediment is removed (also called isostasy or glacial rebound).

children.label: HEADLANDS/BAYS/CAPE
children.definition: Headlands and bays are often found together on the same stretch of coastline. A bay is surrounded by land on three sides, whereas a headland is surrounded by water on three sides. Headlands are characterized by high, breaking waves, rocky shores, intense erosion, and steep sea cliffs.
A narrow strip of land connecting two larger land areas usually with waterforms on either side.
children.label: ISTHMUS
INLETS
children.definition: A narrow body of water between islands or leading inland from a larger body of water, often leading to an enclosed body of water, such as a sound, bay, lagoon or marsh. In sea coasts an inlet usually refers to the actual connection between a bay and the ocean and is often called an "entrance" or a recession in the shore of a sea, lake or river.

children.label: LAGOONS
children.definition: A body of shallow sea water or brackish water separated from the sea by some form of barrier.

A landform, often referred to as a drowned river valley. Rias are almost always estuaries. Rias form where sea levels rise relative to the land either as a result of eustatic sea level change (where the global sea levels rise), or isostatic sea level change (where the local land sinks).
children.label: RIA
SALT MARSH
children.definition: An environment in the upper coastal intertidal zone between land and salty or brackish water, dominated by dense stands of halophytic  (salt-tolerant) plants such as herbs, grasses, or low shrubs.

children.label: SEA ARCHES
children.definition: Sea arches form by wave erosion of coastal headlands. Sea arches are very temporary landforms, in both geologic and human terms.

A littoral cave, is a type of cave formed primarily by the wave action of the sea. The primary process involved is erosion. Sea caves are found throughout the world, actively forming along present coastlines and as relict sea caves on former coastlines.
children.label: SEA CAVES

children.definition: A significant vertical, or near vertical, rock exposure. Cliffs are formed as erosion landforms due to the processes of erosion and weathering that produce them. Cliffs are common on coasts, in mountainous areas, escarpments and along rivers.
children.label: SEA CLIFFS

children.definition: A somewhat linear landform  within or extending into a body of water, typically composed of sand, silt or small pebbles. A spit or sandspit is a type of shoal.
children.label: SHOALS

children.definition: The fringe of land at the edge of a large body of water, such as an ocean, sea, or lake. In Physical Oceanography a shore is the wider fringe that is geologically modified by the action of the body of water past and present, while the beach is at the edge of the shore, representing the intertidal zone where there is one. is the fringe of land at the edge of a large body of water, such as an ocean, sea, or lake. In Physical Oceanography a shore is the wider fringe that is geologically modified by the action of the body of water past and present, while the beach is at the edge of the shore, representing the intertidal zone where there is one.
children.label: SHORELINES
SOUNDS
children.definition: A wide inlet of the sea or ocean that is parallel to the coastline; it often separates a coastline from a nearby island.

A deposition landform  found off coasts. At one end, spits connect to land, while at the far end they exist in open water. A spit is a type of bar or beach that develops where a re-entrant occurs, such as at cove's headlands, by the process of longshore drift.
children.label: SPITS AND BARS
TOMBOLOS
children.definition: A deposition landform  in which an island is attached to the mainland by a narrow piece of land such as a spit or bar. Once attached, the island is then known as a tied island. Several islands tied together by bars which rise above the water level is called a tombolo cluster.

children.label: WAVE-CUT NOTCH/PLATFORMS
children.definition: The narrow flat area often found at the base of a sea cliff or along the shoreline of a lake, bay, or sea that was created by the action of waves. Wave-cut platforms are often most obvious at low tide when they become visible as huge areas of flat rock.

children.label: COASTAL LANDFORMS
children.definition: Refers to the landforms created by coastal processes including erosion, deposition, and tectonic uplift.

children.label: DUNES
children.definition: A hill of sand built by aeolian processes. Dunes occur in different forms and sizes, formed by interaction with the wind. Most kinds of dunes are longer on the windward side where the sand is pushed up the dune and have a shorter "slip face" in the lee of the wind.

Crescent-shaped mounds are generally wider than they are long. The slipfaces are on the concave sides of the dunes. These dunes form under winds that blow consistently from one direction, and they also are known as barchans, or transverse dunes.
children.label: CRESCENTIC (BARCHAN/TRANSVERSE) DUNE

children.definition: Oval or circular mounds that generally lack a slipface, dome dunes are rare, and these occur at the far upwind margins of sand seas.
children.label: DOME DUNE
PARABOLIC DUNE
children.definition: U-shaped mounds of sand with convex noses trailed by elongated arms are parabolic dunes. Sometimes these dunes are called U-shaped, blowout, or hairpin dunes, and they are well known in coastal deserts. Unlike crescent shaped dunes, their crests point upwind. The elongated arms of parabolic dunes follow rather than lead because they have been fixed by vegetation, while the bulk of the sand in the dune migrates forward.

Radially symmetrical, star dunes are pyramidal sand mounds with slipfaces on three or more arms that radiate from the high center of the mound. They tend to accumulate in areas with multidirectional wind regimes. Star dunes grow upward rather than laterally. They dominate the Grand Erg Oriental of the Sahara. In other deserts, they occur around the margins of the sand seas, particularly near topographic barriers. In the southeast Badain Jaran Desert of China, the star dunes are up to 500 metres tall and may be the tallest dunes on Earth.
children.label: STAR DUNE

children.definition: Elongate parallel to the prevailing wind, possibly caused by a larger dune having its smaller sides blown away. Seif dunes are sharp-crested and are common in the Sahara. They range up to 300 m (980 ft) in height and 300 km (190 mi) in length.
children.label: LONGITUDINAL/LINEAR DUNE
RIPPLES
children.definition: Sedimentary structures (i.e. bedforms of the lower flow regime) and indicate agitation by water (current or waves) or wind.
Features of the Earth's surface produced by either the erosive or constructive action of the wind.
children.label: AEOLIAN LANDFORMS

children.definition: Landforms created by the action of glaciers. Most of glacial landforms today were created by the movement of large ice sheets during the Quaternary glaciations.
children.label: GLACIAL LANDFORMS
ARETES
children.definition: An arete is a thin, almost knife-like, ridge of rock which is typically formed when two glaciers erode parallel U-shaped valleys. The arÃªte is a thin ridge of rock that is left separating the two valleys.
Glacially eroded rock basin found on mountains. Most alpine glaciers originate from a cirque.
children.label: CIRQUES/COMBES
LONGITUDINAL CREVASSES
children.definition: Crevasses that form semi-parallel to flow where a glacier expands laterally.
Crevasses that form from the edge of the glacier, due to the reduction in speed caused by friction of the valley walls.
children.label: MARGINAL CREVASSES

children.definition: Are transverse to flow, as a glacier accelerates where the slope steepens.
children.label: TRANSVERSE CREVASSES

children.definition: A crack in an ice sheet or glacier (compare to crevice, which is in rock). Crevasses often have vertical or near-vertical walls, which can then melt and create seracs, arches, etc.; these walls sometimes expose layers that represent the glacier's stratigraphy.
children.label: CREVASSES

children.definition: An elongated whale-shaped hill formed by glacial ice acting on underlying unconsolidated till or ground moraine.
children.label: DRUMLINS
ESKERS
children.definition: A long winding ridge of stratified sand and gravel, examples of which occur in glaciated and formerly glaciated regions of Europe and North America.

Are formed when a glacier cuts a U-shaped valley by abrasion of the surrounding bedrock. Many such valleys were formed during the recent ice age. Glacial melting is accompanied by rebound of Earth's crust as the ice load and eroded sediment is removed (also called isostasy or glacial rebound).
children.label: FJORDS

children.definition: A sharp peak formed where the ridges separating three or more cirques intersect.
children.label: GLACIAL HORNS

children.definition: Refers to any type of natural cave (most commonly lava tubes or limestone caves) that contains significant amounts of perennial (year-round) ice. At least a portion of the cave must have a temperature below 0 Â°C (32 Â°F) all year round, and water must have traveled into the caveâs cold zone.
children.label: GLACIER/ICE CAVES

children.definition: The terms U-shaped and V-shaped are descriptive terms of geography to characterize the form of valleys. Most valleys belong to one of these two main types or a mixture of them, at least with respect of the cross section of the slopes or hillsides.
children.label: GLACIER/HANGING/U-SHAPED VALLEYS

children.definition: Scratches or gouges cut into bedrock by process of glacial abrasion. Glacial striations usually occur as multiple straight, parallel grooves representing the movement of the sediment-loaded base of the glacier.
children.label: GLACIER STRIATIONS/GROOVES
ICE-DAMMED LAKES
children.definition: In geology, a proglacial lake is a lake formed either by the damming action of a moraine or ice dam during the retreat of a melting glacier, or by meltwater trapped against an ice sheet due to isostatic depression of the crust around the ice.

children.label: KAMES
children.definition: A steep conical hill composed of glaciofluvial sediments. This feature develops when glacial crevasses and depressions in stagnant glacial ice are filled with sand and gravel deposits from sediment loaded meltwater.

children.label: KAME DELTA
children.definition: A glacial landform made by a stream flowing through glacial ice and depositing material upon entering a lake or pond at the end or terminus of the glacier, thus "in front" of it, a proglacial lake.

A steep conical hill composed of glaciofluvial sediments. This feature develops when glacial crevasses and depressions in stagnant glacial ice are filled with sand and gravel deposits from sediment loaded meltwater.
children.label: KETTLE HOLES
MORAINES
children.definition: A glacially formed accumulation of unconsolidated glacial debris (soil and rock) which can occur in currently glaciated and formerly glaciated regions, such as those areas acted upon by a past ice age.

Parallel ridges of debris deposited along the sides of a glacier. The unconsolidated debris can be deposited on top of the glacier by frost shattering of the valley walls and from tributary streams flowing into the valley.
children.label: LATERAL MORAINE
MEDIAL MORAINE
children.definition: A ridge of moraine that runs down the center of a valley floor. It is formed when two glaciers meet and the debris on the edges of the adjacent valley sides join and are carried on top of the enlarged glacier.

Are often observed as a series of transverse ridges running across a valley behind a terminal moraine. They form perpendicular to the lateral moraines that they reside between and are composed of unconsolidated debris deposited by the glacier. They are created during temporary halts in a glacier's retreat.
children.label: RECESSIONAL MORAINE

children.definition: Type of basal moraines that forms a series of ribs perpendicular to the ice flow in an ice sheet. The depressions between the ribs are sometimes filled with water making the Rogen moraines look like tigerstripes on aerial photographs.
children.label: RIBBED/ROGAN MORAINE

children.definition: End moraines, or terminal moraines, are ridges of unconsolidated debris deposited at the snout or end of the glacier. They usually reflect the shape of the glacier's terminus.  Glaciers act much like a conveyor belt, carrying debris from the top of the glacier to the bottom where it deposits it in end moraines.
children.label: TERMINAL MORAINE

children.definition: An exposed, often rocky element of a ridge, mountain, or peak not covered with ice or snow within (or at the edge of) an ice field or glacier. The term is typically used in areas where a permanent ice sheet is present. Nunataks present readily identifiable landmark reference points in glaciers or ice caps and are often named.
children.label: NUNATAKS

children.definition: An outwash fan is a fan-shaped body of sediments deposited by braided streams from a melting glacier. Sediment locked within the ice of the glacier, gets transported by the streams of meltwater, and deposits on the outwash plain, at the terminus of the glacier.
children.label: OUTWASH FANS/PLAINS
ROCHE MOUTONNEES/SHEEPBACK
children.definition: A rock formation created by the passing of a glacier. When a glacier erodes down to bedrock, it can form tear-drop shaped hills that taper in the up-ice direction.

Distinctive geomorphological landforms of angular rock debris frozen in interstitial ice which may extend outward and downslope from talus cones, glaciers or terminal moraines  of glaciers. There are two types of rock glaciers: periglacial glaciers, or talus-derived glaciers, and glacial rock glaciers.
children.label: ROCK GLACIERS
TILL PLAINS
children.definition: An extensive flat plain of glacial till that forms when a sheet of ice becomes detached from the main body of a glacier and melts in place depositing the sediments it carried. A till plain with irregular topography is referred to as a ground moraine.
A Karst landform is a feature created on the Earth's surface by the drainage of water into the ground or by its discharge at springs.
children.label: KARST LANDFORMS

children.definition: A shallow usually funnel-shaped depression of the ground surface formed by solution in limestone regions.
children.label: SINKHOLES (DOLINES)

children.definition: A natural underground space large enough for a human to enter. Some people suggest that the term cave  should only apply to cavities that have some part that does not receive daylight; however, in popular usage, the term includes smaller spaces like sea caves, rock shelters, and grottos.
children.label: CAVES
KARST VALLEY
children.definition: A valley-scale, mid-size, closed depression otherwise meeting the definition of a sinkhole but also enclosing more than one smaller sinkhole and sinking stream.
Limestone towers, from 30 to 200m in height with nearly vertical walls and gently domed or serrated summits.
children.label: COCKPIT/TOWER KARST

children.definition: A large elongate sinkhole resulting from enlargement and coalescence of a linear group of small sinkholes
children.label: UVALA
TECTONIC LANDFORMS
children.definition: "Tectonic landforms" are structural landforms of regional extent. These landforms make up extensive landscapes whose topography is strongly influenced by the structure of underlying rocks that have undergone (or are undergoing) some degree of deformation (and possible associated metamorphism and igneous intrusion). Landscapes developed on orogenic belts, uplifts, domes, basins, and shields can all be thought of as tectonic landforms. "Tectonic processes" are large-scale geologic processes that develop these landforms and include mountain building and crustal rifting.

children.label: CALDRA
children.definition: A large circular depression in a volcano.

children.label: CINDER CONE
children.definition: A steep conical hill of tephra (volcanic debris) that accumulates around and downwind from a volcanic vent.
A planar fracture or discontinuity in a volume of rock, across which there has been significant displacement along the fractures as a result of earth movement.
children.label: FAULTS
GRABEN
children.definition: A depressed block of land bordered by parallel faults.

children.label: HORST
children.definition: A raised fault block bounded by normal faults or graben.
