A geological fold occurs when one or a stack of originally flat and planar surfaces, such as sedimentary strata, are bent or curved as a result of permanent deformation.
children.label: FOLDS

children.definition: A cone shaped mountain formed out of rock or ash thrown up from inside the earth, frequently with an opening or depression at the top.
children.label: VOLCANO
TUYA
children.definition: A type of distinctive, flat-topped, steep-sided volcano formed when lava  erupts through a thick glacier or ice sheet. They are somewhat rare worldwide, being confined to regions which were formerly covered by continental ice sheets and also had active volcanism during the same time period.

children.label: LAVA PLAIN
children.definition: Also called a lava field or lava bed, is a large expanse of nearly flat-lying lava flows. Such features are generally composed of highly-fluid basalt lava, and can extend for tens or even hundreds of miles across the underlying terrain.

children.label: MAAR
children.definition: Broad, low-relief volcanic crater that is caused by a phreatomagmatic eruption, an explosion  caused by groundwater coming into contact with hot lava or magma. A maar characteristically fills with water to form a relatively shallow crater lake.
A spring characterized by intermittent discharge of water ejected turbulently and accompanied by a vapour phase (steam).
children.label: GEYSER

children.definition: An area of highland, usually consisting of relatively flat terrain. A highly eroded plateau is called a dissected plateau. A volcanic plateau is a plateau produced by volcanic activity.
children.label: PLATEAU
MOUNTAINS
children.definition: A large landform that stretches above the surrounding land in a limited area usually in the form of a peak. A mountain is generally steeper than a hill. The adjective montane is used to describe mountainous areas and things associated with them.
A geological feature that features a chain of mountains or hills that are of a continuous elevated crest for some distance. Ridges are usually termed hills or mountains as well, depending on size.
children.label: RIDGE
RIFT VALLEY
children.definition: A linear-shaped lowland between highlands or mountain ranges created by the action of a geologic rift or fault. This action is manifest as crustal extension, a spreading apart of the surface which is subsequently further deepened by the forces of erosion.

children.label: LAVA DOME
children.definition: Roughly circular mound-shaped protrusion resulting from the slow extrusion of viscous lava from a volcano. The geochemistry of lava domes can vary from basalt to rhyolite although most preserved domes tend to have high silica content.

The science dealing with the form and surface configuration of the solid earth. It is primarily an attempt to reveal the complex interrelationships between the origin (and therefore material composition) of surface features on the one hand, and the causes of the surface alteration (erosion, weather, crustal upheaval, etc.) on the other hand.
children.label: GEOMORPHIC LANDFORMS/PROCESSES

children.definition: The natural processes relating to the break down  of soil and rock, and theÂ movement and deposition of the resulting  particles.Â
children.label: EROSION/SEDIMENTATION

children.definition: The general lowering of the surface of the land by erosive processes,Â especially by the removal of material through erosion and transportation byÂ flowing water.Â
children.label: DEGRADATION
ENTRAINMENT
children.definition: The process of picking up and carrying along, as the collecting and movement ofÂ sediment by currents.Â
The wearing away of soil and rock by weathering, mass wasting, and the actionÂ of streams, glaciers, waves, wind, and underground water.Â
children.label: EROSION

children.definition: A general term for a wide variety of processes and landforms involving theÂ downslope movement, under gravity, of masses of soil and rock material.Â
children.label: LANDSLIDES

children.definition: The chemical composition of a sediment.Â
children.label: SEDIMENT CHEMISTRY

children.definition: The minearlogical constituents of a sediment.Â
children.label: SEDIMENT COMPOSITION
SEDIMENT TRANSPORT
children.definition: The movement of sediment by natural agents (such as flowing water, ice, wind,Â or gravity) either as solid particles or in	solution, from one place toÂ another on the earth's surface.Â

children.label: SEDIMENTATION
children.definition: The process of deposition of sediment, especially by mechanical means from aÂ state of suspension in water or air.Â

Unconsolidated particles created by the weathering and erosion of rock, byÂ chemical precipitation from solution in water, or from the secretions ofÂ organisms, and transported by water, wind, or glaciers.Â
children.label: SEDIMENTS
STRATIGRAPHIC SEQUENCE
children.definition: A chronological succession of sedimentary rocks from older to younger above,Â essentially without interruption.Â
Sediment particles supported by the upward currents in eddies of turbulent flowÂ in the surrounding fluid.Â
children.label: SUSPENDED SOLIDS

children.definition: The destructive processes by which rocks are changed on exposure to atmosphericÂ agents at or near the earth's surface, with little or no transport of theÂ loosened or altered material.Â
children.label: WEATHERING

children.definition: The fundamental traits of a specific geographic area; including its biological composition, physical environment and anthropogenic or social patterns.
children.label: LANDSCAPE
LANDSCAPE ECOLOGY
children.definition: The study of the distribution patterns of  communities and ecosystems; the ecological processes that affect those  patterns and changes in pattern and process over time.

children.label: LANDSCAPE MANAGEMENT
children.definition: The identification, assessment, design, and manipulation of features or values of a landscape.

children.label: REFORESTATION
children.definition: The natural or intentional restocking of existing forests and woodlands that have been depleted, usually through deforestation.

children.label: LANDSCAPE PATTERNS
children.definition: A natural space classification of living communities and their environmental conditions.
The physical processes that shape an area of land, including landforms, living elements of flora and fauna, and human activity and the built environment.
children.label: LANDSCAPE PROCESSES

children.definition: Restoration: The processes by which an area is treated in  an attempt to restore original conditions.    Reclamation: The process of reconverting land to other forms of productive uses.    Revegetation: Reestablishment of vegetation which may take  place naturally or be induced by humans through seeding or transplanting.
children.label: RECLAMATION/REVEGETATION/RESTORATION
ALBEDO
children.definition: The ratio of the radiation reflected from an object to the total amount incident upon it, for a particular portion of the spectrum.

children.label: ANISOTROPY
children.definition: The characteristic of a surface for which a physical property, such as reflectivity, varies in value with the direction in or along which the measurement is made.
The ratio of the radiation emitted by a surface to the radiation emitted by a perfect blackbody radiator at the same temperature.
children.label: EMISSIVITY
REFLECTANCE
children.definition: The ratio of reflected radiation to that of the incident radiation on a surface.

children.label: SURFACE RADIATIVE PROPERTIES
children.definition: Any measurement involving the scattering, absorption, or reflection of electromagnetic radiation at the land surface.
The general configuration of the land surface,	including its relief and the position of its natural features.
children.label: TOPOGRAPHY

children.definition: The unevenness of the land surface that results in friction for fluid flow. This can be influenced by the presence of such things as vegetation, water bodies, mountains and other landforms, etc.
children.label: SURFACE ROUGHNESS
TERRAIN ELEVATION
children.definition: The vertical distance from mean sea level to a point or object on the Earth's surface.

A type of map characterized by large-scale detail and quantitative representation of relief, usually using contour lines in modern mapping, but historically using a variety of methods. Traditional definitions require a topographic map to show both natural and man-made features. A topographic map is typically published as a map series, made up of two or more map sheets that combine to form the whole map. A contour line is a combination of two line segments that connect but do not intersect; these represent elevation on a topographic map.
children.label: TOPOGRAPHICAL RELIEF MAPS
CONTOUR MAPS
children.definition: A map that contains contours, which are imaginary lines that connect points of equal value (e.g. elevation of the land surface).

children.label: DIGITAL ELEVATION/TERRAIN MODEL (DEM)
children.definition: A digital model or 3D representation of a terrain's surface created from terrain elevation data.

children.label: TOPOGRAPHIC EFFECTS
children.definition: The topographic effect is indicated on Landsat images of rugged terrain by the visual impression of relief. It is caused by the  variation in spectral radiance due to surface slope and aspect variations. The difference in radiance between a horizontal and sloping surface of the same cover type provides a measure of the topographic effect (Holben and Justice 1981).	Holben and Justice (1979) also measured it and showed that the effect is most extreme in areas of rugged terrain and especially for slopes in the principal plane of the sun and at low solar elevations.

children.label: SKIN TEMPERATURE
children.definition: Refers to the effective radiating temperature of the soil plus canopy surface. It is inferred from satellites in the 8-12 um window region. In climate models, it is the temperature used to determine upward thermal emission. The skin temperature usually shows a larger diurnal variation than the surface air temperature, a factor that needs to be considered when evaluating data/model comparisons.

Refers to how hot the âsurfaceâ of the Earth would feel to the touch in a particular location. From a satelliteâs point of view, the âsurfaceâ is whatever it sees when it looks through the atmosphere to the ground. It could be snow and ice, the grass on a lawn, the roof of a building, or the leaves in the canopy of a forest. Thus, land surface temperature is not the same as the air temperature that is included in the daily weather report.
children.label: LAND SURFACE TEMPERATURE
LAND HEAT CAPACITY
children.definition: The ratio of the heat absorbed (or released) by a system to the corresponding temperature rise (or fall).
Refers to the measurements of any sort related to the amount of heat on the surface of the land.
children.label: SURFACE THERMAL PROPERTIES

children.definition: Dominant Species are recognized by their numerical abundance or biomass and areÂ usually defined separately for each trophic level. Â
children.label: DOMINANT SPECIES

children.definition: Tree Rings, also known as annual rings or growth rings, are a sheath of cellsÂ appearing as one of a series of concentric rings in the cross-section of aÂ woody stem.  Each ring is usually the result of a single yearly growth flushÂ starting in spring and ceasing in late summer. Â
children.label: TREE RINGS

children.definition: Afforestation is the establishment of trees on an area that has lacked forest  cover for a very long time or has never been forested. Reforestation is the  natural or artificial restocking (i.e., planting, seeding) of an area with  forest trees. Also called forest regeneration.
children.label: AFFORESTATION/REFORESTATION

children.definition: Mass of biological material. Usually the total mass of a particular group orÂ category; for example, the biomass of producer organisms.Â
children.label: BIOMASS

children.definition: Canopy characteristics refer to Global Change Master Directory detailedÂ variables under the variable, Canopy Characteristics: canopy height, canopyÂ position, canopy reflectance, canopy resistance, and canopy temperature.Â
children.label: CANOPY CHARACTERISTICS

children.definition: Carbon is one of three important elements that compose plants.	The higherÂ photosynthetic organisms need light, carbon dioxide, and water and these rawÂ materials supply the carbon, oxygen, and hydrogen that are the predominantÂ elements in the organic molecules they manufacture, as well as the energyÂ needed to drive the synthetic reactions. Â
children.label: CARBON

children.definition: Chlorophyll is the green pigment in plants responsible for absorbing the lightÂ energy required for photosynthesis.Â
children.label: CHLOROPHYLL

children.definition: The crown is the horizontal layer of the vegetation where most of the branchesÂ and foliage are found. Â
children.label: CROWN
DECIDUOUS VEGETATION
children.definition: Deciduous vegetation is vegetation that sheds its leaves each year in the fall.Â Maple, oak, black cherry, and beech trees are examples.  The loss of leaves inÂ the fall is believed to be an adaptation that greatly reduces evaporation at aÂ time when the supply of liquid water is limited. Â

children.label: EXOTIC VEGETATION
children.definition: Exotic vegetation are species of vegetation that are introduced to aÂ geographical area where they are not native.Â

children.label: FOREST COMPOSITION/VEGETATION STRUCTURE
children.definition: Forest Composition refers to the tree species which make up the forest.  Vegetation Structure refers to the vertical arrangement of canopy layers and  plants of different life forms, or the horizontal variation in canopy  closure and canopy layers, or both.  Vegetation Structure also includes  standing dead trees (snags) and decaying logs on the ground (coarse woody  debris).

children.label: HERBIVORY
children.definition: Herbivory is an ecological interaction between two species where one speciesÂ eats part or all of a plant species.Â

The importance value is the sum of relative density, relative dominance, andÂ relative frequency for a species in the community. The larger the importanceÂ value, the more dominant a species is in the particular community. Â
children.label: IMPORTANCE VALUE
INDIGENOUS VEGETATION
children.definition: Indigenous Vegetation or native vegetation is applied to a species that occursÂ naturally in an area, and therefore, one that has not been introduced by humansÂ accidentally or intentionally. Â
Pertain to the general characteristics of leaves including leaf structure, arrangement, leaf shape, and leaf margin.
children.label: LEAF CHARACTERISTICS

children.definition: The one sided green leaf area per unit ground area in broadleaf canopies, or as the projected needleleaf area per unit ground area in needle canopies.
children.label: LEAF AREA INDEX (LAI)

children.definition: Litter characteristics refer to Global Change Master Directory detailedÂ variable under the variable, Litter Characteristics: litter chemistry, litterÂ decomposition, litter dry weight, litterfall, and litterfall flux.Â
children.label: LITTER CHARACTERISTICS
MACROPHYTES
children.definition: Macrophytes are macroscopic vegetation. Â

children.label: NITROGEN
children.definition: Nitrogen is a plant nutrient that is a component of proteins, nucleic acids,Â coenzymes, and chlorophylls.  Plants that are deficient in nitrogen haveÂ stunted growth, and light-green older leaves.  Â

children.label: NUTRIENTS
children.definition: Nutrients are elements essential for growth and survival of a given organism. Â Directly or indirectly, nutrients have roles in metabolism that no otherÂ nutrients fulfills. Â
Phosphorus is a plant element which is a component of nucleic acids,Â phospholipids and ATP.	  Plants lacking phosphorus have purplish veins, stuntedÂ growth, fewer seeds, and fruits. Â
children.label: PHOSPHORUS
PHOTOSYNTHETICALLY ACTIVE RADIATION
children.definition: Photosynthetically Active Radiation is the light in the whole wavelength band from 400 nm (deep violet) to 700 nm (dark red) used by plants in photosynthesis.

children.label: FRACTION OF ABSORBED PHOTOSYNTHETICALLY ACTIVE RADIATION (FAPAR)
children.definition: The fraction of the incoming solar radiation in the Photosynthetically Active Radiation spectral region that is absorbed by a photosynthetic organism, typically describing the light absorption across an integrated plant canopy.

Pigments are light-absorbing molecules.  In addition to chlorophyll, otherÂ pigments, principally yellow and orange carotenoids, as well as other forms ofÂ chlorophyll, are also present in green plants.	These molecules absorb lightÂ and then pass the energy to the chlorophyll  a. Accessory pigments, like theÂ carotenoids, enable the plants to use more of the light than is trapped byÂ chlorophyll a alone. Â
children.label: PIGMENTS

children.definition: Plant characteristics refer to Global Change Master Directory detailedÂ variables under the variable, Plant Characteristics:  Plant abovegroundÂ biomass, plant biomass, plant blooms, plant boron concentration, plant calciumÂ concentration, plant carbon concentration, plant copper concentration, plantÂ diameter, plant diseases, plant height, plant iron concentration, plantÂ magnesium concentration, plant manganese concentration, plant nitrogenÂ concentration, plant phosphorus concentration, plant potassium concentration,Â plant production, plant root biomass, plant sink capacity, plant sulfurÂ concentration, plant water potential, and plant zinc concentration.Â
children.label: PLANT CHARACTERISTICS

children.definition: Pollen is, collectively, the mass of microspores or pollen grains producedÂ within the anthers of a flowering plant or the male cones of a gymnosperm. Â
children.label: POLLEN

children.definition: Reclamation, as used here refers, to putting a natural resource to a new orÂ altered use.  Restoration is the return of an ecosystem to a closeÂ approximation of its condition prior to disturbance. Revegetation is theÂ planting of vegetation in an area where vegetation has been removed. Â
children.label: RECLAMATION/REVEGETATION/RESTORATION
REFORESTATION
children.definition: Reforestation is the replanting of trees in forests where the trees have beenÂ cut down.  Reforestation sometimes is undertaken in an effort to reduceÂ atmospheric carbon dioxide levels by restoring forests, which are carbon sinks. Â
Vegetation Cover is the percent of vegetation in an area. Â
children.label: VEGETATION COVER
VEGETATION INDEX
children.definition: An indicator that describes the greenness - the relative density and health of vegetation - for each picture element, or pixel, in a satellite image.
The one sided green leaf area per unit ground area in broadleaf canopies, or as the projected needleleaf area per unit ground area in needle canopies.
children.label: LEAF AREA INDEX (LAI)

children.definition: An index of plant âgreennessâ or photosynthetic activity, and is one of the most commonly used vegetation indices.
children.label: NORMALIZED DIFFERENCE VEGETATION INDEX (NDVI)

children.definition: Vegetation Species are the enumeration of different species in an area. Â
children.label: VEGETATION SPECIES

children.definition: Vegetation that has persistent leaves and whose crown is never totally bare.
children.label: EVERGREEN VEGETATION

children.definition: The science that treats the periodic biological phenomena with relation to  climate, especially seasonal changes.  Phenological events are stages of plant growth. From a climatological  viewpoint, these phenomena serve as bases for the interpretation of progress in local seasons and the climatic zones, and are considered to integrate the  effects of a number of bioclimatic factors on rate of plant development.  Phenology may be considered a branch of the science of bioclimatics, the  sequence of plant or crop development stages through its life cycle. Growth  stages may be defined by stage of physiological development such as  germination, first true leaf, flowering, maturity, etc., and/or by physical  stage such as planting, emergence, harvest, etc.
children.label: PLANT PHENOLOGY
VEGETATION
children.definition: Vegetation, as used, here are types of plants and vegetation structures.

children.label: SPECIES BIOACCUMULATION
children.definition: The uptake and retention of chemicals by organisms via food or water.Â

children.label: BIOAVAILABILITY
children.definition: The degree and rate at which a substance is absorbed into a living system or isÂ made available at the site of physiological activity.Â
A property whereby substances are injurious to health when ingested or inhaled,Â such as chlorine, ammonia, pesticides, and formaldehyde.Â
children.label: TOXICITY LEVELS
ECOTOXICOLOGY
children.definition: Describes the adverse effects on living organisms that chemicals can have when  released into the natural environment.
A Biogeochemical cycle is the movement of chemical elements from organism toÂ physical environment to organism in more or less circular pathways.Â
children.label: BIOGEOCHEMICAL CYCLES

children.definition: Food-web Dynamics denotes the complex network of interconnected food chains. Â Food chains are innumberable pathways where one organism is eaten by a second,Â which is eaten by a third.Â
children.label: FOOD-WEB DYNAMICS

children.definition: Primary production is production by green plants.Â
children.label: PRIMARY PRODUCTION
NUTRIENT CYCLING
children.definition: Nutrient cycling is the repeated pathway of particular nutrients or elementsÂ from the environment through one or more organisms back to the environment. Â Nutrient cycles include the carbon cycle, the nitrogen cycle, the phosphorusÂ cycle, and so on.Â

children.label: PHOTOSYNTHESIS
children.definition: Photosynthesis is the synthesis of carbohydrates from carbon dioxide and waterÂ by chlorphyll using light as energy with oxygen as a byproduct.Â

children.label: EXCRETION RATES
children.definition: Excretion is any of several processes by which excess water, excess or harmfulÂ solutes, or waste materials leave the body by way of a urinary system orÂ certain glands. Â
The chemical process that occurs in all living cells wherein organic compoundsÂ are broken down to release energy required for life processes.Â
children.label: RESPIRATION RATE
OXYGEN DEMAND
children.definition: Oxygen demand or biochemical oxygen demand is the amount of oxygen that will beÂ absorbed or "demanded" as wastes are being digested or oxidized in bothÂ biological and chemical processes.Â
The ability of some microorganisms to utilize the chemical energy contained inÂ certain inorganic chemicals such as hydrogen sulfide for the production ofÂ organic material.Â
children.label: CHEMOSYNTHESIS
CONSUMPTION RATES
children.definition: Consumption is the process whereby organisms in an ecosystem derive theirÂ energy from feeding on other organisms or their products.Â

children.label: DECOMPOSITION
children.definition: Action resulting in decay or rotting of organic material.Â
Mass of biological material. Usually the total mass of a particular group orÂ category; for example, the biomass of producer organisms.Â
children.label: BIOMASS DYNAMICS

children.definition: Secondary production is production by herbivores, carnivores, or detritusÂ feeders.Â
children.label: SECONDARY PRODUCTION

children.definition: Trophic dynamics are major interactions among organisms which involve feedingÂ relationships.	  The feeding levels are called trophic levels where allÂ producers belong to the first trophic level; all primary consumers (in otherÂ words, all herbivores), whether feeding on living or dead producers, belong toÂ the second trophic level; organisms feeding on these herbivores belong to theÂ third level, and so on.Â
children.label: TROPHIC DYNAMICS

children.definition: Ecosystem functions are the physical, chemical, biological, and man-made processes that contribute to the self-maintenance of an ecosystem.
children.label: ECOSYSTEM FUNCTIONS
SPECIES/POPULATION INTERACTIONS
children.definition: Describes the dynamics of species or populations, and how these populations interact with the environment by fitting evolutionary strategies.

Species which transfer pollen from an anther (the male reproductive organ)   to a stigma (the receptive part of the female reproductive organ), either   of the same flower (self-pollinator) or of a different flower of the same   species (cross-pollinator).
children.label: POLLINATOR SPECIES
USE/FEEDING HABITATS
children.definition: Feeding habitat refers to the many aspects of how living organisms obtain theirÂ food. Â

Selection, or natural selection, is a nonrandom reproduction of genotypes thatÂ results in the survival of those best adapted to their environment andÂ elimination of those less well adapted.  Selection leads to evolutionaryÂ change. Â
children.label: NATURAL SELECTION
POPULATION DYNAMICS
children.definition: Population dynamics is the study of the reasons for changes in population size.Â
An endangered species is a species in imminent danger of extinction throughoutÂ all or a significant portion of its range.Â
children.label: ENDANGERED SPECIES
PARASITISM
children.definition: Parasitism is where two species live in an obligatory association in which theÂ parasite depends metabolically on the host . Â

children.label: MUTATION RATES
children.definition: Mutation is a spontaneous change in the genotype of an organism at the genetic,Â chromosomal, or genomic level. The term mutation often refers to alterations toÂ new allelic forms, and represents new material for evolutionary change.Â
Extinction is the death of all individuals of a particular species.Â
children.label: EXTINCTION RATE

children.definition: Diurnal movements are movements that occur at daily intervals as applied toÂ such daily rhythms as leaf or flower opening and closing or the characteristicÂ rise and fall of temperature associated with the hours of light and darkness.Â
children.label: DIURNAL MOVEMENTS

children.definition: Adaptation is an ecological or evolutionary change in structure or functionÂ that produces better adjustment of an organism to its environment and henceÂ enhances its ability to survive and reproduce. Â
children.label: EVOLUTIONARY ADAPTATION

children.definition: Herbivory is an ecological interaction between two species where one speciesÂ eats part or all of a plant species.Â
children.label: GRAZING DYNAMICS/PLANT HERBIVORY
INDIGENOUS/NATIVE SPECIES
children.definition: Indigenous Species or native species is a term applied to a species that occursÂ naturally in an area, and therefore, one that has not been introduced by humansÂ accidentally or intentionally. Â

children.label: SURVIVAL RATES
children.definition: Survival is the converse of mortality for an organism.	Survival is a result ofÂ a combination of factors that contribute toward successful reproductiveÂ advantage and the ability to resist being killed or eaten by another species. Â

children.label: MUTUALISM
children.definition: Mutualism is an interaction between two species in which both benefit from theÂ association and cannot live separately.Â

children.label: SPECIES COMPETITION
children.definition: Competition is the interaction of two species where they both use the sameÂ limited resource or harm one another while seeking a resource.Â

children.label: SPECIES PREDATION
children.definition: Predation is where one animal eats all or part of a second animal species.Â
Scavenging is the manner of feeding where the animal feeds on dead animal andÂ plant matter. Â
children.label: SCAVENGING

children.definition: Symbiosis is the intimate living together or association of two kinds ofÂ organisms.Â
children.label: SYMBIOSIS
SPECIES LIFE HISTORY
children.definition: Life History of a population are long-term attributes, such as age at firstÂ breeding, which are more likely to change in response to long-term changes inÂ an organism's environment.Â

children.label: MIGRATORY RATES/ROUTES
children.definition: Migration is a persistent movement across different habitats in response toÂ seasonal changes in resource availability and quality. Migratory rates andÂ routes are observed for many migrating species.Â
Post-Breeding is the time after nesting. Â
children.label: POST-BREEDING PERIODS

children.definition: Range Changes with respect to Migration include forays outside the home range,Â usually in search of suitable habitat or mating opportunities.Â
children.label: RANGE CHANGES

children.definition: Bioluminescence is a flashing of light that emanates from an organism whenÂ excited electrons of ATP phosphorylates, luciferins (highly fluorescentÂ substances), return to a lower energy level. An example of bioluminescence areÂ fireflies which give off these flashes of light as the luciferases convertÂ chemical energy to light energy. Â
children.label: BIOLUMINESCENCE
EXOTIC SPECIES
children.definition: Exotic species are those that are introduced to a geographical area where theyÂ are not native.Â

children.label: BIODIVERSITY FUNCTIONS
children.definition: Biodiversity is the variety of life: the different plants, animals and micro-organisms, their genes and the ecosystems of which they are a part.

Dominance is the condition in communities or in vegetational strata in whichÂ one or more species, by means of their number, coverage, or size, haveÂ considerable influence upon or control of the conditions of existence ofÂ associated species.Â
children.label: SPECIES DOMINANCE INDICES

children.definition: Indicator species are defined as species which can provide information on  ecological changes and give early warning signals regarding ecosystem processes in site-specific conditions due to their sensitive reactions to them. They can  also be called sentinel species, indicator organisms, biological indicators  ("bioindicators"), biological markers, or environmental indicators. The latter  three expressions do not necessarily refer to species but also to other  environmental elements which can indicate environmental changes.
children.label: INDICATOR SPECIES
INVASIVE SPECIES
children.definition: Invasive species are alien species whose introduction does or is likely to cause economic or environmental harm or harm to human health.
With reference to populations [of species], the maturation and entry of youngÂ into the adult breeding population.Â
children.label: SPECIES RECRUITMENT

children.definition: The phenomenon of orderly transition from one biotic community to another andÂ is also known as ecological or natural succession.  Natural succession occursÂ because the physical environment may be gradually modified by the growth of theÂ biotic community itself, such that the area becomes more favorable to anotherÂ group of species and less favorable to the present occupants.Â
children.label: PLANT SUCCESSION

children.definition: wuewuer
children.label: GRAZING DYNAMICS / PLANT ECOLOGY

children.definition: A community is a group of populations of plants and animals in a given placeÂ or an ecological unit used in a broad sense to include groups of various sizesÂ and degrees of integration. Community structure can refer to the physicalÂ structure or to the biological structure of a community. The physical structureÂ is what one sees when looking at a community. For example, in a forest, aÂ primary structure is imposed by large trees, and a secondary structure is theÂ understory trees and shrubs. Biological structure involves species compositionÂ and abundance, temporal changes in communities, and relationships betweenÂ species in a community.Â
children.label: COMMUNITY STRUCTURE
COMMUNITY DYNAMICS
children.definition: Assembled species or populations that dynamically occur in space and time.
Ecosystems that depend on the recurrence of fire to maintain the existingÂ balance.Â
children.label: FIRE OCCURRENCE

children.definition: Describes the physical state of the fire and/or its effect. This may include  the time and location, duration, aerial extent, temperature, radiative power,  and emission products of the fire event.
children.label: FIRE DYNAMICS
FIRE MODELS
children.definition: Calculation method that describes a system or process related to fire development, including fire dynamics and the effects of fire.

children.label: FIRE ECOLOGY
children.definition: Branch of ecology that focuses on the origins of wildfire and their relationship to the environment that surrounds it, both living and non-living.

children.label: ECOLOGICAL DYNAMICS
children.definition: Describes coupled dynamics of human-ecological systems
Areas in which vegetation is dominated by trees with their crowns overlapping, generally forming 60 - 100% cover.
children.label: FORESTS

children.definition: Pertaining to subarctic forest consisting of primarily of short conifer trees and characterized by intensely cold winters, short summers, and high annual variation in temperature.
children.label: BOREAL FOREST/TIAGA

children.definition: Pertaining to forests consisting of broadleaf deciduous trees found in mid-latitudes.
children.label: TEMPERATE DECIDUOUS FOREST

children.definition: Pertaining to forests consisting of coniferous-evergreen trees and characterized by well-defined seasons with cold, long snowy winters and warm, humid summers.
children.label: TEMPERATE CONIFEROUS FOREST

children.definition: Pertaining to forests characterized by both coniferous and deciduous tree species.
children.label: TEMPERATE MIXED FOREST
TEMPERATE RAINFOREST
children.definition: Pertaining to forests in temperate latitudes characterized by high annual precipitation over 140 cm and infrequent fire.
Pertaining to forests in tropical latitudes characterized by high annual precipitation consisting of dense vegetation divided into three distinct layers.
children.label: TROPICAL RAINFOREST

children.definition: Areas of marsh grasses and reeds along coasts and estuaries where the ground isÂ covered by high tides but drained at low tide.Â
children.label: ESTUARINE WETLANDS

children.definition: Palustrine Wetlands are areas along rivers that are at times, wet and atÂ others, dry. Â
children.label: PALUSTRINE WETLANDS
MARINE
children.definition: Marine Wetlands are areas that are sometimes covered with water and sometimesÂ dry, being influenced by marine water level and tidal fluctuations. Â
Swamps are wet areas that are normally covered by water all year and subject toÂ drying out during the summer.  The parameter Swamp may be colloquiallyÂ interchanged with the parameter Marshes.Â
children.label: SWAMPS
LACUSTRINE WETLANDS
children.definition: Lacustrine Wetlands are lakes, or former lakes, that are naturally filled withÂ shallow water at certain times and more or less drained at other times. Â

children.label: PEATLANDS
children.definition: Peatlands are areas formed by a brown mass of organic matter in which twigs,Â roots, and other plant parts can still be recognized.  These areas formed dueÂ to lack of enough oxygen to decay vegetation completely on land. Peatlands formÂ in fresh-water swamps, indicated by the plant fossils. Â
Marshes refer to the area that occurs between the open water of a lake and dryÂ land.Â
children.label: MARSHES
RIPARIAN WETLANDS
children.definition: Riparian wetlands are the strip of woods that grow along natural wetlands.Â

children.label: WETLANDS
children.definition: Wetlands is a term for a broad group of wet habitats.  They are transitional lands between terrestrial and aquatic ecosystems where the lands may be permanently or intermittently water covered.

children.label: KARST LANDSCAPE
children.definition: An ecosystem within a landscape defined as Karst topography characterized by  caves, sinkholes, disappraring streams and underground drainage. Karst forms  when groundwater dissolves pockets of limestone, dolomite, or gypsum in rock.

children.label: CHAPARRAL
children.definition: Pertaining to distinct shrubland unique to California.

children.label: MONTANE SHRUBLAND
children.definition: Pertaining to shrubland found at high elevations.

Areas with vegetation dominated by shrubs (generally greater than 0.5 m or 1.5 ft tall, but less than 5 m or 16 ft tall) with individuals or clumps overlapping to not touching (generally forming more  than 25% cover, trees generally less than 25% cover).
children.label: SHRUBLAND/SCRUB
MONTANE HABITATS
children.definition: The zone in mountainous regions where the influence of altitude (vertical relief) results in local climatic regimes that are sufficiently different from those in the adjacent lowlands as to cause a complex vertical climate-vegetation-soil zonation.

children.label: ALPINE/TUNDRA
children.definition: Habitat found in the zone on mountain tops between permanent snow and the cold limits of trees, or in arctic regions, characterized by very low winter temperatures, short cool summers, permafrost below a surface layer subject to summer melt, short growing season, and low precipitation.

children.label: ARCTIC TUNDRA
children.definition: Pertaining to tundra found north of the Arctic Circle.

children.label: ALPINE TUNDRA
children.definition: Pertaining to tundra found above the timberline on high mountains.

children.label: SUBALPINE
children.definition: Pertaining to high upland slopes and especially the zone just below the timberline.

children.label: GRASSLANDS
children.definition: Areas in which vegetation is dominated by perennial grasses and grass-like plants, such as sedges and rushes.

A rolling grassland scattered with shrubs and isolated trees, which can be found between a tropical rainforest and desert biome. Not enough rain falls on a savanna to support forests. Savannas are also known as tropical grasslands
children.label: SAVANNA

children.definition: a biome defined by the World Wildlife Fund. The biome includes high altitude grasslands and shrublands around the world. The term "montane" in the name of the biome refers to "high altitude", rather than the ecological term which denotes the region below treeline.
children.label: MONTANE GRASSLAND
DESERT SCRUB
children.definition: Pertaining to an area between 15 and 35 degrees N & S characterized by less than 300 mm annual rainfall and consisting of vegetation adapted to hot, dry conditions.
A region with a mean annual precipitation of 10 inches or less, and so devoid of vegetation as to be incapable of supporting any considerable population.
children.label: DESERTS

children.definition: Tracts of land smaller than a continent, surrounded by the water of an ocean sea, lake, or stream.
children.label: ISLANDS

children.definition: An open, grassy, essentially treeless plain, especially as developed in tropical or subtropical regions.
children.label: SAVANNAS
CAVE/SUBTERRANEAN
children.definition: Pertaining to natural openings in solid rock with areas of complete darkness.
The dry land environment in which the life needs of a plant or animal are supplied.
children.label: TERRESTRIAL ECOSYSTEMS

children.definition: Land consisting of marshes or swamps; saturated land.
children.label: WETLANDS

children.definition: Pertaining to seasonal depressional wetlands.
children.label: VERNAL POOL

children.definition: Phytoplankton is the plant portion of the plankton, the plant community inÂ marine and freshwater situations, that floats free in the water and containsÂ many species of algae and diatoms.Â
children.label: PHYTOPLANKTON

children.definition: Zooplankton is the animal portion of the plankton; the animal community inÂ marine and freshwater situations that floats free in the water, independent ofÂ the shore and the bottom, moving passively with the currents.Â
children.label: ZOOPLANKTON

children.definition: Plankton refers to any community of floating or weakly swimming organism;mostly microscopic, living in freshwater and saltwater habitats.
children.label: PLANKTON
AQUATIC ECOSYSTEMS
children.definition: The water environments, such as rivers, and oceans in which the life needs of  a plant or animal are supplied.
The space used by an organism together with the other organisms with which it co-exists and the landscape and climate elements that affect it.
children.label: MARINE ECOSYSTEMS
BENTHIC
children.definition: Pertaining to ocean bottom as the place where an organism lives.
The gently sloping shore of a body of water which is washed by waves or tides;especially the parts covered by sand or pebbles.
children.label: BEACHES

children.definition: Mounds, ridges, or hills of wind-blown sand, either bare or covered with vegetation.
children.label: DUNES

children.definition: Pertaining to coastline consisting of rocky outcrops that are exposed to daily tides.
children.label: ROCKY INTERTIDAL

children.definition: Pertaining to areas of submerged aquatic vegetation or sea grasses below low-tide mark.
children.label: SAV/SEA GRASS BED
MANGROVE SWAMP
children.definition: Pertaining to tropical and subtropical swamps dominated by mangrove trees.
Pertaining to a mud area with less than 5% vegetative cover.
children.label: MUDFLAT
SALT MARSH
children.definition: Pertaining to tidal wetlands areas dominated by salt-tolerant grasses.
Pertaining areas of dense groupings of kelp species in cold and relatively shallow coastal waters.
children.label: KELP FOREST
LAGOON
children.definition: Pertaining to shallow bodies of water partially or completely separated from the open ocean by barriers of sand or coral.

children.label: COASTAL
children.definition: Pertaining to the area of the ocean near the seashore, including coastal embayments.
Habitat where fish and others live at or in the deep water, at the sea floor.
children.label: DEMERSAL

children.definition: The place where animals or plants live in a semi-enclosed coastal embayment where fresh and saltwater mix (such as a river mouth estuary).
children.label: ESTUARY

children.definition: Pertaining to salt marshes where a significant freshwater influx dilutes the seawater to brackish levels of salinity.
children.label: BRACKISH MARSH
MANGROVE SWAMP
children.definition: Pertaining to tropical and subtropical swamps dominated by mangrove trees.
Pertaining to expanses of soft-sediment at or below the tide line with little vegetation.
children.label: MUDFLAT
SAV/SEA GRASS BED
children.definition: Pertaining to areas of submerged aquatic vegetation or sea grasses below low-tide mark.

children.label: NERITIC ZONE
children.definition: Pertaining to open water above the continental shelves.
Pertaining to open water beyond the continental shelves.
children.label: OCEANIC ZONE

children.definition: The waters of the ocean, over the continental shelf and oceanic zones.
children.label: PELAGIC

children.definition: The coral reef habitat is a unique shallow water community of organisms living on limestone rock that was built by some of the reef organisms.
children.label: REEF

children.definition: Pertaining to a reef made up chiefly of corals, coral sands, algal and other deposits, and the solid limestone resulting from their consolidation.
children.label: CORAL REEF
OYSTER REEF
children.definition: Pertaining to a reef formed of shells from successive generations of oysters.
Pertaining to the biogeographic zone of the ocean bottom between the bathyal and hadal zones: from depths of approximately 13,000 to 21,000 feet (4000 to 6500 meters).
children.label: ABYSSAL

children.definition: Pertaining to hot-water vents formed on the ocean floor when seawater circulates through hot volcanic rock.
children.label: HYDROTHERMAL VENT

children.definition: Pertaining to areas of hydrogen sulfide, methane, and other hydrocarbon releases from the ocean floor.
children.label: COLD SEEP
FRESHWATER ECOSYSTEMS
children.definition: Subset of Earth's aquatic ecosystems. They include lakes and ponds, rivers, streams, springs, and wetlands. They can be contrasted with marine ecosystems, which have a larger salt content.
A considerable body of inland water containing large quantities of salt.
children.label: SALINE LAKES

children.definition: Pertaining to lakes formed at high elevation.
children.label: MONTANE LAKE

children.definition: A considerable inland body of standing water.
children.label: LAKE/POND

children.definition: Pertaining to the area of a natural stream of water, where organisms live.
children.label: RIVERS/STREAM

children.definition: Pertaining to the source of a stream.
children.label: HEADWATER STREAM

children.definition: Pertaining to channels with water flowing in them year-round.
children.label: PERENNIAL STREAM/RIVER
INTERMITTENT STREAM
children.definition: Pertaining to channels that experience seasonal water flow and may not have flowing surface water during dry periods.

children.label: EPHEMERAL STREAM
children.definition: Pertaining to streams that only flow after precipitation events.

children.label: RIVER DELTA
children.definition: Pertaining to a low-lying plain that is composed of stream-borne sediments deposited by a river at its mouth.

children.label: CROPLAND
children.definition: Pertaining to areas used for the production of adapted crops for harvest.

Pertaining to land on which the climax or potential plant cover is composed principally of native grasses, grasslike plants, forbs or shrubs suitable for gazing and browsing, and introduced forage species that are managed like rangelands.
children.label: RANGELAND

children.definition: Pertaining to land managed primarily for the production of introduced forage plants for livestock grazing.
children.label: PASTURE

children.definition: Pertaining to an area where trees have been planted, especially for commercial purposes.
children.label: FOREST PLANTATION
AGRICULTURAL LANDS
children.definition: Areas that are used for farming, including ranching, or land that has biophysical attributes that make it suitable for agricultural use.

children.label: URBAN LANDS
children.definition: Areas that have been altered or obstructed by humans, especially by structures relating to cities.
Pertaining to areas of intensive use with much of the land covered by structures
children.label: PARK
CANAL
children.definition: Pertaining to artificial waterways used for navigation, crop irrigation, water supply, or drainage.

children.label: GARDEN
children.definition: Pertaining to a plot of ground where herbs, fruits, flowers, or vegetables are cultivated.
Pertaining to land adjacent to a road.
children.label: ROADSIDE
MINNING/DRILLING SITE
children.definition: Pertaining to areas where vegetative cover and overburden have been removed for resource extraction.

children.label: WIND FARM
children.definition: Pertaining to an area of land with a cluster of wind turbines for driving electrical generators.

children.label: SOLAR FARM
children.definition: Pertaining to an installation or area of land in which a large number of solar panels are set up in order to generate electricity.
Pertaining to artificial impoundments of water used for irrigation, flood control, municipal water supplies, and other human activities.
children.label: WATER IMPOUNDMENT

children.definition: Pertaining to sites of human private industry.
children.label: RESOURCE DEVELOPMENT SITE
ANTHROPOGENIC/HUMAN INFLUENCED ECOSYSTEMS
children.definition: Pertains to terrestrial ecosystems where human activity is significantly and rapidly altering the form and function.  For example, we are changing the chemical composition of the atmosphere, converting natural landscapes to urban areas, and transporting floral and faunal species far beyond their natural boundaries.

children.label: ECOSYSTEMS
children.definition: An ecosystem is a community of living organisms in conjunction with the nonliving components of their environment (things like air, water and mineral soil), interacting as a system. These biotic and abiotic components are regarded as linked together through nutrient cycles and energy flows. As ecosystems are defined by the network of interactions among organisms, and between organisms and their environment, they can be of any size but usually encompass specific, limited spaces. (although some scientists say that the entire planet is an ecosystem.

Measurements related to the signal recorded by the sensor. Phase: A property of a periodic phenomenon, for example a wave, referring to its starting point or advancement (fraction) relative to an arbitrary origin. For example, the angle of a complex number (ie., the waves are out-of-phase). Amplitude: Measure of the strength of a signal, and in particular the strength or "height" of an electromagnetic wave (units of voltage).
children.label: PHASE AND AMPLITUDE

children.definition: External temperature of the instrument, usually a  pyrgeometer.
children.label: DOME TEMPERATURE

children.definition: Definition unavailable.Â
children.label: ULTRAVIOLET SENSOR TEMPERATURE
VIEWING GEOMETRY
children.definition: The properties of the sensor which affect the image geometry, including the sensor scan angle, instantaneous field of view (IFOV), and internal distortions. The sensor scan angle is the angle between the sensor view vector and the downward pointing (to nadir) axis. Data with very large scan angles generally are greatly distorted, and navigation of extremely off-nadir pixels may have large errors. The area detectable on the ground is determined by the IFOV of the sensor, or the angle contained by the minimum area distinguished by the sensor.

children.label: SINK TEMPERATURE
children.definition: Body temperature of the instrument, usually a  pyrgeometer.
Measurement made using a temperature probe (e.g. thermistor) which is the sum of the ambient air temperature plus the heat of friction caused by the high speed air passing over the probe.
children.label: TOTAL TEMPERATURE

children.definition: The sum of the static pressure and the dynamic pressure when these concepts areÂ applicable. (Also called Stagnation Pressure)Â
children.label: TOTAL PRESSURE

children.definition: Properties of the sensor which affect the imagery it acquires.Â
children.label: SENSOR CHARACTERISTICS

children.definition: An acronym for radio detection and ranging, radar uses radio waves Â (microwave portion of the spectrum) to detect the presence of objects and Â determine their range (position).Â
children.label: RADAR

children.definition: The property of illuminated objects to reradiate a portion of the  incident microwave energy.
children.label: RADAR REFLECTIVITY
DOPPLER VELOCITY
children.definition: The radial velocity of a target measured with a Doppler  radar.

children.label: RADAR IMAGERY
children.definition: A mapping of the observed radar reflectivity of a scene, consisting of a  file of digital numbers assigned to spatial	  positions on a grid of  pixels.
Definition currently not available.Â
children.label: RETURN POWER
RADAR BACKSCATTER
children.definition: The (microwave) signal reflected by elements of  an illuminated scene back  in the direction of the radar. It is so named to make clear the difference  between energy scattered in arbitrary  directions, and that which returns  to the radar and thus may be received  and recorded by the sensor.

children.label: SENSOR COUNTS
children.definition: The raw digital values recorded by the sensor.Â

Measure of radar reflectivity, expressed in terms  of the physical size of  a hypothetical, uniformly scattering sphere that would give rise to  the same level of reflection as that observed from the	sample  target.
children.label: RADAR CROSS-SECTION
SIGMA NAUGHT
children.definition: The conventional measure of the strength of radar signals reflected by a distributed scatterer, usually expressed in dB. It is a normalized dimensionless number, comparing the strength observed to that expected from an area of one square meter. Sigma naught is defined with respect to the nominally horizontal plane, and in general has a significant variation with incidence angle, wavelength, and polarization, as well as with properties of the scattering surface itself (see speckle, and statistics).

children.label: SPECTRUM WIDTH
children.definition: Width of the Doppler power spectrum.
Also known as the mean Doppler velocity,  the mean motion along the radial beam.
children.label: MEAN RADIAL VELOCITY

children.definition: The portion of the electromagnetic spectrum lying between the extreme of  the visible wavelengths and the shortest microwaves (approximately 0.70 to  100 micrometers, respectively).
children.label: INFRARED WAVELENGTHS

children.definition: The amount of infrared radiation transferred across a given unit of surface  area in a given unit of time.
children.label: INFRARED FLUX

children.definition: The apparent temperature of the surface assuming a surface emissivity of 1.0. Setting the emissivity to one is equivalent to assuming the target is a blackbody, so the brightness temperature is defined as the temperature a blackbody would be in order to produce the radiance perceived by the sensor. Brightness Temperature is a descriptive measure of radiation in terms of the temperature of a hypothetical blackbody emitting an identical amount of radiation at the same wavelength. The brightness temperature is obtained by applying the inverse of the Planck function to the measured radiation. Depending on the nature of the source of radiation and any subsequent absorption, the brightness temperature may be independent of, or highly dependent on, the wavelength of the radiation. Units: C
children.label: BRIGHTNESS TEMPERATURE

children.definition: A reproduction of an object by imaging the infrared radiation coming from  the object or reflected by the object.
children.label: INFRARED IMAGERY
INFRARED RADIANCE
children.definition: In radiometery, a measure of the intrinsic radiant intensity emitted by  a radiator in a given direction. Radiance is measured in watts per square  meter and steradian.   Units: WÂ·sr^â1Â·m^â2

Reflected infrared In remote sensing, infrared which is solar-generated electromagnetic radiation that has been reflected from an object. Characteristically, reflected infrared radiation has a wavelength between 0.7 Î¼m and 3 Î¼m and is therefore near-infrared.
children.label: REFLECTED INFRARED
SENSOR COUNTS
children.definition: The raw digital values recorded by the sensor.Â

children.label: THERMAL INFRARED
children.definition: Thermal infrared Infrared radiation which has a wavelength between 3.0 Î¼m and 100 Î¼m. At normal environmental temperatures objects emit infrared between these wavelengths; hotter objects, such as fires, emit infrared at wavelengths shorter than thermal infrared. Compare REFLECTED INFRARED.
LIDAR (Light Detection and Ranging) is an optical remote sensing technology that measures properties of scattered light to find range and/or other information of a distant target.
children.label: LIDAR

children.definition: The scattering of radiation in a direction opposite to that of the incident  radiation due to reflection of the transmitted lidar signal back towards the  instrument (from the Radar Backscatter definition).
children.label: LIDAR BACKSCATTER

children.definition: The ratio of cross polarized to co-polarized lidar signal return reflected back in a direction opposite to that of the incident radiation from a lidar  transmission.
children.label: LIDAR DEPOLARIZATION RATIO

children.definition:
A very short electromagnetic wave. The portion of the electromagnetic spectrum lying between the far infrared and the conventional radio frequency portion. While not bounded by definition, it is commonly regarded as extending from 1 mm to 1 m in wavelength (300 GHz to 0.3 GHz frequency).

Passive systems operating at these wavelengths sometimes are called microwave systems. Active systems are called radar, although the literal definition of radar requires a distance measuring capability not always included in active systems.
children.label: MICROWAVE
BRIGHTNESS TEMPERATURE
children.definition: The apparent temperature of the surface assuming a surface emissivity of 1.0. Â Setting the emissivity to one is equivalent to assuming the target is aÂ blackbody, so the brightness temperature is defined as the temperature aÂ blackbody would be in order to produce the radiance perceived by the sensor.Â
Absolute radiometric temperature incident upon the instrument antenna with  no corrections for spurious energy received from sources not intended by  the instrument design.
children.label: ANTENNA TEMPERATURE
MICROWAVE RADIANCE
children.definition: In radiometery, a measure of the intrinsic radiant intensity emitted by aÂ radiator in a given direction. Radiance is measured in watts per square meterÂ and steradian.Â
A reproduction of an object by imaging the microwave radiation coming from  the object or reflected by the object.
children.label: MICROWAVE IMAGERY
SENSOR COUNTS
children.definition: The raw digital values recorded by the sensor.Â

children.label: ULTRAVIOLET RADIANCE
children.definition: In radiometery, a measure of the intrinsic radiant intensity emitted by aÂ radiator in a given direction. Radiance is measured in watts per square meterÂ and steradian.Â
The amount of ultraviolet radiation transferred across a given unit of surface  area in a given unit of time.
children.label: ULTRAVIOLET FLUX
SENSOR COUNTS
children.definition: The raw digital values recorded by the sensor.Â

children.label: ULTRAVIOLET WAVELENGTHS
children.definition: Situated beyond the visible spectrum at its violet end âused of radiation having a wavelength shorter than wavelengths of visible light and longer than those of X-rays

children.label: PLATFORM CHARACTERISTICS
children.definition: Properties of the platform which affect the sensors residing on it, and inÂ turn, the imagery they acquire.Â

children.label: VIEWING GEOMETRY
children.definition: The effects of roll, pitch, and yaw, as well as jitter on the image geometry. Roll will cause the image to take on a wavy appearance, pitch will cause grid cells to contract or expand in the flight direction, and yaw will create a skewed image. Jitter consists of random and unsystematic vibaration which cannot be measured.
Wind velocity in the viewing area of the instrument.
children.label: LINE OF SIGHT VELOCITY

children.definition: Those properties which define the position of a satellite by determining theÂ relationship between its axes and a reference datum  (such as the earthÂ horizon, the sun, or stars).Â
children.label: ATTITUDE CHARACTERISTICS
ORBITAL CHARACTERISTICS
children.definition: Those properties which describe a satellite in its  periodic revolution. TheseÂ consist of the satellite's altitude, orbital  inclination (angle with respectÂ to the equator, thus a polar orbit is  near 90 degrees, while an equatorialÂ orbit is near 0 degrees), orbital period, etc.Â

Airspeed is the speed on an exposed (usually airborne) object relative to the  atmosphere.   In a calm atmosphere, airspeed equals ground speed. Ground speed is the speed  of an airborne object relative to the earth's surface.	It is the magnitude of  the vector sum of the object's velocity with respect to the air and the wind  velocity, or, expressed in a different manner, the algebraic sum of the  aircraft's airspeed and the wind factor.
children.label: AIRSPEED/GROUND SPEED

children.definition:
Consists of various time parameters measured during an aircraft flight, including computer clock time and GPS time:
- syncclock_time = time found at the syncclock (VSI-SYnCCLOCK-32) in seconds from first file name
- syncclock_m_time = time found at the syncclock (VSI-SYnCCLOCK-32) in Matlab dateform format
- system_time = system time in seconds from first file name
- system_m_time = system time in dateform format
- gps_time = time found at the GPS unit in seconds from first file name
- gps_m_time = time found at GPS unit in dateform
- cmos_time = time found at the computer CMOS in seconds from first file name
- cmos_m_time = time found at the computer CMOS in dateform
children.label: DATA SYNCHRONIZATION TIME
FLIGHT DATA LOGS
children.definition: Records events that take place during the aircraft flight.

children.label: VISIBLE WAVELENGTHS
children.definition: The band of the electromagnetic spectrum which can be  perceived by the  naked eye. This band ranges from about .75  Î¼m to .4 Î¼m, being bordered by  the infrared and ultraviolet bands.
The raw digital values recorded by the sensor.Â
children.label: SENSOR COUNTS
VISIBLE FLUX
children.definition: The amount of visible radiation transferred across a given unit of surface  area in a given unit of time.
A reproduction of an object by imaging the visible radiation coming from  the object or reflected by the object.
children.label: VISIBLE IMAGERY
VISIBLE RADIANCE
children.definition: In radiometery, a measure of the intrinsic radiant intensity emitted by aÂ radiator in a given direction. Radiance is measured in watts per square meterÂ and steradian.Â

X-Ray (Or x-radiation, Rntgen ray) is electromagnetic radiation with wavelengths shorter than that of ultraviolet radiation and greater than that of gamma radiation.

Discovered accidentally by Rntgen in 1895. The primary mechanism for the production of x- rays is deceleration of a rapidly moving charge upon interaction with matter (bremsstrahlung). The x-ray spectrum from an x-ray tube consists of this continuous spectrum on which are superimposed narrow bands (characteristic radiation) that are a consequence of transitions between electronic energy levels of atoms. No sharp boundary exists between x- and ultraviolet radiation nor between x- and gamma radiation, although the latter term is usually restricted to radiation resulting from transitions between nuclear energy levels.
children.label: X-RAY
X-RAY FLUX
children.definition: Short electromagnetic waves whose wavelengths range from .00001 ? to 3000  ?.

children.label: RADIO WAVE
children.definition: Radio waves are that portion of the electromagnetic spectrum having  wavelengths longer than about 10 cm.

children.label: RADIO WAVE FLUX
children.definition: An electrical impusle sent through the atmosphere at radio frequency (usuallyÂ between 10 kHz and 300,000 MHz).Â

children.label: GAMMA RAY
children.definition:
Gamma Rays (or gamma radiation) is electromagnetic radiation originating from transitions between energy levels of atomic nuclei.

A nucleus formed as a consequence of beta or alpha emission sometimes exists briefly in an excited energy level and makes a transition to a lower energy level accompanied by emission of a gamma ray photon with energy equal to the difference between the energies of the initial and final levels. Gamma ray energies from radioactive decay lie in the approximate range 10 keV6 MeV. Gamma rays are also emitted in nuclear reactions. The boundary between x-rays and gamma rays is fuzzy, the latter term being most often used for electromagnetic radiation of nuclear origin.

children.label: GAMMA RAY FLUX
children.definition: The portion of the electromagnetic spectrum from approximately 10^-7 to  10^-5 micrometers.  Most often, gamma ray sensors are used to detect  composition (from wavelengths of rays emitted by nuclei) or to measure  soil moisture.

children.label: ABLATION ZONES/ACCUMULATION ZONES
children.definition: Pertaining to the reduction of a glacier due to melting and/or  evaporation.

children.label: GLACIERS
children.definition: A mass of land ice, formed by the further recrystallization of firn, flowing  continuously from higher to lower elevations.

A continuous sheet of land ice that covers a very large area and moves outward  in many directions.   This type of ice mass is so thick as to mask the land surface contours, in  contrast to the smaller and thinner highland ice. The continental glacier of  Greenland is sometimes called the Inland Ice. This term is often used to  describe the great ice masses that characterized the ice ages.
children.label: ICE SHEETS
ICEBERGS
children.definition: A massive piece of ice of greatly varying shape, protruding 5 m or more  above sea- level, which has broken away from a glacier and which may be  afloat or aground. They may be described as tabular, domed, pinnacled,  wedged, drydocked or blocky. Sizes of icebergs are classed as small,  medium, large and very large.
Rounded, well-bonded snow that is older han one year (from NSIDC glossary). A  permeable aggregate of small ice grains with densities greater than 0.55 up to  0.82 where begins glacial ice.
children.label: FIRN

children.definition: In general, facies are the set of all characteristics of a sedimetary rock that indicates its particular environment of deposition and which distinguish it from other facies in the same rock. Glacial facies refer to the characteristic nature of glacial ice and/or the processes by which the ice formed and processes by which  rock debris from the bed is entrained into the ice.
children.label: GLACIER FACIES

children.definition: Mass balance describes the net gain or loss of snow and ice through a given  year. It is usually expressed in terms of water gain or loss.
children.label: GLACIER MASS BALANCE/ICE SHEET MASS BALANCE
GLACIER THICKNESS/ICE SHEET THICKNESS
children.definition: The difference in height between two levels in the glacier or ice sheet.

children.label: GLACIER TOPOGRAPHY/ICE SHEET TOPOGRAPHY
children.definition: Surface relief of the land. Topography usually is measured in meters above sea  level. The topography can be very different from one location to another.  Topography can be flat, or mountainous, or hilly.

children.label: GLACIER ELEVATION/ICE SHEET ELEVATION
children.definition: Pertaining to the measured height of large thick, glaciers, with an area of  at least 50,000 sq. km, covering a continuous stretch of land and growing  in all directions.

children.label: GLACIER MOTION/ICE SHEET MOTION
children.definition: The rate of flow of the glacier/ice sheet over a period of time.

children.label: GLACIERS/ICE SHEETS
children.definition: Glaciers are masses of land ice, formed by the further recrystallization of  firn, flowing continuously from higher to lower elevations. Ice sheets are a  continuous sheet of land ice that covers a very large area and moves outward in many directions. This type of ice mass is so thick as to mask the land surface  contours, in contrast to the smaller and thinner highland ice. The continental  glacier of Greenland is sometimes called the Inland Ice. This term is often  used to describe the great ice masses that characterized the ice ages.

children.label: SEA ICE
children.definition: Pertaining to the study of frozen seawater over the ocean surface.Â

children.label: LEADS
children.definition: Any fracture or passage-way through ice which is navigable by surface  vessels. Leads and other open water areas within the sea ice pack are also  important in studies of the energy budget in the polar regions and in  local and regional climatology.

Any non-linear shaped opening enclosed by ice. May contain brash ice and/or  be covered with new ice, nilas or young ice; sub-mariners refer to these  as skylights. Polynyas are important in the study of the energy budget of  the polar ocean and local and regional climatology.
children.label: POLYNYAS

children.definition: How salty the water is.   Brine has a very high salinity.   Fresh water has a  salinity of zero.
children.label: SALINITY
SNOW MELT
children.definition: The melting of snow on top of the sea ice. Yearly snow melt on sea ice can be  derived from remote sensing satellites such as Nimbus-7 SMMR and SSM/I on the  DMSP satellites. Snow melt onset is defined as the point in time when microwave brightness temperatures increase sharply due to the presence of liquid water in the snowpack.
Measurements of the temperature of the sea ice and surrounding sea surfaceÂ temperature. These measurements are usually obtained from remote sensingÂ satellites. Â
children.label: ICE TEMPERATURE

children.definition: Ice that has been squeezed together, and in places, forced upwards  and downwards. Some subdivisions of deformed ice are rafted ice, ridged  ice, and hummocked ice.
children.label: ICE DEFORMATION
ICEBERGS
children.definition: A massive piece of ice of greatly varying shape, protruding more than 5m above  sea-level, which has broken away from a glacier, and which may be afloat or  aground. Icebergs may be described as tabular, dome-shaped, sloping, pinnacled, weathered or glacier bergs.

children.label: SEA ICE MOTION
children.definition: Refers to the movement and direction of ice fields or floes. Ice motionÂ processes include: diverging, compacting, and shearing. Â
Pertains to the measurement of the surface height of the sea ice. In  particular, sea ice elevation is measured by the radar altimeter on board the  NASA IceSat satellite.
children.label: SEA ICE ELEVATION
ICE EXTENT
children.definition: The minimum or maximum length of the ice or ice edge into the open water.  Also refers to the extent of the ice pack into the open ocean (which  varies seasonally).

Ice depth or thickness refers to the extent of the ice below the surface of theÂ water. The term is also used in river and lake ice studies. Remote sensingÂ techniques (particularly radar and microwave) have been used to estimate iceÂ thickness as have recently declassified submarine measurements of polar iceÂ thickness. Â
children.label: ICE DEPTH/THICKNESS

children.definition: The measurement of the heat flux or heat loss from open ocean areas within theÂ sea ice pack is important for the study of energy balance in the polar regionsÂ and local and regional climatology. Heat loss through the open water is 100Â times more than through thick ice. Â
children.label: HEAT FLUX
ICE EDGES
children.definition: The ice edge is the demarcation at any given time between open water and  the sea (can also refer to river and lake ice) whether fast or drifting.
Floe refers to any relatively flat piece of ice 20 m or more across. Floes  are subdivided according to horizontal extent: small, medium, big, vast,  giant.
children.label: ICE FLOES

children.definition: Melt of the ice can occur at various stages: puddle, thaw holes, dried  ice, rotten ice, flodded ice, and frozen puddle. Developing sea ice (or  growth) takes on the following stages: New Ice, Youg Ice, First-Year Ice,  Old Ice. Lake Ice development goes through the following stages: New Lake  Ice, Thin Lake Ice, Medium Lake Ice, Thick Lake Ice, and Very Thick Lake  Ice.
children.label: ICE GROWTH/MELT

children.definition: The small-scale variation in the relief of the terrain surface (in this  case the surface of the ice). Remote sensing instruments, such as radar  and microwave sensors, have been able to detect the degree of roughness of  sea, lake, and river ice.
children.label: ICE ROUGHNESS

children.definition: Ice Types is a general term applied to sea, river, and lake ice to  describe attributes such as age, stage of development or growth, or  surface feature.
children.label: ICE TYPES

children.definition: Pack ice refers to high concentrations of sea ice. When concentrations are  60% or less, then the term drift ice is used.
children.label: PACK ICE
REFLECTANCE
children.definition: The reflectance properties of ice bodies. A smooth ice surface will act as  a near-specular reflector. As surface roughness increases, the reflection  becomes diffuse. It is the ratio of the intensity of reflected radiation  to that of the incident radiation on a surface. The suffix (-ance) implies  a property of that particular specimen surface.

children.label: SEA ICE AGE
children.definition: The age of the sea ice is usually a distinction between first-year andÂ multiyear ice. Multiyear sea ice is usually thicker, has more ridges, and canÂ be more of a hinderance to ship travel than first-year ice. Microwave remoteÂ sensing studies have shown that first-year sea ice has a higher emissivity atÂ the 1.55 cm wavelength than multiyear ice, thus making it possible toÂ distinguish between different ice ages from satellites. Ice age can also beÂ qualitatively determined using visible, infrared and radar wavelengths fromÂ satellites. Â
The ratio of the area of the water surface covered by ice as a fraction of theÂ whole area. Sea ice concentration has been monitored by polar orbitingÂ satellites at all wavelengths. Â
children.label: SEA ICE CONCENTRATION
SNOW DEPTH
children.definition: Pertaining to the thickness of snow pack throughout the year.

children.label: ISOTOPES
children.definition: Isotopes are a form of an element with a certain number of neutrons, for  example carbon exists in three isotopes: C12, C13, and C14. Some isotopes are  naturally unstable and spontaneously decay at a fixed rate; other isotopes are  stable.

children.label: FREEBOARD
children.definition: On sea ice, the height of the ice surface above the water.

children.label: PERIGLACIAL PROCESSES
children.definition: Of, or pertaining to, the outer perimeter of a glacier, particularly to the  fringe areas surrounding the great continental glaciers of the geologic ice  ages.  Thus, periglacial weathering is said to have produced certain  characteristic  land forms.

1. (Also called perennially frozen ground, pergelisol, permanently frozen ground.) A layer of soil or bedrock at a variable depth beneath the surface of the earth in which the temperature has been below freezing continuously from a few to several thousands of years. Permafrost exists where the summer heating fails to descend to the base of the layer of frozen ground. A continuous stratum of permafrost is found where the annual mean temperature is below about 5C (23F).

2. As limited in application by P. F. Svetsov, soil that is known to have been frozen for at least a century.

Muller, S. W., 1947: Permafrost, or Permanently Frozen Ground, and Related Engineering Problems,

Hare, F. K., 1951: Compendium of Meteorology, p. 958, and map, p. 956.
children.label: PERMAFROST
ROCK GLACIERS
children.definition: A mass of rock fragments and finer material, on a slope, that  contains either interstitial ice or an ice core and shows evidence of past or  present movement.

Active layer, also called frost zone or mollisol, is part of the soil included  with the suprapermafrost layer (i.e., existing above permafrost) that usually  freezes in winter and thaws in summer.   Its bottom surface is the frost table, beneath which may lie permafrost or  talik. The depth of the active layer varies anywhere from a few inches to  several feet.
children.label: ACTIVE LAYER

children.definition: Soil formed in either mineral or organic materials having permafrost either  within 1 m below the surface or, if the soil is strongly cryoturbated, with 2 m below the surface, and having a mean annual ground temperature below 0 deg C.
children.label: CRYOSOLS

children.definition: The temperature measured at a given soil depth, typically at 2, 4, 8, and  sometimes 20 and 40 in.   Many biological processes, including seed germination, plant emergence,  microbial activity, and soil respiration are a function of soil temperature.
children.label: SOIL TEMPERATURE

children.definition: Ground that freezes and thaws annually.
children.label: SEASONALLY FROZEN GROUND

children.definition:
Talik, also called tabetisol, is a Russian term applied to permanently unfrozen ground in regions of permafrost.

This usually applies to a layer that lies above the permafrost but below the active layer, that is, when the permafrost table is deeper than the depth reached by winter freezing from the surface. Talik is also found within and beneath permafrost; when it occurs beneath the permafrost it is equivalent to subgelisol.
children.label: TALIK
GROUND ICE
children.definition: A general term referring to all types of ice contained in freezing and frozen  ground. Ground ice occurs in pores, cavities, voids or other openings in soil  or rock and includes massive ice. It may occur as lenses, wedges, veins,  sheets, seams, irregular masses, or as individual crystals or coatings on  mineral or organic particles. Perennial ground ice can only occur within  permafrost bodies.

Soil within which the moisture has predominantly changed to ice, the unfrozen  portion being in vapor phase.   Ice within the soil bonds (adfreezes) adjacent soil particles and renders  frozen ground very hard. Permanently frozen ground is called permafrost. Dry  frozen ground is relatively loose and crumbly because of the lack of bonding  ice. Frozen ground is sometimes inadvisedly called frost or ground frost.
children.label: FROZEN GROUND

children.definition: Pertaining to the study of frozen water over the Earth's surface.Â
children.label: SNOW/ICE
PERMAFROST
children.definition: Pertaining to the extent, depth, and other characteristics of frozen subsoilÂ located in arctic/subarctic areasÂ

children.label: SNOW DENSITY
children.definition: Pertaining to the ratio between the volume of snow, and the amount of meltwaterÂ derived from that volume of snow.Â
Pertaining to the measurement, rates, geographical extent of freezing, andÂ melting of snow and ice cover.Â
children.label: FREEZE/THAW

children.definition: Defined as the horizontal displacement of ice over an area.
children.label: ICE MOTION

children.definition: Pertaining to the measured internal temperature of snow/ice pack(s).Â
children.label: SNOW/ICE TEMPERATURE
ICE DEPTH/THICKNESS
children.definition: Pertaining to the measurement and geographic extent of ice thickness onÂ theÂ continental land masses.Â Â

children.label: AVALANCHE
children.definition: Pertaining to the measuerment of a large mass of snow, ice, soil, rock, fallingÂ rapidly from heights far above a lowland area.Â
Pertaining to the characteristics of the layer of ice crystals that formsÂ between the ground and snow cover by sublimation.  It's also referred to asÂ sugar snow.Â
children.label: DEPTH HOAR

children.definition: Pertaining to the rate and extent of melting snow pack(s).Â
children.label: SNOW MELT

children.definition: The order and thickness of layers within the snowpack.
children.label: SNOW STRATIGRAPHY

children.definition: Pertaining to the extent, thickness, longevity, etc. of ice formations thatÂ occur on river systems.Â
children.label: RIVER ICE

children.definition: Pertaining to the extent, depth, and longevity of snow pack.Â
children.label: SNOW COVER

children.definition: Pertaining to the measurement, and analysis to ice formation on inland bodiesÂ of salt or fresh water.Â
children.label: LAKE ICE
ALBEDO
children.definition: Albedo is the ratio of the radiation (radiant energy or luminous energy)Â reflected by a surface to that incident on it. Snow and cloud surfaces have aÂ high albedo, because most of the energy of the visible solar spectrum isÂ reflected. Vegetation and ocean surfaces have low albedo, because they absorb aÂ large fraction of the energy. Clouds are the chief cause of variations in theÂ Earth's albedo.Â

children.label: SNOW FACIES
children.definition: Pertaining to the observable differences that separate/distinguish one snow/iceÂ unit from another.Â
Pertaining to the geographical extent of ice on continental land masses.Â
children.label: ICE EXTENT
ICE VELOCITY
children.definition: Pertaining to the rate at which ice formations (glaciers, ice sheets, etc.) areÂ moving.Â

children.label: WHITEOUT
children.definition: Pertaining to the occurence, extent, and severity of whiteout conditions.Â

children.label: ICE GROWTH/MELT
children.definition: Pertaining to the measurement of ice growth/melting rates, and annual changesÂ in those rates.Â

children.label: SNOW ENERGY BALANCE
