children.definition: Pertaining to the net increase, or decrease in energy due to snow formation,Â melting, evaporation, etc..Â

children.label: SNOW WATER EQUIVALENT
children.definition: Pertaining to the measurement of the amount of water in a given snow pack.Â

children.label: FROST
children.definition: Pertaining to the measurement, geographic extent, and seasonality of frost.Â
Pertaining to the thickness of snow pack throughout the year.Â
children.label: SNOW DEPTH

children.definition: Refers to the chemical composition of snow and ice as determined from snow cores, ice cores, and snow pits.
children.label: SNOW/ICE CHEMISTRY

children.definition: Pertaining to the measurement and analysis of ancient tree rings to  determine environmental conditions during that tree's lifetime and  extrapolate that to climatic conditions. The study of tree rings related to past climate conditions is called dendroclimatology. Variations in tree ring widths from year to year are recognized as an important source of chronological and climatic information. The width of a tree ring is a function of many variables including tree species, age, availability of stored food within the tree, soil nutrients, and climatic factors such as precipitation, sunshine temperature, winds and humidity.
children.label: TREE RINGS
MICROFOSSILS
children.definition: Microfossils are fossils too small to be seen without the aid of a microscope, e.g., a foraminifer or ostracode. It may be the remains of microscopic organisms or a part of a larger orgnaism.

children.label: MACROFOSSILS
children.definition: Macrofossils are fossils large enough to be studied without the aid of a microscope. Macrofossils can indicate the range of plant or animal species in the past.

Radiocarbon refers to radioactive carbon especially carbon-14, but also carbon-10 and carbon-12. Carbon-14 is a heavy radioactive isotope of Carbon having a mass of 14 and a half-life of 5730 +/-40 years. Carbon-14 is useful in dating organic materials during the last 50,000 years.
children.label: RADIOCARBON

children.definition: The isotopic record found in various non-marine records reveal direct information about the past climate. d18O (delta oxygen-18), 16O and 18O are isotopes of oxygen with slight differences in atomic weight. Studies using other isotopes such as Carbon-13, Carbon-14 and Hydrogen are widely used. Isoptopic analysis is especially important in dendroclimatologic and speleothem analyses.
children.label: ISOTOPES

children.definition: Unconsolidated particles created by the weathering and erosion of rock, byÂ chemical precipitation from solution in water, or from the secretions ofÂ organisms, and transported by water, wind, or glaciers.Â
children.label: SEDIMENTS

children.definition: Cave deposits, or speleothems, are mineral formations in caves. While the water flows, the speleothems grow in thin, shiny layers. The amount of growth is an indicator of how much ground water dripped into the cave. Little growth might indicate a drought, just as rapid growth could point to heavy precipitation. When the speleothems stop growing, the outside becomes dirty and eroded in places, giving it a dull appearance. Spelothems can be dated by measuring how much uranium has decayed. Evidence of past climate changes can be inferred from measuring oxygen isotopes in speleothems.
children.label: CAVE DEPOSITS

children.definition: A glaciation (a created composite term meaning Glacial Period, referring to the Period or Era of, as well as the process of High Glacial Activity), often called an ice age, is a geological phenomenon in which massive ice sheets form in the Arctic and Antarctic and advance toward the equator. Conversely, the term interglacial or Interglacial Period, such as the current era, is used to denote the absence of large-scale glaciation on a global scale Â¿ i.e., a non-Ice Age. Interglacials are, in general, shorter than glacial epochs.
children.label: GLACIATION

children.definition: Loess is a deposit of wind-blown silt and dust of Pleistocene age that covers large areas of the continents. It is predominently calcerous consisting of quartz feldspars and micas. Loess is extensive in the North American Great Plains, south-central Europe, Ukraine, central Asia, China, and Argentina. Loess deposits in North America are related to large outwashes from the Laurentide ice sheet and floodplains of large rivers. Loess deposits in Europe are related to the former Alpine and Scandinavianice sheets. Loess in China and central Asia are related to desert conditions.
children.label: LOESS

children.definition: Paleomagnetism is the study of natural remnant magnetization of the Earth's  materials in order to determine the itensity and direction of the Earth's  magnetic field in the geologic past. Variations in the Earth's magnetic field  can be used as a means of stratigraphic correlation. Major reversals of the  Earth's magnetic field are well known and the record of these reversals in  sediments can be used as time markers or chronostratigraphic horizons.
children.label: PALEOMAGNETIC DATA
PALEOSOLS
children.definition: Paleosols are soils that formed in a landscape of the past with distinctive morphological features resulting from a soil-forming environment that no longer exists at the site.

children.label: PALEOVEGETATION
children.definition: Paleovegetation refers to plant species that were living at some time in the past. Indicators of past vegetation include pollen and plant macrofossils. Animal fossils and sedimentary indicators can also be used to reconstruct past vegetation.

children.label: POLLEN
children.definition: Pollen are several-celled microgametophyte of seed plants enclosed in a microspore wall. Fossil pollen consists entirely of the microspore wall. The study of pollen is called palynology or pollen analysis and is an important aspect in reconstructing past climates. Paleoclimatic reconstructions by pollen analysis is possible because (1) pollen grains possess morphological characteristics that are specif to a particular genus or species of plant; (2) they are produced in vast quantities by wind-pollinated plants and are distributed widely from their source; (3) they are extremely resistant to decay; and (4) they reflect the natural vegetation at the time of pollen deposition, which can yield information about ast climatic conditions.

children.label: STRATIGRAPHIC SEQUENCE
children.definition: A set of deposited sedimentary beds that reflects the depositional  environment of those beds and the geologic history of a region.   A stratigraphic sequence is a chronologic succession of sedimentary rocks from older below to younger above without interruption.

Volcanic deposits can consist of tephra, which is airborne pyroclastic material. Extremely explosive volcanic eruptions can produce vast quatntities of tephra over wide areas. Tephra layers can form regional isochronous stratigraphic markers. Tephrachronology can a very important tool in paleoclimatic studies. Volcanic ash horizons can also be used as chronostratigraphic markers.
children.label: VOLCANIC DEPOSITS
BOREHOLES
children.definition: Boreholes are holes drilled deep into the ground (or ocean crust). Profiles of rock temperatures with depth can be related to the history of temperature changes at the surface, which can be converted to estimates of air temperature. Borehhole temperature measurements can provide estimates of local temperature variations over time intervals of a few hundred to over a thousand years.

Non-marine geological information pertinent to paleoclimatology consists of all continental sedimentary records including loess,volcanic deposits, glaciation, spelothems, tree ring, pollen, and other land-based records.
children.label: LAND RECORDS
ISOTOPES
children.definition: The isotopic record found in ice cores reveal direct information about the past climate. d18O (delta oxygen-18), 16O and 18O are isotopes of oxygen with slight differences in atomic weight. Depending on the temperature of evaporation and how far the water has had to travel before it fell as snow, the ratio of 18O to 16O will vary. This ratio, known as d18O, can be measured very accurately using a mass spectrometer. Over short time scales the change in temperature from summer to winter produces a very clear oscillation in the 18O/16O ratio. This oscillation is used to determine the age of the core at different depths, simply by counting the oscillations. Over longer time periods, this ratio indicates the average temperature of the regions between the evaporation site and the coring site. Investigators in Greenland and Antarctica are also analyzing for the ratio of 1H/2H (Hydrogen to deuterium) which will allow even finer detail about source temperature and condensation history to be obtained.

children.label: ELECTRICAL PROPERTIES
children.definition: An important baseline measurement in ice cores is electrical conductivity.  Electrical conductivity measurements (ECM) of the core is a very rapid method to indicate how acidic the core is without the chemical detail of the ion analyses. The value of the measurement is that it can be done for the whole length of the core in high resolution and provide an immediate picture of the core and allow quick detection of interesting areas, such as a volcanic eruptions. Because it is a high resolution, continuous measurement it can be used, along with the other measurements, for time frequency analysis in order to identify cycles in the climate signal.

Volcanic deposits (including volcanic ash, debris, etc.) are found within ice core  records. Volcanoes can produce large quantities of particles and leave a record in the ice. Scanning electron micrographs of the particles from a particularly large dust peak in an ice core may reveal that it is from a known volcano and allow a firm date to be placed on that section of core. For prehistoric times, the dust record is a key tool for reconstructing a history of volcanic activity.
children.label: VOLCANIC DEPOSITS
NITROUS OXIDE
children.definition: Nitrous oxide (N2O) is a greenhouse gas produced from ocean upwelling and soils in tropical and temperate regions. Ice core studies have shown that nitrous oxide increases with temperature in the Northern Hemisphere.

Methane (CH4) is a greenhouse gas and is seen in polar ice cores. From the ice core record, it is known that methane rose rapidly whenever climate changed from glacial to interglacial conditions (during "deglaciation"). Warming of water bathing the seafloor could have led to large-scale release of methane from the melting of methane ice.
children.label: METHANE
CARBON DIOXIDE
children.definition: A minor but very important component of the atmosphere, carbon dioxide traps infrared radiation. Atmospheric CO2 has increased about 25 percent since the early 1800s, with an estimated increase of 10 percent since 1958 (burning fossil fuels is the leading cause of increased CO2, deforestation the second major cause). The increased amounts of CO2 in the atmosphere enhance the greenhouse effect, blocking heat from escaping into space and contributing to the warming of Earth's lower atmosphere. (Earth Observatory)  The most direct method for measuring atmospheric carbon dioxide concentrations for periods before direct sampling is to measure bubbles of air (fluid or gas inclusions) trapped in the Antarctic or Greenland ice caps. The most widely accepted of such studies come from a variety of Antarctic cores and indicate that atmospheric CO2 levels were about 260Â¿280uL/L immediately before industrial emissions began and did not vary much from this level during the preceding 10,000 years.   The longest ice core record comes from Vostok, Antarctica, where ice has been sampled to a depth of 3,600 meters, corresponding to an age of 420,000 years before the present. During this time, the atmospheric carbon dioxide concentration has varied between 180Â¿210 uL/L during ice ages, increasing to 280Â¿300 uL/L during warmer interglacials.(http://www.nationmaster.com/encyclopedia/Carbon-dioxide)

children.label: ICE CORE AIR BUBBLES
children.definition: Trapped gases in ice-core bubbles are highly reliable records of atmospheric composition in reconstructing past climates.

children.label: IONS
children.definition: Pertaining to the measurement of various electrostatically charged  compounds found in ice cores. Ions can be analyzed to infer human, biological, and volcanic activity, as well as ocean water conditions.
Particulate matter in ice cores (continental dust, volcanic ash, diatoms, and pollen)can provide information on past climate conditions and climate variability.
children.label: PARTICULATE MATTER

children.definition: An ice core is a section of ice drilled from a glacier or ice sheet. Ice deposits contain samples of the atmosphere at the time the ice formed; they also record seasonal fluctuations of temperature and dust. That's why ice cores are extremely valuable sources of paleoclimate data on the Earth's climate in the distant past. Researchers drill sections of ice cores hundreds of meters long and then match sections at different depths with particular eras in the Earth's past. These sections can then be analyzed for clues about atmospheric gases and temperatures from hundreds of thousands of years ago.
children.label: ICE CORE RECORDS

children.definition: Reconstruction of past lake levels based on paleoclimate proxy records.
children.label: LAKE LEVEL RECONSTRUCTION
DROUGHT/PRECIPITATION RECONSTRUCTION
children.definition: Reconstruction of past drought and precipitation climatic conditions based on  paleoclimate proxy records (mostly tree ring data).

children.label: STREAMFLOW RECONSTRUCTION
children.definition: Reconstruction of past streamflow conditions based on paleoclimate proxy  records (related to drought/precipitation records).
Reconstruction of past sea surface temperatures (SST) based on paleoclimate  proxy records.
children.label: SEA SURFACE TEMPERATURE RECONSTRUCTION

children.definition: Reconstruction of past atmospheric circulation conditions based on paleoclimate proxy records.
children.label: ATMOSPHERIC CIRCULATION RECONSTRUCTION

children.definition: Reconstruction of past solar forcing and insolation based on paleoclimate proxy records.
children.label: SOLAR FORCING/INSOLATION RECONSTRUCTION

children.definition: Reconstruction of past air temperatures using paleoclimate proxy records.
children.label: AIR TEMPERATURE RECONSTRUCTION

children.definition: Reconstruction of past ocean salinity based on paleoclimate proxy records.
children.label: OCEAN SALINITY RECONSTRUCTION
GROUND WATER RECONSTRUCTION
children.definition: Reconstruction of past ground water conditions based on paleoclimate proxy  records.
Reconstruction of past sea levels based on paleoclimate proxy records.
children.label: SEA LEVEL RECONSTRUCTION
VEGETATION RECONSTRUCTION
children.definition: Reconstruction of past vegetation conditions based on paleoclimate proxy  records.

children.label: PALEOCLIMATE RECONSTRUCTIONS
children.definition: Reconstruction of past climatic conditions using paleoclimate proxy records  (tree rings, ice cores, etc.)

children.label: STRATIGRAPHIC SEQUENCE
children.definition: A set of deposited sedimentary beds that reflects the depositional  environment of those beds and the geologic history of a region.   A stratigraphic sequence is a chronologic succession of sedimentary rocks from  older below to younger above without interruption.

Radiocarbon refers to radioactive carbon especially carbon-14, but also  carbon-10 and carbon-12. Carbon-14 is a heavy radioactive isotope of Carbon  having a mass of 14 and a half-life of 5730 +/-40 years. Carbon-14 is useful in dating organic materials during the last 50,000 years.
children.label: RADIOCARBON
LAKE LEVELS
children.definition: Lake level fluctuations can provide important evidence for paleoclimatic conditions, particulary in arid and semiarid areas. Lake levels are particularly sensitive to changes in hydrologic balance due to climatic fluctuations. Lakes may develop and expand if there is an abundance of precipitation and will recede and even dry up (due to evaporation) during prolonged droughts. Lake sediment cores are often drilled to provide stratigraphic clues to past climate conditions.

children.label: SEDIMENTS
children.definition: Marine sediments are composed of both biogenic and terrigenous materials. Biogenic sediments includes the remains of planktic and benthic organisms, which provide a record of past climate and oceanic circulation. Terrigenous material provides a record of humidity-aridity variations on the continents, intensity and direction of winds, and other modes of sediment transport (rivers, glaciers, erosion, etc.).
Microfossils are fossils too small to be seen without the aid of a microscope,  e.g., a foraminifer or ostracode. It may be the remains of microscopic  organisms or a part of a larger orgnaism.
children.label: MICROFOSSILS
BOREHOLES
children.definition: Boreholes are holes drilled deep into the ground (or ocean crust). Profiles of rock temperatures with depth can be related to the history of temperature changes at the surface, which can be converted to estimates of air temperature. Borehhole temperature measurements can provide estimates of local temperature variations over time intervals of a few hundred to over a thousand years.

children.label: MACROFOSSILS
children.definition: Macrofossils are fossils large enough to be studied without the aid of a  microscope. Macrofossils can indicate the range of plant or animal species in  the past.

Corals are generally members of the order Scleractinia, which have hard calcerous skeletons supporting softer tissues. For paleoclimatic studies, the important coral subgroup is the reef-building, massive corals known as hermatypic corals. Coral growth rates vary and are sensitive to sea surface temperatures (SSTs). Dating coral growth has shown high correspondance between large excursions of oxygen-18 (del18O) and El Nino Southern Oscillation (ENSO) events. Coral growth studies have led to new information about paleo-SSTs, rainfall, river runoff, ocean circulation, and tropical wind systems.
children.label: CORAL DEPOSITS

children.definition: Pertaining to the measurement of isotopic (excluding oxygen) signatures  in ocean/lake sediments to determine past climatic conditions, and apply  those findings to the Earth's climate at the time period in question.  Carbon isotope analysis is very important in extracting paleoclimatic signatures from corals and from benthic forams.
children.label: ISOTOPES
OXYGEN ISOTOPES
children.definition: Isotopes of oxygen (O-18, O-16, O-13) are found in calcium carbonate in sea water. The production of O18 is highly dependent on temperature. The oxygen isotope record in marine sediments varies locally with temperature and globally with variations in continental ice volume. Oxygen isotope analyses have been carried out on deep sea cores from areas of calcareous sedimentation throughout the world and similar variations in O18 are recorded everywhere. The O18 signal is that of ice volume changes on the continents and concomitant changes in the isotopic content of the oceans.

children.label: PALEOMAGNETIC DATA
children.definition: Paleomagnetism is the study of natural remnant magnetization of the Earth's  materials in order to determine the itensity and direction of the Earth's  magnetic field in the geologic past. Variations in the Earth's magnetic field  can be used as a means of stratigraphic correlation. Major reversals of the  Earth's magnetic field are well known and the record of these reversals in  sediments can be used as time markers or chronostratigraphic horizons.

A sedimentary bed or lamina or sequence of laminae (thin layers) deposited in a body of silt or still water within a year's time. Usually refers to glacial varves resulting from seasonally deposited meltwater streams in a glacial lake or other body of still water. Counting the varves have been used to measure glacial deposits.
children.label: VARVE DEPOSITS
OCEAN/LAKE RECORDS
children.definition: Paleoclimatic information can be inferred from biogenic material in ocean sediments, oxygen isotopic analyses of sea water (via deep sea cores), coral growth, inorganic material such as from weathering and erosion, lake levels and glacial varves, and ocean circulation changes as a result of glacial-interglacial cycles.
Invertebrates are animals lacking a backbone, or without bones.
children.label: ANIMALS/INVERTEBRATES

children.definition: The phylum Arthropods possesses an exoskeleton, the arrangement of hardenedÂ plates and tubular sections found in the outer covering or cuticle of the body.Â
children.label: ARTHROPODS
ARACHNIDS
children.definition: Arachnids are arthropods with a body divided into an anterior and posteriorÂ part.  The posterior section contains four pairs of legs. Arachnids are almostÂ entirely terrestrial and mainly free living. Â
A subphylum or superclass of arthropods containing over 35,000 species distributed  worldwide, mainly in freshwater and marine habitats, where they constitute a major component of plankton.
children.label: CRUSTACEANS

children.definition: Insects are a class of Arthropoda, members of which have three pairs of legsÂ and usually two pairs of wings borne on the thorax. Â
children.label: INSECTS

children.definition: Centipedes are in the Class Chilopoda, and are elongate arthropods with bodyÂ divided into head and trunk, the latter bearing ten or more pairs of legs.Â
children.label: CENTIPEDES
MILLIPEDES
children.definition: Millipedes are in the Class Chilopoda, in the Phylum Arthropoda, and areÂ elongate arthropods with body divided into head and trunk, the latter bearingÂ never many more than 200 pairs of legs.Â

children.label: ECHINODERMS
children.definition: The phylum Echinoderms is a wholly marine group whose members include theÂ familiar starfish and sea urchins often found on the shore. Some of theirÂ particular features are their five-sided adult symmetry, their endoskeletonÂ which consists of many small crystals of calcium carbonate and tube feet, whichÂ are outward manifestations of their water vascular system.Â

children.label: MOLLUSKS
children.definition: Mollusks are fundamentally bilaterally symmetrical coelomates with segmentationÂ almost or completely absent; muscular foot, typically ventral; head usuallyÂ with concentrated sense organs; dorsal mantle of tissue folded to form a cavityÂ with usually houses gills; well developed blood vascular system and usually anÂ internal or external calcareous shell.Â

Sponges are multicellular organisms with no discrete tissues and organs butÂ with a skeleton composed of collagen (with or without mineral elements), and aÂ tubular water filtration system driven by specialized uniflagellate cells. Â They have a free living sessile habit and are mainly marine at all depths andÂ latitudes but some occur in freshwater.Â
children.label: SPONGES
SEGMENTED WORMS (ANNELIDS)
children.definition: Segmented Worms are worms that have a repeating series of body units that mayÂ or may not be similar to one another. Â

The name Cnidaria comes from the Greek word "cnidos", which means stinging nettle (i.e. nematocysts). This phylum contains thousands of living species worldwide.  These creatures are radially symmetrical. There are four major groups of cnidarians:  1) Anthozoa, which includes true corals, anemones, and sea pens;  2) Cubozoa, the amazing box jellies with complex eyes and potent toxins;  3) Hydrozoa, the most diverse group with siphonophores, hydroids, fire corals, and many medusae; and  4) Scyphozoa, the true jellyfish.
children.label: CNIDARIANS

children.definition: Anemones, or Sea Anemones, belong to the class Anthozoa, which are  sedentary polypoid forms including sea fans, and hard and soft corals.  Anthozoans are the most advanced members of the Phylum Cnidaria.
children.label: SEA ANEMONES
JELLYFISHES
children.definition: Jellyfish are acoelomate with a body wall divided into two layers and separatedÂ by a jelly-like mesoglea.  They are primarily radially symmetrical with no anusÂ and a mouth usually surrounded by tentacles bearing stinging nematocysts. Â Jellyfish are free swimming.Â

Roundworms are mostly worm-like and unsegmented, with an external cuticle, aÂ pseudocoelom between body wall and gut, an anus and complex nervous system butÂ not circulatory system.  They are mostly free living bottom dwellers in marineÂ and freshwater environments and in the soil.Â
children.label: ROUNDWORMS

children.definition: Flatworms have a dorsoventrally flattened, simple triploblastic body lacking aÂ coelom, anus and blood vascular system.Â
children.label: FLATWORMS/FLUKES/TAPEWORMS

children.definition: Conifers are pollen- and seed-bearing plants of the dominant group ofÂ gymnosperms; mostly evergreen, woody trees and shrubs with needle-like orÂ scale-like leaves. Â
children.label: CONIFERS

children.definition: Macroalgae, or seaweeds, are the dominant marine plants inhabiting temperateÂ coasts. Macroalgae contain chlorophyll and an assortment of additional pigmentsÂ spanning the visible spectrum from blue to red. Historically, classification wasÂ based on pigmentation. At present, the classification of marine algae relies onÂ additional diagnostic characteristics. Although pigmentation is only one of theÂ characteristics used to classify the algae, the original names, which were basedÂ on color, have been retained. The major divisions of seaweed are green algaeÂ (Chlorophyta), red algae (Rhodophyta), and brown algae (Phaeophyta).Â
children.label: MACROALGAE (SEAWEEDS)
MOSSES/HORNWORTS/LIVERWORTS
children.definition: Mosses and Liverworts belong to the Phylum Bryophyta, Class Musci andÂ Hepaticae, respectively. Bryophytes are relatively small plants that grow inÂ moist places on land -- on damp rocks and logs, on the forest floor, in swampsÂ or marshes, or beside streams and pools. In a moss, the sporophyte stage of theÂ life cycle is a relatively simple structure consisting of three parts: a footÂ embedded in the "leafy" green gametophyte, a stalk, and a distal capsule, orÂ sporangium. The gametophyte plants of some liverworts resemble mosses exceptÂ that the "leaves" are scaly in appearance, and the "stem" is prostrate.  OtherÂ liverworts grow as flat green structures lying on the substratum.Â

children.label: ANGIOSPERMS (FLOWERING PLANTS)
children.definition: Flowering Plants are all included within the class Angiospermae. TodayÂ angiosperms are the dominant plant life, their survival helped by theÂ angiosperms' flowers (through pollination), fruit (by being carried to newÂ places), and seeds (which contain food to nourish the young plant). Â

children.label: MICROALGAE
children.definition: Microalgae are microscopic algae. Â

children.label: FERNS
children.definition: Ferns, of the phylum Pterophyta, with 12,000 species, are the largest group ofÂ seedless vascular plants, and are in mainly tropical, temperate habitats. Â
Pertaining to the scientific classification of plants.
children.label: PLANTS
ANIMALS/VERTEBRATES
children.definition: Vertebrates are chordates with a backbone, either of cartilage or bone, and a brain located inside a protective chamber of skull bones.

children.label: MAMMALS
children.definition: The class Mammals are warm-blooded craniates with glandular skin which isÂ typically hairy; Young are fed on milk secreted by mammary glands. Mammals areÂ mostly terrestrial in all habitats from forest to desert, but some fly and someÂ inhabit freshwater or the sea.Â

children.label: BIRDS
children.definition: Birds, of the class Aves, are warm-blooded craniates with a body covering ofÂ feathers; typically with forelimbs modified as wings for active flight. TheyÂ are free living (most can fly) in all terrestrial and surface water habitats;Â some are capable of swimming underwater.Â

Amphibians are craniates with a permeable skin across which respiration  can take place.  Their life cycle includes a shell-less egg which gives  rise to a distinct larval form.  The amphibians are free living in fresh  water and on land (some are arboreal) but all are dependent on water or  damp conditions.
children.label: AMPHIBIANS
FISH
children.definition: Fish are, broadly speaking, any poikilothermic (or organism whose bodyÂ temperature varies according to the temperature of its surroundings) legless,Â aquatic vertebrate that possesses a series of gills on each side of theÂ pharynx, a two-chambered heart, no internal nostrils, and at least a median finÂ as well as a tail fin. Â

children.label: TUNAS AND ALLIES
children.definition: Members of the Family Scombridae, including tunas, albacores, bonitos, and mackerels

children.label: REPTILES
children.definition: Reptiles are cold-blooded tetrapod craniates which breathe using lungs, have aÂ dry, scaly skin and lay large, shelled eggs.  They live in all types ofÂ terrestrial habitats, the majority in tropical regions; many secondarilyÂ freshwater and marine species.Â

children.label: BACTERIA/ARCHAEA
children.definition: Bacteria are a group of microscopic, one-celled protists.Â

Blue-Green Algae, now called cyanobacteria, are good examples ofÂ photoautotrophic eubacteria.  They are also among the most commonÂ photoautotrophs on Earth.  Most live in ponds and other freshwater habitats. Â They may grow as mucus-sheathed chains of cells, which can form dense, slimyÂ mats near the surface of nutrient-enriched water. Â
children.label: CYANOBACTERIA (BLUE-GREEN ALGAE)
PROTISTS
children.definition: Protists are of the Kingdom Protista and are one of the diverse eukaryotes,Â single-celled species of which may resemble the first eukaryotic cells.  At theÂ present they are categorized by what they are not (not bacteria, fungi, plants,Â or animals). Â

children.label: FLAGELLATES
children.definition: Flagellates are free-living predators and parasites bearing one to severalÂ flagella. The free-living types abound in freshwater or marine habitats.Â Parasitic types live in the moist tissues of plants and animals, includingÂ humans. Â

Coccolithophores are extremely small, flagellated organisms of the KingdomÂ Protista, which are adorned with buttons of calcium carbonate, calledÂ coccoliths.  The coccolithophores appear to contribute significantly to marineÂ food chains by capturing radiant energy and manufacturing food duringÂ photosynthesis.	The coccolithophores make up a considerable portion of theÂ microscopic life in warmer regions, such as the Sargasso Sea. Â
children.label: COCCOLITHOPHORES
AMOEBAS
children.definition: The genus amoebae includes several protozoan species.  Although, through theÂ microscope it appears as a shapeless mass of cytoplasm surrounded by a thinÂ membrane.  Amoebae perform all of life's functions.Â

Radiolarians belong to the class Actinopoda, meaning "ray feet" which refers toÂ the numerous slender, reinforced pseudopods that radiate from the body. LikeÂ foramniferans, the radiolarians are well represented in the fossil record, forÂ they have ornate, silica-hardened parts that resist degradation. RadiolarianÂ shells contribute to the formation of siliceous rocks such as chert. Â
children.label: RADIOLARIANS
FORAMINIFERS
children.definition: Foraminifers of subclass Sarcodina are amoeboid marine protozoa that secrete aÂ calcareous, many-chambered test in which to live and then extrude protoplasmÂ through pores to form a layer over the outside. Â

children.label: CILIATES
children.definition: Ciliates are members of the phylum Ciliophora. As their name implies, ciliatesÂ use numerous cilia as locomotor organelles.  The ciliates exhibit the greatestÂ elaboration of subcellular organelles of any protozoan group, where, forÂ example, the Paramecium has a special oral groove and cytopharynx, into whichÂ indigestible wastes are expelled from food vacuoles. Â

Diatoms are algae of the Phylum Ochrista that lack flagella.  They have aÂ jewel-like appearance.	They play an extremely important role in aquatic foodÂ webs in that they are the second most abundant component of marine planktonÂ (after blue-green algae). Â
children.label: DIATOMS
SPOROZOANS
children.definition: Sporozoans are one of four categories of protozoans. Sporozoan is an informalÂ name for parasitic protistans that complete part of the life cycle insideÂ specific cells of host organisms.  Many sporozoans cause human diseases. Â Plasmodium causes malaria while Cryptosporidium strains which contaminate manyÂ water supplies can cause serious intestinal disorders. Â

One of the taxonomic kingdoms, comprising eukaryotic, non-photosynthetic organisms, which obtain nutrients by the absorption of organic compounds from their surroundings. Fungi usually have chitin-containing cell walls and may be unicellular, filamentous (mycelial), or plasmoidal.
children.label: FUNGI

children.definition: Yeasts are members of the Ascomycota Division.	Yeasts are unicellular and theyÂ reproduce asexually by budding. Â
children.label: YEASTS/TRUFFLES

children.definition: A type of heterotrophic protistan with a life cycle that includes free-livingÂ cells that at some point congregate and differentiate into spore-bearingÂ structures.Â
children.label: SLIME MOLDS
MUSHROOMS
children.definition: Mushrooms are a type of fungi (which are major decomposers that engage inÂ extracellular digestion and absorption of organic matter). Mushrooms are of theÂ order Basidiomycota, the club fungi, which have a fruiting body in theÂ aboveground portion of the plant.   Â

children.label: LICHENS
children.definition: Lichens are a type of composite organism, which consists of a fungus and anÂ algae living in symbiotic association.Â

Water quality refers to the physical, chemical, and biological characteristics  of water with respect to its suitability for a particular use. Water chemistry  refers to the chemical characteristics of water.
children.label: WATER QUALITY/WATER CHEMISTRY
CARBON DIOXIDE
children.definition: One of the major greenhouse gases. Human-generated carbon dioxide is causedÂ mainly by the burning of fossil fuels and deforestation. The chemical formulaÂ for carbon dioxide is CO2. Long-term measurements of CO2 in the atmosphere areÂ conducted at Manua Loa, Hawaii and several international monitoring stationsÂ around the world.Â

children.label: STABLE ISOTOPES
children.definition: Any non-radioactive form of a chemical element, having the same atomic weightÂ as that element (i.e. same number of protons), but a different number ofÂ neutrons. Â
A measure of the average kinetic energy of the vibration of water molecules.
children.label: WATER TEMPERATURE
CONDUCTIVITY
children.definition: The degree to which an electrical current can pass through water due to  ions dissolved in the water. Salinity is often calculated from  conductivity and temperature.
Contaminants are foreign agent that are present, as in water or sediment whichÂ may produce a physical or chemical change.  Â
children.label: CONTAMINANTS

children.definition: Chlorophyll is the green pigment in plants responsible for absorbing the  light energy required for photosynthesis.
children.label: CHLOROPHYLL
WATER POTABILITY
children.definition: Water that is safe and palatable for human consumption.

children.label: ORGANIC MATTER
children.definition: Soil constituents consisting of a wide range of  organic (carbonaceous)Â substances, including living organisms, carbonaceous remains of organisms whichÂ once occupied the soil, and organic compounds produced by current and pastÂ metabolism in the soil.Â

children.label: TOXIC CHEMICALS
children.definition: Toxic Chemicals are identified as chemicals that can cause serious harm to the environment including lakes, oceans, and biota.

children.label: TURBIDITY
children.definition: Measurement of the degree of scattering of light in water, related to theÂ amount of suspended material in the water. Â
Definition is not yet available.Â
children.label: PHOSPHOROUS COMPOUNDS
NITROGEN COMPOUNDS
children.definition: Nitrogen compounds refer to the nitrogen particles that come from industrial manufacturing which cause contamination to water resources.
A measure of the alkaline or acid strength of a substance.  pH is defined asÂ the logarithm of the reciprocal of the hydrogen ion concentration of aÂ solution. Â
children.label: PH

children.definition: The alkalinity of seawater is the combined negative charges due to  hydrogen carbonate and carbonate ions expressed in molal concentrations.  Alkalinity is based on seawater being electrically neutral and is  determined by titration (and therefore given the subscript t).
children.label: ALKALINITY

children.definition: A colorless, odorless, gaseous element, constituting 21 percent of the volume of the atmsophere, and essential for aerobic forms of life. Gaseous oxygen has a chemical forumla of O2. Despite its abundance in air, the concentration of oxygen in water is usually quite low, at just a few parts per million. Nevertheless, this concentration is a good indicator of water quality. If it is too low, many organisms, including fish, will die.
children.label: OXYGEN
RADIOISOTOPES
children.definition: Any radioactive form of a chemical element, having the same atomic weight asÂ that element (i.e. same number of protons), but a different number of neutrons.Â Used in a variety of oceanic applications such as dating and movement of waterÂ masses. Â
Trace metals are metals in extremely small quantities, almost at the molecular level, that reside in or are present in animal and plant cells and tissue.
children.label: TRACE METALS
HYDROCARBONS
children.definition: Organic compounds composed entirely of carbon and hydrogen atoms. Â

children.label: CARCINOGENS
children.definition: The measure of water quality based on the presence of carcinogens.
Trace elements are chemical elements that are present in minute quantities im  water.
children.label: WATER TRACE ELEMENTS

children.definition: The concentartion of ions in water. Ions are positively or negatively charged  atom or group of atoms.
children.label: WATER ION CONCENTRATION
NUTRIENTS
children.definition: Nutrients are elements essential for growth and survival of a given organism. Â Directly or indirectly, nutrients have roles in metabolism that no otherÂ nutrients fulfills. Â
Materials less than 0.45 micrometer in length, as distinguished from  suspended solids and other particulate matter, which are greater than 0.45  micrometer in length.
children.label: DISSOLVED SOLIDS
DISSOLVED GASES
children.definition: Elements or compounds of gaseous form, dissolved in seawater. When keyed in  a DIF, they do not typically include carbon dioxide, oxygen, nitrogen, or  nitrous oxide, since these are their own variables.
Related to the processes of depositing acidic (pH less than 7.0) material intoÂ a body of water.Â
children.label: ACID DEPOSITION

children.definition: Measurement of the percentage of light received at a photo cell placed at  fixed distances from a light source.
children.label: LIGHT TRANSMISSION

children.definition: A measure of water quality based on the presence of Benthic organisms.
children.label: BENTHIC INDEX

children.definition: Dissolved or particulate substances that are not hydrocarbons or hydrocarbonÂ derivatives. Variables such as dissolved inorganic matter (DIM) or particulateÂ inorganic matter (PIM) are included as detailed variables under inorganicÂ matter. Â
children.label: INORGANIC MATTER
SUSPENDED SOLIDS
children.definition: Particulate matter suspended in the water column, greater than  0.45 micrometers, as distinguished from dissolved solids which are less  than 0.45 micrometers.	Synonymous with Particulates.
Pertaining to the area from which a surface watercourse or a groundwater system derives its water.
children.label: WATERSHED CHARACTERISTICS
WATERSHED BOUNDARIES
children.definition: Defined by topographic divides and delineate areas where surface-water runoff drains into a common surface-water body, such as a lake or section of a stream.

children.label: WATERSHED DRAINAGE
children.definition: The main site where watershed water drains.
The distance water must travel to reach the drainage site.
children.label: WATERSHED LENGTH
WATERSHED SLOPE
children.definition: The steepness of the highest point to the lower elevations.

children.label: WATERSHED SHAPE
children.definition: The watershed can vary from streams to many various cracks.
Refers to the chemical composition of the surface water of rivers, lakes,  streams, and reservoirs including water quality and contamination.
children.label: SURFACE WATER CHEMISTRY
AQUIFER RECHARGE
children.definition: The processes involved in the replenishment of water to the zone of saturation.Â

children.label: RECHARGE AMOUNT
children.definition: Amount of water needed to replenish ground water.

children.label: RECHARGE FREQUENCY
children.definition: Number of times water goes through a cycle to be replenished.
The depth of the saturated rock through which water can easily move.
children.label: AQUIFER DEPTH

children.definition: The pattern followed by the waters of an area as they pass or flow off inÂ surface streams.Â
children.label: DRAINAGE

children.definition: Direction in which standing water is removed from am area.
children.label: DRAINAGE DIRECTION
DRAINAGE AMOUNT
children.definition: The amount of water being drained from a specified area.

children.label: INUNDATION
children.definition: Flooding, by the rise and spread of water, of a land surface that is not normally submerged.

children.label: INUNDATION FREQUENCY
children.definition: Number of times a surface is covered with water in a single period.

children.label: INUNDATION AMOUNT
children.definition: Amount of water that covers an area during flooding.

children.label: INUNDATION LEVEL
children.definition: The level of the water that covers an area during flooding.

children.label: FLOOD FREQUENCY
children.definition: Flood frequency is the concept of the probable frequency of occurrence of a given flood.

children.label: FLOOD LEVELS
children.definition: Average height flood water reaches.

children.label: FLOODS
children.definition: The condition that occurs when water overflows the natural or artificialÂ confines of a stream or other body of water, or accumulates by drainage overÂ low-lying areas.Â
The measurement of the vertical distance from the surface of a body of water to the floor.
children.label: WATER DEPTH
HYDROPERIOD
children.definition: A given amount of time in which a river/stream system is active; i.e., water  is passing through the system(s).
Pertaining to the measurement of force per unit area exerted on water by the overlying column of water.
children.label: WATER PRESSURE
HYDROPATTERN
children.definition: The hieracrchical (branch-like) pattern that is found within river and  stream systems.

children.label: TOTAL RUNOFF
children.definition: The total runoff is equal to the total precipitation less the losses caused by evapotranspiration, storage, and other such abtractions.

children.label: RUNOFF RATE
children.definition: Rate at which water is discharged in surface streams.

children.label: RUNOFF
children.definition: The measurement of the flow of water in a stream, usually expressed in cubic feet per second; the net effect of storms, accumulation, transpiration, melt, seepage, evaporation, and percolation.

children.label: STAGE HEIGHT
children.definition: The elevation of the water level of a lake, river, stream or other body of water above a common datum.
All bodies of water on the surface of the Earth.
children.label: TOTAL SURFACE WATER

children.definition: The processes involved in the amount of water released from a flowing body of water.
children.label: WATER YIELD

children.definition: Average amount of water flowing through a point in the stream per second.
children.label: AVERAGE FLOW
BASE FLOW
children.definition: The portion of stream flow that is not runoff and results from seepage of water from the ground into a channel slowly over time. The primary source of running water in a stream during dry weather.

children.label: PEAK FLOW
children.definition: Peak flow is due to rainwater pushing out water that had been stored in wetlands or groundwater.

children.label: FLOW VELOCITY
children.definition: Flow velocity is the speed at which a fluid flows.

River: A large, natural freshwater surface stream having a permanent seasonal flow and moving toward a sea, lake, or another river in a definite channel. Stream: A body of running water moving under the influence of gravity to lower levels in a narrow, clearly defined natural channel.
children.label: RIVERS/STREAMS

children.definition: Wetlands is a term for a broad group of wet habitats. They are transitional lands between terrestrial and aquatic ecosystems where the lands may be permanently or intermittently water covered.
children.label: WETLANDS

children.definition: An area of land where surface water from rain, melting snow, or ice converges to a single point at a lower elevation, usually the exit of the basin, where the waters join another waterbody, such as a river, lake, reservoir, estuary, wetland, sea, or ocean.
children.label: LAKES/RESERVOIRS
WATER CHANNELS
children.definition: The deeper portion of a waterway carrying the main current.

children.label: DRAINAGE BASINS
children.definition: An area of land where surface water from rain, melting snow, or ice converges to a single point at a lower elevation, usually the exit of the basin, where the waters join another waterbody, such as a river, lake, reservoir, estuary, wetland, sea, or ocean.
Water features that exist on the surface of the Earth.
children.label: SURFACE WATER FEATURES
SURFACE WATER
children.definition: Pertains to all water present above the substrate or soil surface including water contained in an ocean, river, stream, lake, pond, lagoon, or impoundment reservoir.

children.label: AVALANCHE
children.definition: Pertaining to the measuerment of a large mass of snow, ice, soil, rock,  falling rapidly from heights far above a lowland area.
Pertaining to the characteristics of the layer of ice crystals that  forms between the ground and snow cover by sublimation.  It's also  referred to as sugar snow.
children.label: DEPTH HOAR

children.definition: Pertaining to the observable differences that separate/distinguish one  snow/ice unit from another.
children.label: SNOW FACIES
SNOW COVER
children.definition: Pertaining to the extent, depth, and longevity of snow pack.

children.label: ICE EXTENT
children.definition: Pertaining to the geographical extent of ice on continental land masses.
Pertaining to the extent, thickness, longevity, etc. of ice formations  that occur on river systems.
children.label: RIVER ICE
SNOW DENSITY
children.definition: Pertaining to the ratio between the volume of snow, and the amount of  meltwater derived from that volume of snow.
Pertaining to the measurement of the amount of water in a given snow  pack.
children.label: SNOW WATER EQUIVALENT

children.definition: Pertaining to the extent, depth, and other characteristics of frozen  subsoil located in arctic/subarctic areas
children.label: PERMAFROST

children.definition: Pertaining to the measurement, and analysis to ice formation on inland  bodies of salt or fresh water.
children.label: LAKE ICE

children.definition: Pertaining to the net increase, or decrease in energy due to snow  formation, melting, evaporation, etc..
children.label: SNOW ENERGY BALANCE
SNOW MELT
children.definition: Pertaining to the rate and extent of melting snow pack(s).
Pertaining to the measurement, rates, geographical extent of freezing,  and melting of snow and ice cover.
children.label: FREEZE/THAW
SNOW DEPTH
children.definition: Pertaining to the thickness of snow pack throughout the year.

children.label: ICE GROWTH/MELT
children.definition: Pertaining to the measurement of ice growth/melting rates, and annual  changes in those rates.
Pertaining to the occurence, extent, and severity of whiteout conditions.
children.label: WHITEOUT

children.definition: Pertaining to the rate at which ice formations (glaciers, ice sheets, etc.)  are moving.
children.label: ICE VELOCITY
FROST
children.definition: Pertaining to the measurement, geographic extent, and seasonality of  frost.
Defined as the horizontal displacement of ice over an area.
children.label: ICE MOTION

children.definition: The order and thickness of layers within the snowpack.
children.label: SNOW STRATIGRAPHY

children.definition: Refers to the chemical composition of snow and ice as determined from snow  cores, ice cores, and snow pits.
children.label: SNOW/ICE CHEMISTRY
ALBEDO
children.definition: Albedo is the ratio of the radiation (radiant energy or luminous energy)Â reflected by a surface to that incident on it. Snow and cloud surfaces have aÂ high albedo, because most of the energy of the visible solar spectrum isÂ reflected. Vegetation and ocean surfaces have low albedo, because they absorb aÂ large fraction of the energy. Clouds are the chief cause of variations in theÂ Earth's albedo.Â
Pertaining to the measurement and geographic extent of ice thickness on  the continental land masses.
children.label: ICE DEPTH/THICKNESS

children.definition: Pertaining to the measured internal temperature of snow/ice pack(s).
children.label: SNOW/ICE TEMPERATURE

children.definition: Pertaining to the study of frozen water over the  Earth's surface.
children.label: SNOW/ICE
ICEBERGS
children.definition: A massive piece of ice of greatly varying shape, protruding more than 5m above  sea-level, which has broken away from a glacier, and which may be afloat or  aground. Icebergs may be described as tabular, dome-shaped, sloping, pinnacled, weathered or glacier bergs.
A mass of land ice, formed by the further recrystallization of firn, flowing  continuously from higher to lower elevations.
children.label: GLACIERS
ICE SHEETS
children.definition: A continuous sheet of land ice that covers a very large area and moves outward  in many directions. This type of ice mass is so thick as to mask the land  surface contours, in contrast to the smaller and thinner highland ice. The  continental glacier of Greenland is sometimes called the Inland Ice. This term  is often used to describe the great ice masses that characterized the ice ages.

children.label: GLACIER MOTION/ICE SHEET MOTION
children.definition: The rate of flow of the glacier/ice sheet over a period of time.
Pertaining to the measured height of large thick, glaciers, with an area of  at least 50,000 sq. km, covering a continuous stretch of land and growing  in all directions.
children.label: GLACIER ELEVATION/ICE SHEET ELEVATION

children.definition: Surface relief of the land. Topography usually is measured in meters above sea  level. The topography can be very different from one location to another.  Topography can be flat, or mountainous, or hilly.
children.label: GLACIER TOPOGRAPHY/ICE SHEET TOPOGRAPHY

children.definition: Pertaining to the reduction of a glacier due to melting and/or  evaporation.
children.label: ABLATION ZONES/ACCUMULATION ZONES

children.definition: Rounded, well-bonded snow that is older han one year. A permeable aggregate of  small ice grains with densities greater than 0.55 up to 0.82 where begins  glacial ice. (Glossary of glacier terms/Northeastern Illinois University)
children.label: FIRN
GLACIER FACIES
children.definition: In general, facies are the set of all characteristics of a sedimetary rock that indicates its particular environment of deposition and which distinguish it  from other facies in the same rock. Glacial facies refer to the characteristic  nature of glacial ice and/or the processes by which the ice formed and  processes by which  rock debris from the bed is entrained into the ice.

children.label: GLACIER MASS BALANCE/ICE SHEET MASS BALANCE
children.definition: Mass balance describes the net gain or loss of snow and ice through a given  year. It is usually expressed in terms of water gain or loss.

children.label: GLACIER THICKNESS/ICE SHEET THICKNESS
children.definition: The difference in height between two levels in the glacier or ice sheet.

Glaciers are masses of land ice, formed by the further recrystallization of  firn, flowing continuously from higher to lower elevations. Ice sheets are a  continuous sheet of land ice that covers a very large area and moves outward in many directions. This type of ice mass is so thick as to mask the land surface  contours, in contrast to the smaller and thinner highland ice. The continental  glacier of Greenland is sometimes called the Inland Ice. This term is often  used to describe the great ice masses that characterized the ice ages.
children.label: GLACIERS/ICE SHEETS

children.definition: Pertaining to the various chemical substances contained within  groundwater.
children.label: GROUNDWATER CHEMISTRY
GROUND WATER PROCESSES/MEASUREMENTS
children.definition: Describes how ground water is measured and the various ground water processes throughout the ground water system.

children.label: INTRUSION AMOUNT
children.definition: Amount of seawater that moves into fresh water aquifer.

children.label: INTRUSION RATE
children.definition: The speed at which seawater moves into the fresh water aquifer within certain time period.

children.label: SALTWATER INTRUSION
children.definition: The intrusion of saline marine water into fresh groundwater supplies along coasts, often due to the extraction of fresh groundwater for human consumption.
Pertaining to the rate that substances spread through an aquifer.
children.label: DISPERSION

children.definition: The rate at which clay particles separate from one other in moist soil.
children.label: DISPERSION RATE

children.definition: The number of clay particles that separate from one other in moist oil in a single period.
children.label: DISPERSION FREQUENCY
DISCHARGE AMOUNT
children.definition: The volume of water flow, including any suspended solids which is transported through a given cross-sectional area.

children.label: DISCHARGE RATE
children.definition: The rate of water flow, including any suspended solids which is transported through a given cross-sectional area.

children.label: DISCHARGE
children.definition: The volume of water flow, including any suspended solids which is transported through a given cross-sectional area.
Direction in which standing water is removed from am area.
children.label: DRAINAGE DIRECTION
DRAINAGE AMOUNT
children.definition: Amount of water removed from am area.

children.label: DRAINAGE
children.definition: Pertaining to the process/method that water discharges out of an aquifer.
The rate at which rain/snow/water seeps into the subsurface soil and rock.
children.label: INFILTRATION RATE

children.definition: Amount of water that infiltrates the subsurface soil and rocks.
children.label: INFILTRATION AMOUNT

children.definition: Amount of water that infiltrates the subsurface soil and rocks in a single period.
children.label: INFILTRATION FREQUENCY
INFILTRATION
children.definition: Pertaining to the process by which substances enter an aquifer.

children.label: LAND SUBSIDENCE
children.definition: Pertaining to the process by which the land surface sinks over an aquifer as water is pumped out of it.
The amount of groundwater that is withdrawn from certain types of rocks.
children.label: SUBSIDENCE AMOUNT
SUBSIDENCE RATE
children.definition: The rate of groundwater that is withdrawn from certain types of rocks.

children.label: PERCOLATION AMOUNT
children.definition: The amount of fluids being filtered through porous materials.

children.label: PERCOLATION RATE
children.definition: The speed of filtering fluids through porous materials within a certain time.
Pertaining to the movement of water through the pore space of an aquifer.
children.label: PERCOLATION

children.definition: Amount of water needed to replenish ground water.
children.label: RECHARGE AMOUNT

children.definition: Number of times water goes through a cycle to be replenished.
children.label: RECHARGE FREQUENCY

children.definition: The depth of the saturated rock through which water can easily move.
children.label: AQUIFER DEPTH
AQUIFER RECHARGE
children.definition: The primary method that water enters an aquifer.

children.label: SUBSURFACE FLOW
children.definition: The flow of water beneath earth's surface as part of the water cycle. In the water cycle, when precipitation falls on the earth's land, some of the water flows on the surface forming streams and rivers.
Average amount of water flowing through a point in the stream per second.
children.label: AVERAGE FLOW
PEAK FLOW
children.definition: Peak flow is due to rainwater pushing out water that had been stored in wetlands or groundwater.
The speed at which a fluid flows.
children.label: FLOW VELOCITY
GROUND WATER FEATURES
children.definition: Water features that exist below the surface of the Earth.

children.label: AQUIFERS
children.definition: Pertaining to subsurface rock layers that store and transport water through pore-space within the units.

children.label: FRESHWATER SPRINGS
children.definition: Pertaining to the zones where the water table intersects the land surface, and water flows out of an aquifer without needing to be pumped out of a well,
The surface defined by the level of freestanding water in fissures and pores at the top of the saturated zone.
children.label: WATER TABLE

children.definition: The level below which the ground is completely saturated with water.
children.label: WATER TABLE DEPTH
GROUND WATER
children.definition: Ground water in its broadest sense includes all subsurface water whether in its liquid, solid or gaseous state, provided it is not chemically combined with the minerals present. In practice, it is all subsurface water that participates in the hydrological cycle.

Solar energetic particles are high energy particles occasionally emitted from active areas on the Sun, associated with solar flares and coronal mass ejections. The EarthÂ¿s magnetic field keeps them out of regions close to Earth (except for the polar caps) but they can pose a hazard to space travelers far from Earth. Solar energetic particles are somtimes referred to as solar cosmic rays.
children.label: SOLAR ENERGETIC PARTICLE FLUX
SUB-ATOMIC PARTICLE FLUX
children.definition: These particles include atomic constituents such as electrons, protons, and  neutrons (protons and neutrons are actually composite particles, made up of  quarks), as well as other particles such as photons and neutrinos which are  produced copiously in the sun. However, most of the particles that have been  discovered and studied are not encountered under normal earth conditions; they  are produced in cosmic rays and during scattering processes in particle  accelerators.

An alpha particle has positive charge and consists of two protons and  two neutrons (the nucleus of a helium atom).  Alpha particles can cause   ionization of neutral atoms.   Flux is the rate of flow through a reference  surface, measured in particles per unit area.
children.label: ALPHA PARTICLE FLUX
ELECTRON FLUX
children.definition: The rate of flow of electrons through a reference surface. In cgs  units, measured in electrons s-1, or simply s-1.

An atom (or molecule) which has become charged as a result of gaining or losing one or more orbiting electrons. A completely ionized atom is one stripped of all its electrons. Heavy ions are those ionized particles at high energy (MeV range). Flux is the rate of flow through a reference surface, measured in particles per unit area.
children.label: ION FLUX

children.definition: The rate of flow of protons through a reference surface, measured in particles per unit area.
children.label: PROTON FLUX

children.definition: Solar energetic particles consisting of nuclei of elements heavier than protons and electrons.
children.label: HEAVY NUCLEI FLUX
NEUTRAL PARTICLE FLUX
children.definition: Neutral atoms or neurons in the solar wind observed in space and on earth at energies of around 10*7 - 10*9 ev.
The rate of flow of x-rays through a reference surface.
children.label: X-RAY FLUX
PARTICLE DENSITY
children.definition: The number of particles present per unit volume (typically a cubic centimeter).

Total Electron Content (TEC) is the number of free electrons in a column of the Earth's ionosphere. TEC is affected by geomagnetic storms and measurements of TEC is crucial for calibrating measurements obtained by active radar and altimeter instruments such as used on TOPEX/Poseidon. Measurements of TEC are a by-product if sea surface height measurements and TEC global ionosphere climatologies have been developed from TOPEX/Poseidon measurements.
children.label: TOTAL ELECTRON CONTENT

children.definition: The energy deposited into the atmosphere from ionization of atmospheric  gases, as well as excitation of photometric and x-ray emissions.  The  ionospheric effects resulting from the energy deposition by incident particle  fluxes include:  - production of secondary electrons (ionization)  - enhanced steady-state electron density  - photometric emissions   - bremsstrahlung x-rays  - conductivity changes  - E-region horizontal currents   - plasma heating(collisional, Joule heating)  - magnetic field perturbations
children.label: ENERGY DEPOSITION

children.definition: Particle composition refers to the elemental composition of solar particles, such as protons, electrons, atoms, etc.
children.label: PARTICLE COMPOSITION
PARTICLE DISTRIBUTION FUNCTIONS
children.definition: A characterization of the density of particles located at a given point in phase space (a combination  of either velocity or position coordinates) at a given time. The velocity-space distribution function gives the number of particles with a particular velocity; the position-space distribution function is synonymous with the particle density in position-space.  Different combinations of position and spatial coordinates are useful in different problems.

The distance per unit time of particles propagating through the Earth's atmosphere or through the interplanetary magnetic fields as a result of solar events. For example, the solar wind has a 'fast' component or high speed stream with a speed of about 10*5 M/sec. and a 'slow' component of about 5x10*4 m/sec.
children.label: PARTICLE SPEED

children.definition: The measure of the heat of an object, namely of the average kinetic energy of the randomly moving particles in an object.    Reference: the Cambridge Encyclopedia of the Sun, The Cambridge University Press,  Cambridge, CB2, 2RU, UK, 2110.
children.label: PARTICLE TEMPERATURE
IONOSPHERE/MAGNETOSPHERE DYNAMICS
children.definition: Refers to dynamic processess of the Earth's ionosphere and solar magnetosphere  triggered by solar events. The magnetosphere is the magnetic cavity surrounding the earth, carved out of the passing solar wind by virtue of the geomagnetic  field, which prevents, or at least impedes, the direct entry of the solar wind  plasma into the cavity. The ionosphere is the region of the earth's upper  atmosphere containing a small percentage of free electrons and ions produced by photoionization of the constituents of the atmosphere by solar ultraviolet  radiation at very short wavelengths (l.t.1000 angstroms).  The ionosphere  significantly influences radiowave propagation of frequencies less than about  30 MHz.

children.label: GEOMAGNETIC INDICES
children.definition: Geomagnetic indices are an indicator of geomagntic activity caused by solar  events. Typical geomagntic indices are: a, A, Ap, Dst, K, and Kp.   The A-index,  for example, is a daily average composed of 3-hour data points.  Geomagnetic  indices can be used in conjunction with solar"wind" data to predict the onset  and intensity of geomagnetic storms.

An Electromagnetic field (EM field) is the region of space near electric currents, magnets, broadcasting antennas etc., regions in which electric and magnetic forces may act, for example on charged particles.
children.label: MAGNETIC FIELDS/MAGNETIC CURRENTS

children.definition: The process in which a neutral atom or molecule is given a net electrical charge. The atomic process in which ions are produced by removing one or more electrons from an atom, ion, or molecule, typically be collisions with atoms or electrons (collisional ionization), or by interaction with electromagnetic radiation (photo-ionization).  Reference: the Cambridge Encyclopedia od the Sun, The Cambridge University Press   Cambridge, CB2, 2RU, UK, 2001.
children.label: ION CHEMISTRY/IONIZATION
ELECTRIC FIELDS/ELECTRIC CURRENTS
children.definition: An electric field is the region in which electric forces can be observed, e.g.  near a charged particle.  As a field, it may also be viewed as a region of  space  modified by the presence of electric charges. An electric current is a  continuous flow of electrons and/or ions, through a material which conducts  electricity. A current usually flows in a closed circuit, without beginning or  end. In daily life, currents are generally driven through wires by voltages  produced by batteries or generators.  In space plasmas, currents are  produced by the movement of charged paricles in the presence of a   magnetic field.

children.label: AURORAE
children.definition: A faint visual phenomenon associated with geomagnetic activity,  which occurs mainly in the high-latitude night sky.  Typical  auroras are 100 to 250 km above the ground.   The phenomenon  caused by collisions between charged particles, atoms, and ions  in the Earth's ionosphere and upper atmosphere.

children.label: GEOMAGNETIC FORECASTS
children.definition: The levels of geomagnetic field activity, or disturbance, currently used in the long-term (up to 27 days) forecasts are labelled qualitatively for general  usage. For each of the three major zones (subauroral, auroral, polar cap), the  range of activity is divided into four classifications: quiet, unsettled,  active, storm. The actual parameter used for reporting and forecasting magnetic activity is a daily index. It is known as DRX and is the average of the hourly  ranges (maximum minus minimum during each hour) in the X (northward) component  of the magnetic field intensity for a day (the UT [or GMT] day), i.e., DRX for the  zone is the mean of 24 values. Because this averaging process has the effect of smoothing (filtering) the more rapid fluctuations in the field, the qualitative descriptors are defined rather differently than for the short-term forecasts.  Units are nanoteslas (nT).

A magnetic storm is a large-scale disturbance of the magnetosphere, often initiated by the arrival of an interplanetary shock originating at the Sun. A magnetic storm is marked by the injection of an appreciable number of ions from the magnetotail into the ring current, a process accompanied by increased auroral displays. The strengthened ring current causes a world-wide drop in the equatorial magnetic field, taking perhaps 12 hours to reach its greatest intensity, followed by a more gradual recovery.
children.label: MAGNETIC STORMS

children.definition: A plasma is a gas containing ions, electrons, and a magnetic field, and therefore capable of  conducting electric currents. A plasma wave is a set of particles under the influence of electromagnetic fields, exhibiting wave-like motions with amplitude and periodicity.
children.label: PLASMA WAVES
SOLAR WIND
children.definition: The solar wind is hot solar plasma spreading from the solar corona in all directions, at a typical speed of 300-1,000 km/sec. The solar wind is essentially the hot solar corona on expanding in all directions into the interplanetary space. The solar wind is diverted around the Earth by the Earth's magnetic field, although some solar particles enter the Earth's field at the poles. The solar wind carries coronal magnetic fields by a process known as frozen in the flux. If these frozen in fields have the same North-South orientation as the Earth's magnetic field, energy can be transferred into the Earth's magnetosphere, leading to geomagnetic storms.

children.label: SOLAR ACTIVITY
children.definition: Any change in the sun's appearance or behavior. The sun's activity  is described as being very low, low, moderate, high or very high.  Solar activity changes over a period of, on average, 11 years. At  solar maximum, the solar activity is high and so too the Extreme  Ultraviolet (EUV) radiation output which affects the ionosphere. At solar   minimum, the opposite is true.

children.label: SOLAR FLARES
children.definition: A sudden and violent release of matter and energy within a solar activity region in the form of electromagnetic radiation, energetic particles, shock waves, lasting a few minutes to hours.	Solar flares accelerate charged particles into interplanetary space.

children.label: SOLAR ULTRAVIOLET EMISSIONS
children.definition: Radiation with wavelengths roughly between 200 and 400 nanometers. TheseÂ wavelengths are shorter than those which characterize visible light.Â Observations from satellites in the UV and extreme UV (EUV) wavelengths haveÂ demonstrated the sun's UV variability over short time scales of days and weeks.Â UV variability is linked to solar magnetic activity phenomena such as flaresÂ and plages. Studies of the UV and EUV irradiance variability may have indicatedÂ influences on the Earth's climate dynamics.Â

children.label: SOLAR RADIO WAVE EMISSIONS
children.definition: Also known as solar radio emissions. Emissions of the sun in radio  wavelengths from centimeters to decameters, under both quiet and disturbed  conditions.

An extended region in the solar corona where the density and temperature are lower than other places in the corona. The weak diverging and open magnetic field lines in coronal holes extend radially outward and do not immediately return to the sun. The high speed part of the solar wind comes from coronal holes.  Reference: the Cambridge Encyclopedia of the Sun, The Cambridge University Press,  Cambridge, CB2, 2RU, UK, 2001.
children.label: CORONA HOLES

children.definition: The outermost, high temperature region of the solar atmosphere. Above the chromosphere and transition region, consisting of almost fully ionized plasma contained in closed magnetic field loops, called coronal loops or expanding out along open magnetic field lines to form the solar wind. The corona is a highly rarefied, low density gas, with electron densities of less than 10*16 electrons/ m*3, heated to temperatures of millions of degrees. The corona is visible to the unaided eye as a white halo during a total eclipse of the sun.
children.label: CORONA
SOLAR ACTIVE REGIONS
children.definition: A region of the solar atmosphere from the photosphere to the corona that develops when strong magnetic fields emerge from inside the sun. The magnetized realm in and around the sunspots is called an active region. Radiation from active regions is enhanced when compared to neighboring areas in the chromosphere a corona over the whole electromagnetic spectrum. They may last from a few hours to a few months. They are the sites of intense explosions, called solar flares.
Solar imagery refers to solar images obtained for research in any spectral wavelength from ground or space-borne platforms.
children.label: SOLAR IMAGERY
SOLAR IRRADIANCE
children.definition: Solar irradiance at the top of the atmosphere on a plane normal to the incidentÂ¿radiation, and at the mean distance of the Earth from the Sun. Solar irradianceÂ¿is also referred to as the solar constant. In satellite remote sensing, theÂ¿solar irradiance is used as an onboard calibration of visible band sensors.Â¿Some climate studies suggest that small variations in the solar irradianceÂ¿associated with solar activity over days to decades may have an effect theÂ¿Earth's climate.Â¿  The intensity of the sun's radiation at different wavelengths. The radiation is generally given in terms of solar constant \ S, defined in terms of flux of total radiation received outside the earth's atmosphere per unit area at mean sun earth distance., and has the value S = 1.34 X 10*6 ergs cm*-2  sec*-1.

The surface of the sun oscillates in certain modes defined by the  numberÂ¿of latitudinal and longitudinal modal planes. The sun vibrates  inÂ¿multiple modes simultaneously, each mode typically having a  differentÂ¿amplitude. Observing the amplitudes of the various solar  oscillationÂ¿modes is a way to look inside the sun. A commonly observed  phenomena is theÂ¿"5-minute" oscillation, but other periods have been  observed from 10 to 160Â¿minutes on the long period scale to about 10  seconds on the short periodÂ¿scale. Also observed are so-called "g-mode"  oscillations (internal gravityÂ¿waves) generated by turbulent convection  below the photosphere.Â¿These oscillations are the result of internal motions of the sun and their study is known as helioseismology.
children.label: SOLAR OSCILLATIONS
SOLAR PROMINENCES/SOLAR FILAMENTS
children.definition: A term identifying cloud-like features in the solar atmosphere. The  features appear as bright structures in the corona above the solar limb  and as dark filaments when seen projected against the solar disk.   Solar filaments are also known as prominences, can appear as arcs and properties can vary with the solar cycle.

children.label: SOLAR X-RAY EMISSIONS
children.definition: Solar X-Ray emissions can consist of X-Ray background flux or X-Ray bursts. A daily average background X-ray flux is in the 1 to 8 angstrom range.  It is a midday minimum designed to reduce the effects of flares. X-Ray burstsare a temporary enhancement of the X-ray emission of the sun.  The time-intensity profile of soft X-ray bursts is similar to that of the H-Alpha profile of an associated flare. Bursts last from minutes to several hours.

children.label: SUNSPOTS
children.definition: An area seen as a dark spot on the PHOTOSPHERE of the sun.  Sunspots  are concentrations of magnetic flux, typically occurring in bipolar  clusters or groups.  They appear dark because they are cooler than the  surrounding photosphere. Sunspots are classified as to their group  characteristics (called the Zurich Sunspot Classification; older sunspot  counting schemes may have used the Wolf Sunspot Number classification).  Satellite observations of the sun (notably by the ACRIM and ERBE sensors)  have demonstrated a correlation between sunspot luminosity changes and  sunspot numbers - a possible influencing factor in Earth's climate  dynamics.

children.label: SOLAR SYNOPTIC MAPS
children.definition: Synoptic maps refer to the state of the entire viewable solar disk at a  given moment in time.

Solar velocity fields are also known as differential rotation. The sun rotates slightly more rapidly at the equator than at the poles. Gases at the equator make about 10 rotations, whiles gases at midlatitudes rotates 9 times and gases at the poles rotates about 7 times. This produces a shear in the gas motions and a pronounced E-W orientation of the magnetic field.
children.label: SOLAR VELOCITY FIELDS

children.definition: Coronal mass ejection (CME) is a huge cloud of hot plasma, occasionally expelled from the Sun. It may accelerate ions and electrons and may travel through interplanetary space as far as the EarthÂ¿s orbit and beyond it, often preceded by a shock front. When the shock reaches Earth, a magnetic storm may result.
children.label: CORONAL MASS EJECTIONS

children.definition: High energy particles and photons emitted by stellar processes. The highest energies have been observed at 10*8 Tev and are believed to come from shocks emanating from galaxies. Solar cosmic rays are protons observed at 1 Gev, having been accelerated by shocks associated with solar flares.
children.label: COSMIC RAYS

children.definition: A linkage between weather changes occuring in widely seperated regions of the globe.  The term "teleconnections" is most commonly applied to variability on monthly or longer timescales and refers to the fact that such correlations suggest that information is propagating between distant points through the atmosphere.
children.label: TELECONNECTIONS

children.definition: The North Pacific Index is the area-weighted sea level pressure over  the region 30N-65N, 160E-140W.
children.label: NORTH PACIFIC OSCILLATION

children.definition: The PNA pattern is one of the most prominent modes of low-frequency  variability in the Northern Hemisphere extratropics, appearing in all  months except June and July. The PNA pattern reflects a quadripole  pattern of height anomalies, with anomalies of similar sign located  south of the Aleutian Islands and over the southeastern United  States. Anomalies with sign opposite to the Aleutian center are  located in the vicinity of Hawaii, and over the intermountain region  of North America (central Canada) during the Winter and Fall (Spring).
children.label: PACIFIC/NORTH AMERICAN (PNA) PATTERN
EAST ATLANTIC PATTERN
children.definition: The East Atlantic (EA) pattern is the second prominent mode of low-frequency variability over the North Atlantic, and appears as a leading mode in all months. The EA pattern is structurally similar to the NAO, and consists of a north-south dipole of anomaly centers spanning the North Atlantic from east to west. The anomaly centers of the EA pattern are displaced southeastward to the approximate nodal lines of the NAO pattern. For this reason, the EA pattern is often interpreted as a âsouthward shiftedâ NAO pattern. However, the lower-latitude center contains a strong subtropical link in association with modulations in the subtropical ridge intensity and location. This subtropical link makes the EA pattern distinct from its NAO counterpart. This EA pattern is similar to that shown in the Barnston and Livezey (1987) study, but is distinctly different from the EA pattern originally defined by Wallace and Gutzler (1981).  The positive phase of the EA pattern is associated with above-average surface temperatures in Europe in all months, and with below-average temperatures over the southern U.S. during January-May and in the north-central U.S. during July-October. It is also associated with above-average precipitation over northern Europe and Scandinavia, and with below-average precipitation across southern Europe.  The EA pattern exhibits very strong multi-decadal variability in the 1950-2004 record, with the negative phase prevailing during much of 1950-1976, and the positive phase occurring during much of 1977-2004. The positive phase of the EA pattern was particularly strong and persistent during 1997-2004, when 3-month running mean values routinely averaged 1.0-2.0 standard deviations above normal.

An ENSO meridional wind anomaly index is calculated for the region 12-2N, 160E-80W from the International Comprehensive Ocean-Atmosphere Data Set (COADS). This region was chosen from a map of meridional wind regressed onto an index of eastern equatorial Pacific SST for the period 1950-79.
children.label: EQUATORIAL PACIFIC MERIDIONAL WIND ANOMALY INDEX
EAST ATLANTIC JET PATTERN
children.definition: The East Atlantic Jet pattern is the third primary mode of low frequency variability found over the North Atlantic, appearing between April and August.
